In calling for the resignation of Mr Sadlier as Director-General of ASIO, I am not reflecting on his loyalty to Australia but on his competence. Mr Sadlier is a competent diplomat; Mr Sadlier is an incompetent Director-General of ASIO. He does not have the temperament or training to be head of ASIO. He was appointed Director-General of ASIO to improve its relations with intelligence services in our region. Mr Sadlier does not know any Asian language; he is not an intelligence officer. Under Mr Sadlier, ASIO has veered from disaster to disaster. The government is well aware that ASIO morale is at an all-time low. For ASIO the game is up.

The government should therefore give serious consideration to amalgamating most of the functions of ASIO with the Australian Federal Police—after, of course, the most vigorous vetting. It is my understanding that many ASIO staff would welcome amalgamation with the Federal Police. They realise that ASIO is no longer a viable organisation. They realise that ASIO is not held in high regard by the government or overseas intelligence organisations. They also realise that ASIO is beyond micro-level management reform, re-organisation or even the appointment of yet another new Director-General. Increasingly, even the government is conceding that, given the Iranian embassy fiasco and the cost of protracted investigations and inquiries into ASIO, ASIO is no longer cost effective. The government's continuing inquiries into ASIO are evidence of this belief. From 1987-88 to 1993-94, ASIO vetted over 109,000 Australians; only one adverse and nine qualified assessments were issued. These figures would be laughable, if the situation concerning the integrity and efficiency of ASIO were not so serious. They underline the point that even ASIO's vetting function has become obsolete.

The matters I have raised today are too important to be whitewashed by the government. There are currently three security inquiries taking place: the inquiry of Mr Justice Samuels into ASIS; ASIO's own internal inquiry into Russian penetration; and the inquiry of Mr Michael Cook into national security and the penetration of ASIO. There is no valid reason why the major findings of these inquiries cannot be disclosed to this House and the Australian people; I call on the government to do so.

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome this opportunity to speak on the appropriation bills for 1994-95. Today I would particularly like to address my remarks to the government's funding of migrant resource centres within the immigration and ethnic affairs portfolio. This Labor government spent $5.8 million in the 1993-94 budget period to support more than 25 migrant resource centres throughout Australia. In fact, the Macarthur Migrant Resource Centre has been a happy participant in this program, receiving more than $330,000 in the last two federal budgets.

PARA.TAB: This is one of the things that makes us different from our conservative opponents: we recognise the fundamental importance of multicultural tolerance and cooperation in this country—and we are prepared to do something about it. This government is prepared to put its money into the support of organisations whose work is absolutely invaluable in encouraging real access and equity in our society. This is not the cosmetic pretence at multicultural acceptance that the opposition offers. Our government has made a commitment to empowerment and equality, and it is serious about that commitment. It is prepared to commit both money and other resources to ensure that all people in our society have the opportunity to fully participate in all aspects of Australian society and to recognise their potential.

This is one of the reasons why I am always very proud to attend citizenship ceremonies in my electorate. Both previously when I was a councillor on the Campbelltown Council and since I have been a federal member, I have attended as many of these citizenship ceremonies as possible because I am always very proud to see new citizens taking the oath of allegiance and pledging their loyalty to Australia and its people, whilst at the same time being able to have a right to their own cultural heritage and beliefs while respecting those of others. Multiculturalism is a very important aspect of Australian society and one that this government supports.

In December 1992, the federal government announced the opening of a new migrant resource centre, the Macarthur Migrant Resource Centre. This centre received $130,000 in 1993-94 and more than $200,000 in the 1994-95 budget. The Macarthur Migrant Resource Centre is located in the city of Campbelltown and also covers the Camden and Wollondilly local government areas. It services the federal electorates of both Macarthur and Werriwa. It also covers, amongst others, the two state electorates of Campbelltown and Camden. Both of the federal seats of Macarthur and Werriwa are currently held by the Labor Party. The state seat of Campbelltown is held by the Labor Party and the Liberal Party currently holds the marginal state seat of Camden.

Last week in the New South Wales parliament, the Minister for Multicultural and Ethnic Affairs, Mr Michael Photios, made a number of outrageous allegations in relation to the Macarthur Migrant Resource Centre. In response to a Dorothy Dix question from the state member for Camden, Dr Liz Kernohan, Mr Photios told the New South Wales parliament that the annual general meeting of the Migrant Resource Centre in Macarthur was the focus of a Labor inspired stacking exercise. He claimed that the Labor candidate for Camden, Mr Peter Primrose, and I conspired with a presumably large number of ALP members to try to overthrow the incumbent management committee.

He further alleged that I sought to postpone the AGM and that I had threatened to defund the organisation unless I got my way. He alleged that Mr Primrose's campaign director, Mr Wayne Warton, had `orchestrated the whole affair', walking members into the meeting and `running the whole show on his mobile phone'. Mr Photios alleged that most of these people were members of the Camden branch of the ALP.

As I told this House on Monday in my personal explanation, these allegations are totally untrue and without foundation. They should be treated with the utter contempt that they deserve. However, I will take the time to refute these allegations in some detail because Mr Photios and Dr Kernohan have chosen to raise these completely baseless allegations under parliamentary privilege. That means that those people accused have no opportunity for legal action against those who would defame them and, apart from me and the state member for Campbelltown, Mr Michael Knight, they do not have access to the forum of parliament to respond in their defence.

To start with, I was at the meeting because I was invited by the President of the Migrant Resource Centre, Sergeant Jeff Trichter, to be the keynote guest speaker, as I had been the previous year, in recognition of my long-term support for the organisation. In fact, Sergeant Trichter telephoned my office on three occasions to check that I would be attending. At the same time, he also invited Mr Primrose, who, as I said, is the state Labor candidate for Camden, and his wife Jan to attend. Both of these people have a record of advocacy and support for the non-English speaking community in the Macarthur area.

Sergeant Trichter had also invited Mr Knight to attend and act as returning officer, as Mr Knight told the New South Wales parliament in his personal explanation which followed the minister's attack last week. But it is here that the minister's allegations can be exposed for the fraud that they are. Firstly, I can hardly be accused of gatecrashing a meeting in which I was invited to be guest speaker.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I rise on a point of order.
—Here we go.

—Here we go, indeed. My point of order is under standing order 145 in relation to relevance. I appreciate that the appropriations are a very wide ranging debate, and I do not necessarily want to stop the member from discussing the Migrant Resource Centre which he is quite entitled to do. But I think he is going way beyond that and I ask you to bring the member back to matters that he was legitimately raising.

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Hon. J.D.M. Dobie)—Order! There is no point of order.

TALK.START.PARA: —Secondly, neither Mr Primrose nor his wife were able to attend the meeting because at the very time of the meeting Mr Primrose was performing the happy duties of best man at his brother's wedding in Camden. The minister also alleged that Councillor Paul Lynch of the Liverpool City Council—the ALP candidate for Liverpool—had attended the meeting. In fact, at the time of the meeting, Councillor Lynch was attending to his council responsibilities in another city. The minister is wrong again!

PARA.TAB: I have already dealt with the outrageous claim made by Minister Photios that I threatened to defund the MRC—to take away its federal funding—unless the meeting was deferred. This is a most serious allegation and, as I have said already, it is an outrageous and malicious lie. It is hard enough to get sufficient funding for community organisations. I certainly did not, and would never, threaten an organisation servicing my own electorate with losing its funding.

This is unlike the party that Mr Photios and Dr Kernohan represent—the Liberal Party—which has been responsible for the closure of many vital services throughout my electorate. These include the Camden offices of the Department of Community Services, Prospect Electricity and, most notoriously, the children's ward at Camden District Hospital—all of this in an area with the fastest growth rate and the youngest population in New South Wales.

The minister then claims that I demanded the deferral of this annual general meeting. In fact, the motion to defer the meeting was moved by the representative of the local St Vincent de Paul office and seconded by an employee of the Macarthur Disabled Persons Resource Centre. I might mention that neither of these two people are, or ever have been, members of the ALP.

This motion to defer the meeting had nothing to do with the question of who may or may not have won a particular ballot in the annual elections. It was moved on the basis of problems arising from the period prior to the conduct of the annual general meeting. The motion requested that the meeting be deferred to allow for mediation in order to resolve matters which were in dispute in relation to the conduct of the annual elections and, further, that the Australian Electoral Commission be asked to conduct the elections.

This motion was moved at the beginning of the meeting just as I was about to be asked to address the meeting as guest speaker. It was to my great concern and embarrassment that I then became aware that there was a serious dispute within the organisation over the conduct of the annual elections. I am now aware that this involves court challenges and several allegations of improprieties. Notwithstanding this, the move to place the matter in the hands of the Australian Electoral Commission was opposed by Sergeant Trichter and also by several other prominent members of the existing management committee.

It was at this stage that I took the opportunity to express my concern at what was occurring, and to suggest that perhaps the meeting should be deferred to enable the matters in dispute to be resolved by the appropriate authorities. I expressed concern at the possible damage to the organisation which could be caused by the escalation of the dispute, especially given reports of the closure of migrant resource centres in other states. This was a reflection of my genuine concern and could not possibly be construed either as a demand that the meeting be deferred or as a threat to defund the centre, as the minister has alleged.

As it turned out, Mr Knight, in his role as returning officer, found that he could not make a determination of the outcome of the deferral motion due to uncertainty over the membership credentials of some of the people in attendance. So, after a tense hour or two, the meeting was indeed deferred by agreement of all parties—and I emphasise `by agreement of all parties'.

I now turn to the minister's allegations that the meeting was stacked with Labor Party members to take over the centre. The minister claims that these people were from the Camden branch of the ALP. I myself am a member of the Camden branch of the ALP. As the federal member, you would expect that if there were members of my own party branch present I would recognise them. But, in fact, I can only recall seeing three members of the Camden branch in attendance at the meeting, including me—there were me and two others. As about 100 people attended on the day, I do not think that two could be considered as a stack of an organisation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not good enough.
—In fact, as the member for Petrie interjects, one would have thought that a community minded organisation such as the ALP would have done a lot better than getting two people there.

PARA.TAB: The minister went on to accuse Mr Warton of walking large numbers of people into the meeting and of orchestrating the alleged stack by using his mobile phone. I certainly did not see him walking anybody into the meeting, and he actually does not even own a mobile phone.

As I have already said, Mr Primrose and Mr Lynch, who were somehow supposed to be involved in this conspiracy with me, were not even at the meeting. The minister's whole story is nothing but a tissue of lies based on the fertile imaginations of those with a political motive to smear the Labor Party and some of its members.

I am very interested to know, though, what allegedly forged documents the minister has in his possession. As I have no knowledge at all of what he is talking about, I presume that this is in the same realm of fantasy as his other allegations. However, given that all of the documents relating to the annual general meeting had been held by Sergeant Trichter for some weeks prior to the AGM, it is difficult to know how anyone else had any opportunity at all to do anything with these alleged documents.

Mr Photios further alleges that this so-called Labor Party stack was aimed at the reinstatement of a former employee of the centre, Ms Mary Seaman. Ms Seaman has recently accepted an out of court settlement to a case of unfair dismissal in the New South Wales Industrial Commission. She was not present at the meeting, she is not a member of the MRC and she no longer lives in the area.

In making his untrue and inaccurate claims of a Labor Party takeover, Mr Photios quoted comments made by Mr Kevin Doyle, the treasurer and publicity officer of the MRC, which were published in the Macarthur Chronicle on 22 November. Mr Doyle claimed that members of the left wing of the Labor Party were trying to stack the MRC to take control of the management committee so that they could give themselves jobs. I have already dealt with these allegations in some detail. Mr Doyle's claims, like those of Mr Photios, are patently untrue and, given the nature of his claim, they could only have been politically motivated.

Mr Photios has clearly misled the New South Wales parliament and has recklessly abused parliamentary privilege. Mr Photios should apologise to all the people he has so flagrantly slandered, and he should also resign as a minister. If he does not resign, Premier John Fahey should have the guts to sack him. Mr Fahey said recently at his Liberal Party conference that some of his Liberal Party colleagues had not been up to scratch and he had had to show some of them the door. He should now show Mr Photios the door.

Since the annual general meeting of 12 November, I have been informed of some of the background to the real circumstances which exist at the Macarthur Migrant Resource Centre. As I said earlier, this dispute involves court proceedings and several allegations of impropriety. I understand many of these matters are now sub judice, so accordingly I am unable to detail them at this time. Rather than abuse parliamentary privilege, as Mr Photios has done, I will allow the appropriate authorities to deal with these matters which, I point out, have nothing whatsoever to do with the Labor Party.

It would appear, however, that these matters have had a shattering effect on the morale of workers at the Macarthur Migrant Resource Centre. What has happened is that the workers, many of whom are non-white, of non-English speaking background and female, feel intimidated by the actions of some members of the current all-white, English speaking, male dominated executive. It seems that the current executive has a very poor relationship with the staff and other committee members of the Migrant Resource Centre. I am told that the non-white, non-Anglo-Celtic people at the centre do not feel that they are accorded the same respect and status enjoyed by others.

Matters at the centre have apparently deteriorated to an extent where people who have come to Australia from violent and traumatic lands now feel the same sense of threat and trepidation from the very people who have been appointed as their advocates and protectors. But, for the reasons I have mentioned, I do not intend to detail the extremely serious complaints and allegations which have been made by these people. I understand that the proper authorities have been advised in full of these matters, and I have no doubt at all that they will be treated with the seriousness that is due.

TALK.START.PARA: —After the comments of the previous speaker, the honourable member for Macarthur (Mr Haviland), it is perhaps appropriate that we should deal with Appropriation Bill (No. 3), Appropriation Bill (No. 4) and Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill (No. 2), which are the subject of discussion before the House.

PARA.TAB: I suppose the comments of the honourable member did draw attention to some appropriations that are made from time to time by the Commonwealth to community organisations. In some instances, the standards of management of those organisations do not justify the Commonwealth resources that are provided to them. Without wanting to refer specifically to the organisation he mentioned, about which I have no personal knowledge, I can say that there are sadly many instances throughout the community where factional groups and arguments prevent organisations from carrying out the purpose for which they received the Commonwealth grant.

This raises a matter of concern about the way in which organisations in the community are sometimes used to promote government objectives and to spend taxpayers' money. We need always to be sure that those funds are spent wisely and well. I have seen in my own electorate and in other places examples where feuding and disagreement have made it very difficult for the intended objectives of the organisation to be achieved.

I want to refer to some of the matters dealt with in these appropriation bills. I refer initially to the appropriation provided in these bills for the Australia Remembers commemoration next year. I would like to commend the government on the initiatives it is taking to help make next year's 50th anniversary of the end of World War II a significant event in Australian history. World War II did contribute much to the richness of Australia's history. It taught us a lot about the horrors of war, but it also demonstrated to the world much of the heroic nature of the Australian serviceman and our capacity as a nation to contribute to important international causes.

Australia Remembers is a very important occasion for Australians and deserves appropriate recognition. Our objective over the year should be to acknowledge the great privilege that we as Australians have to live in peace and to recognise the contribution of Australian service men and women who died during the war and in subsequent years. We should also thank those remaining service personnel for their efforts. We also need to acknowledge the role played by those other Australians who kept the country operating during the war years.

It is particularly appropriate that days such as VE day and VP day be recognised in this country because of the role played by Australians in those significant events and the contribution those events made to securing a generation of peace for Australians and guaranteeing that our continent would be spared the ravages of war.

I would also like to commend the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Sciacca) on the even-handed way in which he is approaching these celebrations. Unlike so many events organised by the Labor government in the past, which have tended to develop a political focus, it seems the minister has endeavoured to evenly spread around Australia the resources that are being provided so that every electorate can enjoy and participate in Australia Remembers commemorations. In my own electorate, we are doing quite a lot of work towards organising activities. We are looking forward to our share of the funds.

The minister has indicated that approximately $20,000 will be available to each federal electorate to assist with Australia Remembers commemorations. The $20,000 on a per electorate basis in some sense sounds fair, although it does tend to concentrate the amount of money available in the capital cities where there are a lot of federal electorates and where there will therefore be very large budgets to spend on appropriate commemorations. I have to spread that $20,000 amongst 50 separate towns in my electorate. It is obviously not going to go all the way around. I would very much like to see larger allocations being given to rural, regional and provincial areas. I have probably 20 different RSL branches within my electorate, so sadly the $20,000 will not go around. Nonetheless, we put together a selection committee that will allocate funds to ensure that some of the Australia Remembers celebrations can occur in each and every community within the electorate.

I would also like to encourage the government to be generous in making Defence Force personnel available to assist in the Australia Remembers commemoration. I know that comes from a different budget from that of the Minister for Veterans' Affairs. Sadly, the defence budget has been depleted so much over recent years that there is a limited capacity to do what I think should be done in 1995 to help commemorate Australia Remembers. Many organisations would like to have defence personnel present to help add prestige and a military dimension to their proposed celebrations. In Kingaroy, which is in my electorate, there is a proposal to have an air pageant to commemorate VE day and to particularly mark the role played by Kingaroy in air force training and the activities of the air force during World War II. They have asked to have some air force presence, including the Roulettes, to help make that a very important celebration.

I hope the defence department will be able to make some air force personnel available to add to that day's celebrations which will recognise the role that Kingaroy played in training so many air force pilots, including some very significant names in Australian history. I hope they will be able to be present on that day to add to the commemoration.

In addition, I refer to the announcement that medals are to be available to some people who served in ancillary services, such as the Women's Land Army. Some of those medals will be available for presentation during 1995. It would be good to have a military parade to recognise those people who will be honoured and who will finally have their service during and around World War II and in subsequent conflicts recognised through the presentation of a medal.

If we are going to have parades to adequately recognise those people, it will require some Defence Force commitment. I hope the government will take that on board and make people available wherever possible to assist in making those commemorations as significant as possible.

While handing out bouquets to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, I have to draw his attention to a matter which pleased me much less. The government recently announced new initiatives to assist Vietnam veterans in Australia. I was very disturbed to learn from counsellors who participated in the Vietnam veterans country outreach program that the government is about to axe the program. This seems to be an extraordinary action on the part of the government on the eve of the Australia Remembers commemoration in light of the commitments made by the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, I am sure in all sincerity, to do more to assist Vietnam veterans. It seems the government has decided to axe this counselling service.

There are seven counsellors in my electorate who are employed for 32 hours per month to assist Vietnam veterans with their various needs. That is not an enormous commitment from the government, but it seems that the government wants this service to become voluntary. This is a very stressful occupation. It is stressful not only for the counsellors themselves, some of whom are from families of Vietnam veterans, but also for the immediate families of the counsellors because the veterans call in at all hours and the counsellors are called out at all hours. It places a burden on their families.

For the minister to expect these counsellors to perform this service for nothing is clearly unreasonable. Most of the counsellors who are currently involved in the program have indicated to me that they are not prepared to do that work without some kind of financial assistance. Apparently, all the minister is prepared to offer them is a bit of mileage and some reimbursement for their outgoing telephone calls. The government wants these counsellors to perform this highly skilled and very stressful task without any reimbursement. Frankly, that is unreasonable. I call on the Minister for Veterans' Affairs to reconsider his attitude to this matter and continue the funding for the Vietnam veterans country outreach program.

My final point in the area of veterans affairs relates to the Australia Remembers commemoration. There has been a lot of pressure within my electorate—and I am sure in other places as well—for a public holiday to commemorate VP Day. That is a day of great significance for Australia. It was a day of great celebration 50 years ago; it was a public holiday 50 years ago. It would certainly add greatly to the public's acknowledgment of that day if there were a holiday for VP Day again in 1995.

I know that employers and businesses are reluctant to have more holidays. We certainly have plenty of them in this country, and more than most. Why not in this very special year transfer, say, the Labour Day holiday—a holiday which is celebrated on various days around Australia—to VP Day to mark a very significant event? If the labour movement is reluctant to give away its holiday for one year, perhaps the Queen's Birthday holiday could for one year be on this day to recognise this important event. If that day is not suitable, there are many show days or pupil free days in schools that could surely be transferred to VP Day to help local communities better celebrate this important event.

I know that choosing holidays is a matter for state governments. I think the Minister for Veterans' Affairs could exercise some influence with his state colleagues, and with local government since they are also capable of recommending holidays, particularly for show days. Surely for one year we could use one of the existing holidays to help guarantee that VP Day is properly remembered.

Whilst dealing with defence matters, I note also that, despite the fact that we have a hard pressed defence budget and a white paper currently before the parliament which slashes defence expenditure to the lowest level since World War II, the Department of Defence is still going to have to find around $10 million to redecorate the Prime Minister's jet. It seems an extraordinary priority, when we cannot find money to adequately staff the defence battalions and we cannot find money for new equipment, that $10 million is going to have to be found to upgrade the Prime Minister's 707 jet because, apparently, it does not meet his imperial standards.

As a result of these modifications, it will be more difficult to use that 707 jet in its primary defence role—namely, transporting troops in times of conflict. It will be difficult to modify the jet for that purpose. Apparently, there is $8 million in these appropriations to redecorate the Prime Minister's jet. In these tough economic times, one wonders about that priority.

We are being told by the government at the present time that the recession is over, good times have come and we now need to take measures to help dampen the enthusiasm in the economy. Once again, Labor's response to the improved economy is to suggest that we need to dampen it down with more taxes. I find it remarkable that in times of improved economic activity Labor chooses to adopt a more tax solution.

When we were in the recession the government's solution was also more taxes. In that case it wanted more taxes so it could stimulate the economy. Now it wants more taxes so that it can suppress the economy. It does not matter what the problem is, Labor's solution is always higher taxes. The government totally lacks imagination in dealing with the economy because the only solution it can ever find is higher taxes.

The government needs to remember that there is already a stack of higher taxes that will be inflicted upon Australians next year as a result of last year's budget, including higher sales taxes, higher petrol taxes and higher tobacco taxes. All of these taxes hurt middle and ordinary Australians more than they hurt those on higher incomes. These taxes will be inflicted on Australians.

To hear the government now talk about a raft of new taxes is a totally inappropriate response to the current economic improvement. Indeed, higher fuel taxes, higher indirect taxes, will hurt the people who are not benefiting from any kind of improvement in the economy. People in rural and regional parts of Australia know nothing about any kind of improved economy. They are still suffering from drought and recession.

To increase fuel taxes would hurt the very people who are still in the depths of recession. It is deplorable that any member opposite would be advocating higher fuel taxes in these circumstances. Australia taxes fuel more inappropriately than any country in the world. If there is any country that ought not tax fuel, it is Australia, which is so vast and spread over an enormous continent. By taxing fuel we penalise our productive industries. They are the ones that need fuel to transport their produce to port. They are the ones who need to locate their business and their activity away from the capital cities. They are the ones who bear the disproportionate share of the fuel tax burden.

In this country we already impose more than $10 billion worth of taxation as a result of distance. Distance should never be taxed. We should be encouraging people to live, locate and do business away from the capital cities. The only way that can be done is to reduce fuel taxes rather than impose higher taxes.

I call on the government to immediately rule out the possibility of higher fuel taxes. In fact, it should rule out the possibility of any new taxes in this situation. The government will reap an automatic windfall in tax revenue because the economy is picking up. It does not need higher levels of taxes.

Let us look at the last federal budget, which the Treasurer (Mr Willlis) proudly announced as a no new taxes budget. Of course, that was not true; there were some new taxes in the budget. But even without increasing existing taxes specifically, the government still budgeted on an income tax increase of 8.4 per cent; 5.7 per cent more from the Medicare levy; seven per cent increase in company tax; 27 per cent increase in super funds taxes; and a fringe benefits tax increase of an incredible 131 per cent—all of that without any increases in tax. Sales taxes went up by 7.7 per cent, fuel excise went up by 12.6 per cent and there was a 6.3 per cent increase in other excises. The government reaped that tax windfall without increasing taxes. Frankly, all of those figures will be understated. Because of the improvement in the economy, the government's haul from taxes will be even greater.

There is no excuse whatsoever for higher taxes. There are plenty of excuses for the government to cut its own expenditure and to cut its own waste. Sadly, in this appropriation bill we are allocating more money for more government waste. There are so many examples of where the government has failed to cut its own budget and where it has failed to draw in its own expenditure. It prefers instead to raise levels of taxes to penalise ordinary Australians, the people who are trying to get their businesses up and running again. Not only do they slave and struggle under increasing government regulation and higher charges and taxes, but they are also never rewarded for their effort. Their reward for higher profitability, for putting in those extra hours, is more taxes.

As our economy improves, the government should recognise that that improvement is directly the result of the individual efforts of Australian small business and industry. It has nothing to do with any brainstorm on behalf of the Prime Minister or any intervention on the government's part. It is entirely due to the efforts of individual Australians. Those efforts should be rewarded, encouraged and acknowledged—not penalised through higher taxes. The government needs to take that into account in proposing its mini-budget early next year and in its future budgetary planning. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Mr H.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —As we go through the decade of the 1990s and approach the centenary of Federation, it is appropriate to reflect upon the events of 100 years ago and on how it was that we came to have our constitution, which remains relatively unchanged—very similar to the original document. We should remember that the Australian constitution had its legal entity created with the enactment of the Commonwealth of Australia Constitution Act 1900, enacted by the British parliament. The simple fact is that the act had nine clauses with the ninth clause commencing by saying:

PARA.TAB: 9. The Constitution of the Commonwealth shall be as follows:-

SPEECH.PARA: Our constitution was created as a clause of an act of the British parliament. It is very difficult to imagine in the 1990s how we would go about putting in place a constitution to create the federation of Australia. It is a bit hard to imagine being in the situation of the British parliament, being required to achieve the outcome. That is not to say that we do not need to look at contemporary Australia and to think about those things that are made more difficult because of the constitution being created in the 1890s.

PARA.TAB: One of the increasing frustrations that I have as a member of the Australian parliament is that often the things we would like to achieve are frustrated, or made more complicated, because of the need to wend our way through the sensitivities of Commonwealth-state relations. I see the Minister for Consumer Affairs (Ms McHugh) at the table. We have a debate at the moment about national competition policy. It is a quite complex and complicated policy on its own without having the difficulties of looking at it in the context of agreements between the Commonwealth and the states. I raise that as one example because I believe there has not been sufficient debate about competition policy arising out of the Hilmer report and that there is perhaps a lack of understanding of its ramifications. When people investigate those ramifications, it becomes even more difficult because it is hard to identify what means will be used to achieve outcomes.

It will be of interest to you, Mr Deputy Speaker, and the minister at the table to know that last week the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Environment, Recreation and the Arts revisited Lake Mungo, one of the first four areas placed on the World Heritage List. I do not know whether both of you were on the previous visit. I was not a member of the committee at the time but have often heard about the very interesting meeting that you had with the leaseholders. Unfortunately I have to report that, nearly 10 years down the track, not much has changed.

It is a classic example of the Australian parliament and the Australian government having the responsibility under their treaty obligations of ensuring that those places under World Heritage listing are properly managed while the day-to-day management of those places resides in the hands of a state government. After a decade, we really have not put in place a management regime shared between the Commonwealth and, in this instance, the New South Wales government which would achieve clear outcomes—which would protect those values that have caused that area to be placed on the register and, at the same time, give a degree of direction and certainty to those people who live in the area and who try to make an economic existence out of their stewardship of that land.

I am sure that we could all come up with examples which show the difficulties Australia has in the 1990s in a whole raft of areas of public administration because of the nature of our federation. The debate really is and should be, as we run into the centenary of Federation: what does the Australian community expect of the Commonwealth government and what is the type of Australia we really would like to see?

We reflect upon the creation of the federation and there is from time to time, quite rightly, some very harsh criticism of the way in which the constitution was put in place. Arising from some comments of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) in June of this year, there appeared an article in the Telegraph Mirror under the heading `Constitution a grubby compromise'. The author of the article was Richard White, a historian at the Sydney University. The first part of the article was critical of the Prime Minister for the way in which he has assessed what happened in that important time in our history. I believe that was a little unfair. I will go to the latter parts of his article where he says:
The Constitution that was produced was a compromise, in many parts a rather grubby compromise or a wilfully vague one.

SPEECH.PARA: It is a bit harsh, 100 years on, to be critical of the way in which the constitution was put together. Richard White further states:

PARA.TAB: They comprised "founding fathers" if you like but were, more accurately, a group of middle class politicians, mostly lawyers, Alexander Downer's grandfather among them.

SPEECH.PARA: For the purposes of this debate, I do not want to belabour that point. Certainly, in the way in which the community was debating federation at the time, for various reasons, there were people who were concerned. At the time of Federation, the labour movement was divided about the question and was very cautious.

PARA.TAB: The newspaper the Worker expressed some concerns about the young federation becoming a plutocracy under the influence of `bribed leaders and corrupt statesmen'. The Melbourne based Tocsin was similarly bitterly opposed to the powers given to the Governor-General and felt that Australian liberty had been imperilled by federation. Some in the labour movement would say that was very prescient of what occurred during the 1970s. The Worker concluded:

SPEECH.PARA: Essentially the spirit of a federal movement was democratic and the nation . . . must if it is true to itself . . . even become more democratic.
The Tocsin finally accepted the Commonwealth Act, stating:
. . . for better or worse. We shall try to find in it secret charms for bettering the condition of Victoria and Australia. We shall strive to make of it a charter of liberty for the distant future.
Despite those reservations, from the outset it has been the labour movement that has seen the need for constitutional change to reflect the changing needs of the nation.

PARA.TAB: In this context, I should also raise a statement by the founder of the Liberal Party, who recognised that a constitution needs to grow and adapt to change. In 1967, Robert Gordon Menzies suggested:

SPEECH.PARA: A written constitution is an express scheme of government designed to give a basic structure in a changing world, not designed to inhibit growth in a growing world, nor to make the contemporary world subject to the political, social or economic ideas of a bygone age.
The Australian constitution has not changed very much. It is still a document suited to the social and economic conditions of the 1890s, when it was conceived.

PARA.TAB: If we look at some of the pamphlets circulated during the run-up to federation, we see one that compared the proposed constitution with the then fledgling Swiss and American constitutions. This pamphlet made the bold claim that it would be easier, under the proposed Australian constitution, to achieve constitutional change than it would be under the American constitution. I think the history of the past century—in the case of the American constitution, a greatly longer period—proves that the American constitution has proved in its ability to be amended a much more pliable document that can be changed to represent contemporary ideas and views.

The problems that have been created by this inflexibility and lack of change within the Australian constitution are well known. Earlier I gave some examples, but perhaps the situation was best summarised by a graphic illustration given by then Prime Minister Bob Hawke in 1990. Mr Hawke gave the example of a cargo container being sent by rail between Sydney and Perth that may have been subject to three non-integrated railway systems, four changes in locomotives, five different safe working systems, six different sizes of loading gauge, 10 different engineering standards of basic standard gauge rail track and 12 or more hours at sidings or junctions for crew changes.

Some of those problems catalogued in that example are slowly but surely being addressed. We are looking at the national rail grid. Some of the things that Mr Hawke talks about which concern different standards of safety and associated issues are laboriously being addressed. Arising out of an Industry Commission report on accident compensation, at the level of COAG we will look at those issues, at our separate jurisdictions, because those matters reside within the powers that were reserved by the colonies back in the 1990s, and at the way in which we can put in place a national policy.

As Richard White said, the founding fathers, whom I quoted earlier, were often regarded with undue reverence. Back in the 1970s, Don Dunstan pointed out that they were really little more than state politicians protecting vested interests. What we need to do is to ask how, in the 1990s, we can wind back the clock and how we can wind back those attitudes that were motivated by these vested interests so that we can achieve change that focuses on looking at Australia as one nation, rather than looking at Australia as a continuing collection of the six colonies.

We should realise that the founding fathers knew well that they were condemning future generations. Manning Clark pointed out in his history of Australia that as early as the late 1840s the Whig Earl Grey warned the colonists about the dangers of separate parliaments `legislating on such subjects of common interest as railway gauges'. Clark continues:

SPEECH.PARA: The price for colonial folly was that New South Wales adopted the standard railway gauge, Victoria five feet three inches, and Queensland, South Australia and Western Australia three feet six inches.

At the time of Federation, those issues were not immediately or magically addressed because of the creation of the federation or the way the constitution was framed. It has taken us progressively over the last century to be able to address the problems that the earlier colonial decisions created. I think it is worth repeating a quote of Don Dunstan: We are now left with results of their work—
that is, the state politicians—

a system of sovereign governments whose boundaries bear no relation to physical, social or economic geography, and which are limited in their attempts to legislate efficiently in such important areas as trade practices or national transport because the framers of the Constitution on the one hand did not believe that governments should be concerned with the economy or business practices, and on the other they foresaw no problems emerging.
Mr Dunstan also said:

The system as a whole is inefficient and debilitating. And as the years pass the writing of the Constitution becomes enveloped in the mists of time, that well known contagion of Federated States can be seen developing high-minded reverence for the Founding Fathers. Any criticism of their document becomes a kind of political blasphemy. They are even now being seen as far-sighted, despite the fact that when they drew the document up about the only matters they considered crucial to national Government were defence, an end to custom barriers and an efficient post office . . .

One of the driving forces that moved politicians in the six colonies to agitate for federation was the influence of the French and the Germans in their efforts to colonise our region. For others, it was the concern that they had of either Asian invasion or Asian takeover through migration. In the 1990s we are having debates about free trade throughout the world and, in particular, yesterday's debate arising from the APEC meeting in Bogor about free trade in our region. In that context it is interesting that one of the driving forces for the colonies in getting together to create the Federation was free trade between the colonies.

PARA.TAB: So where does that leave us at the moment? It leaves us in a situation whereby, through COAG as a meeting of heads of governments, we are trying to achieve a cooperative approach to the way in which we can tackle the problems that confront Australia. Because of what is sometimes termed `the new federalism', whereby we have to achieve national policies through the agreement of both the national and state governments and national and state legislatures, a great degree of compromise is needed to achieve outcomes. Without suggesting that consultation in any form is a bad thing, to achieve this cooperation—to do it right—requires lengthy consultation, which delays our ability to put in place change and delays our ability to address problems at a national level.

We have slowly come to grips with the fact that, in economic policy terms, only the national government can give the direction. There are still tensions in place, because of the 1942 court decision that gave income tax raising powers to the Commonwealth, about the sharing of resources. There is continuing concern where people are conjuring up this concept of states rights without thinking that we should be talking about people's individual rights and the need for a national direction in those areas of policy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Abbott Mr A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I had not intended to speak about the constitution but, given that the member for Scullin (Mr Jenkins) has raised this subject and done so in an interesting but, I would argue, wrong way, I will address a few of his points. The constitution is a document that was designed in the 1890s but, as Sir Isaac Isaacs said, it was designed to be the birth certificate of a nation. As our nation has changed, so our constitution has changed. Our constitution is not perfect, but there is nothing wrong with it that becoming a republic is going to fix.

PARA.TAB: The member for Scullin raised various issues of overlap, duplication, waste and so on which he believes stem from the existence of the states. The problem with his line of argument is that it does not actually help the agenda of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) for constitutional reform unless the Prime Minister is prepared to accept that becoming a republic should also include abolishing the states. I would think that that is in fact part of the Prime Minister's long-term agenda, but it is certainly not something that he is prepared to admit at the moment. In fact, at the moment the Prime Minister is saying that if the states did not exist it would be necessary to invent them.

The member for Scullin has fallen into the trap which so many members opposite fall into—namely, in their desire to bring about certain changes to our constitution, they are rubbishing the entire document. The member for Scullin read articles from some academic who was talking of our constitution as `a grubby compromise'. I would have thought that compromise was part of life. Effective life in civil society means knowing when to compromise, because compromise of some sort is simply inevitable. Putting a pejorative adjective in front of the word `compromise' does not change that fact. He may as well have spoken about `grubby cooperation', but of course he would not talk that way because we all know that cooperation is part of life and it is essential if we are going to have the kind of society that people are happy to live in.

Of course, the constitution was originally an act of the British parliament, but that was the icing on the cake. The essence of our constitution was decided by the Australian people in Australia for Australians by a series of constitutional conventions. For the member for Scullin or anyone else to say that it was rammed down our throat by Queen Victoria in the British parliament is simply a slander on Australia's history.

Yes, documents—even documents like the constitution—do need to be changed from time to time. But the changes must address the real needs of the people and not the imaginary needs and the cheap political interests of certain political sections and ideologies in society. The fact is that, if you look at the constitutions which were changed most often in the modern world, you get constitutions like that of the former Soviet Union. That constitution went through five or six incarnations in 70 years. On paper, the constitution of the Soviet Union was the most relevant and up-to-date constitution in the world, but it did not matter at all as far as protecting rights in the Soviet Union was concerned, because there was no cohesive culture—political culture, culture of human rights—behind it. The fact is that, if our constitution needs to change to serve the needs of the Australian people, it must change. But it must not change simply to serve the needs of the Prime Minister.

The appropriation bills that are before the House at the moment indicate the sorry reality of Australia's economic condition. By contrast, the Prime Minister's self-adulation, expressed in his statement about the APEC meeting at Bogor, demonstrates the fantasy land that this government is living in. The Prime Minister said that the APEC agreement permanently changed our region and the world. He put the APEC agreement up there on the same pedestal as the Bretton Woods agreement, which laid the foundations for the international economic conditions of the postwar world.

It is interesting that the Prime Minister's great political hero is none other than Jack Lang. Jack Lang supporters used to run around Sydney back in the 1930s saying that Lang was greater than Lenin. At least Jack Lang had the decency to let his supporters say that he was greater than Lenin. The Prime Minister lacks that decency. In standing up here and boasting about APEC and Bogor, what he was really saying was: `Paul Keating is greater than Roosevelt; Paul Keating is greater than Churchill; Paul Keating is greater than John Maynard Keynes. I am greater than these architects of the post world war economic world.'

Is it any wonder that well-known and able journalistic commentator, Mr Greg Sheridan, was forced to say in his recent column that the Prime Minister was suffering from Bogor fever? The Prime Minister has caught Bogor fever and is deep in the throws of that dreadful disease. The Prime Minister said that APEC was our chance to sit at a big table. The PM is obsessed with big tables, as long as they come from Thailand and as long as they are made of teak. I suppose he wants his Thai teak table to go with his Thai knighthood: a Knight Grand Cordon of the Most Exalted Order of the White Elephant.

The Prime Minister's statement on APEC shows serious historical amnesia in that he has totally forgotten one of the fundamental planks of the last election campaign. The Prime Minister went round this country saying to the workers of the textile industry, the motor industry and the footwear industry, `Vote Labor, because Labor will protect your tariffs.' Now he is saying that within a few short years tariffs will be abolished, not because we in Australia want them to be abolished but because APEC, apparently, is telling us that they should be abolished. The Prime Minister has forgotten in just a short space of time the fundamental plank on which he fought the last election. He has exposed himself as the real Captain Zero of Australian politics, the real deceiver of our political system.

The second case of historical amnesia is that the Prime Minister has said that he produced APEC. If any Australian politician is to claim credit for APEC, it should be the former Prime Minister Bob Hawke. Bob Hawke is the real ghost at the Prime Minister's APEC banquet. Hawke has been removed by the current Prime Minister from the APEC picture in much the same way that Stalin had Trotsky removed from the photographs of the old Bolsheviks.

The third and most serious case of historical amnesia is that the Prime Minister does not know or understand the history of this country. I refer to a government report which commended a certain course of action because that course of action would provide `facilities for carrying on trade with India and the Malay Peninsula as well as with China'. That report was not written for Paul Keating last year. It was not written for Bob Hawke five years ago. It was not written for Bob Menzies a generation ago. It was written for Governor Stirling of Western Australia back in 1828. The point I am making is that Australia has been interested in Asia, vitally concerned with Asia and deeply involved with Asia for as long as this country has existed.

It is important to remember who has and who has not got the right stuff on Asia. It was Bob Menzies and not Paul Keating who first talked about Asia as our `near north'. It was Percy Spender and not the current Prime Minister who implemented the Colombo Plan, which brought tens of thousands of Asia's future leaders to our shores. It was Bob Menzies and Black Jack McEwen and not the current Prime Minister who established the trade treaty with Japan which resulted in the total reorientation of our trade in just a few short years.

It was Harold Holt and not the current Prime Minister who declared, back in 1966, that the next century would be `a century of Asia'. It was Harold Holt and not the current Prime Minister who ended the White Australia policy. At the very time he did so Labor was being led by a man who notoriously said, `Two wongs don't make a white'. That was the attitude of the Labor Party then. It was Malcolm Fraser and not the current Prime Minister who first began large scale Asian immigration to this country. Labor at that time was being led by a man who wanted to keep the boat people out because they were, he said, `f . . . ing yellow balts'. That is the record of the Labor Party as opposed to the record of the coalition on this subject.

Let me also point out on this subject of relations with Asia that the first member of this parliament of Asian extraction was Senator Thomas Backhap, back in the early years of this century, who represented one of the forebears of the Liberal Party, the Nationalist Party. But to go into more detail as to which party is the party of Asia in this country, just how long Australians have been talking about the need to integrate with Asia and just what a Johnny-come-lately to this crusade the Prime Minister is, Sir John Latham said in 1934:

SPEECH.PARA: It is inevitable that the relations between Australia and Asia . . . will become closer and more intimate as the years pass. Therefore, it is important that we should endeavour to develop and improve our relations with our near neighbours.
In 1939 Menzies said:
I believe that the Pacific is of all zones in the world, the zone in which our risks are primary risks and our responsibilities are primary responsibilities.
He went on to say that the government should:
. . . do everything that it can to increase our cultural relationship, our personal contact with them—
that is to say with Asians—
and to improve all of those things which go to make a real and personal understanding.
In the 1950s Dick Casey said:

Our geographical situation is such that we must inevitably be brought into close touch with the peoples of Asia. If we make no effort to understand their problems, we can scarcely expect them to make an effort to understand ours. Differences of race, religion, language and culture could easily lead to regrettable misunderstandings which might adversely affect our relations with them.

It is a pity that the Prime Minister did not heed Dick Casey's advice. If he really understood Asian culture he would not have made his regrettable comments about the Prime Minister of Malaysia Dr Mahathir which led to months of trade tensions between Australia and one of our important trading partners. In the 1950s the Prime Minister of India Mr Nehru welcomed Australia's coming closer to Asia. So this idea that Asia was only discovered in December 1991, when the current Prime Minister assumed office, is a myth. The Prime Minister only discovered Asia then because until that point Asia had been something that you flew over on the way to the antique fairs of London and Paris.

PARA.TAB: I will conclude this part of my comments with another well-known Australian politician, this time speaking in the 1960s. He said that our destiny lay with Asia:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . we must fulfil it spiritually, unselfishly, with shining enlightenment . . . (This) will stand as the most glorious achievement, so far, in our history.
That politician was not the current Prime Minister; it was Sir Alexander Downer, the father of the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Downer).

PARA.TAB: Let us examine the reality of our current relationship with Asia. In 1968, 65 per cent of our total exports were already going to the Asia-Pacific region. In 1968 we already had nearly seven-tenths of our economic relationship with the Asia-Pacific region. That was 25 years ago. It has nothing to do with the current Prime Minister and everything to do with the good work of the Menzies government.

Our share of East Asian markets over the last few years has declined. Our exports to East Asia have been increasing as a percentage of our GDP but falling as a percentage of East Asia's GDP because its growth rates are higher than ours. Our penetration of East Asian markets has fallen since the early 1980s from four per cent of East Asian GDP to about 3 1/2 per cent.

Investment from Asia in this country has also fallen over the last few years. Australian investment in countries such as Britain and America has skyrocketed but our investment in Asia has stagnated. Our investment in Britain today is six times our total investment in ASEAN. I am not saying this to approve; I am saying it to indicate the reality of our economic position, which is that our relationship with Asia has gone backwards in the last few years, notwithstanding all the hyperbole of the Prime Minister.

APEC is certainly an important step in the right direction. One of the reasons why it is an important step in the right direction is that it is a small step in the improvement of our domestic economic position, which has been damaged by this government. This government has practised hairshirt economics. When times were good back in the 1980s, it put interest rates up to 17 per cent. When times were bad in the early 1990s, it put unemployment up to one million people. Now that times are allegedly good again, interest rates are going up again. In other words, before the economic recovery has crawled off the front pages of the Financial Review—it has not even got into people's pockets yet—interest rates are already going up. The last round of interest rate rises, let alone the next round, will amount to a tax of $100 a month on ordinary home buyers in this country.

In the 1980s we had interest rate rises we `had to have', in 1990 we had the recession we `had to have', now we are having more interest rate rises that we `had to have' and soon we will have another recession that we `had to have'. The Prime Minister has done it before and he will do it again. The tragedy of what this Prime Minister is doing to this country is that it amounts to a complete betrayal of the people that he and the Labor Party are supposed to represent.

One of the great ironies of the current situation is that Labor members opposite are only too happy to turn to traditional working class areas when they are looking for a safe seat, but they rush off to the rich parts of town when they are looking for a house. The Leader of the House (Mr Beazley) is rushing off to a safer seat as fast as he can, given his vast bulk. At the same time we have the Prime Minister, who has a perfectly safe seat, rushing off to buy a $2.2 million mansion in Woollahra. The motto of this government is, if I might take the biblical lamentation: `To those who have, more shall be given. To those who have not, even what little they have shall be taken away.' It is a terrible indictment of a Labor government that that should be the case.

This government needs to stop fantasising about overseas countries coming to save us from our domestic predicament. Its leader needs to stop his fantasies about strolling around in his batik shirt with President Clinton. The government needs to get on with the real job of economic management. It needs to tackle the rorts, the rackets and the rip-offs which still exist in our economy. It needs to tackle the union rules, which means that the pit pony cannot be removed from a colliery because it is a member of a union and that means that Australian 767s have to have differently designed cockpits to accommodate extra union members.

The Prime Minister needs to stop his Napoleonic fantasies and get on with the job of running this country. He needs to come back home where the problems are and forget about overseas problems that he cannot do anything to fix.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crosio The Hon J.A.

TALKER.NAME: Mrs CROSIO
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Social Security)

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak today on the government's appropriation bills. I will take this opportunity to reflect on some of the federal Labor government's achievements and our Liberal coalition's shortcomings. During my speech, I would like to compare the positive actions of our government with the Clayton's policies and retrograde activities of the coalition. It is becoming an illuminating experience.

PARA.TAB: Before I go on to the points I would like to raise in the debate today, I will take the honourable member for Warringah (Mr Abbott) to task on his memory lane trips in this place. He talked about how things were established down memory lane, which is recorded in history, of what one particular person was supposed to have said, whether it was in 1939, 1964 or whenever. I say to him as he is leaving the House now that he should hang his head in shame—history records words, but history does not record action.

It took the Prime Minister and the Labor government to bring action to reality, to bring those words to fruition, to make sure that APEC came to fruition. When something like that happens, the opposition resorts to personal, vindictive attacks time and again. Those opposite do not like the achievements that have taken place under the leadership of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating). They do not like the fact that somebody of his renown can bring many countries of the world to agreement. They do not want to see that. They do not want to stand up and be counted and be part of a country which is proud of those achievements. They want to stand up here and put on a scene.

If Actors Equity were here grading the member for Warringah, he would probably get about two out of 10. I would not give him much more, because he has referred to what has happened in the past. He should bring himself back to the present and start looking to the future. You would swear to God, from some of the remarks made by the member for Warringah, that you had to be swab tested before you moved out of your electorate and bought property in some other electorate. I found him absolutely obscene.

The debate before the House today will give me an opportunity to bring some of our achievements to the notice of the House. Since 1983 we have been driven by a need to look at where we are going throughout Australia. When our government took office it found that many areas of responsibility had been left to it by the Liberal government. I am pleased that our government has been able to formulate policy on a scale that has assisted everyday Australians.

We are coming to the end of 1994. As our Labor government forges ahead, nothing has really changed for the Liberals. They have certainly become a lot more sluggish and, if one can take notice of what has been happening in the papers recently with the leadership debate, much more chaotic. Our Liberal state of disarray has certainly been summed up well by Glen Milne in the Australian on 28 November:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . former NSW Liberal Premier, Nick Greiner stands as testimony to the capacity of the Liberal Party for self-delusion.
That some sections of the Liberal Party are mooting the idea of bringing Mr Greiner to this House is absurd, given his track record, which, incidentally, Mr Milne outlines so well. He states:
In 1991, Greiner went to an election a year early, for no apparent reason, and saw the Liberals' comfortable majority squandered and control of the Parliament ceded to the Independents . . .

Mr Greiner's involvement and ineptitude in the ICAC debacle resulting from offering that Liberal defector Terry Metherell a highly paid Public Service job are certainly etched in the minds of the voters of New South Wales and, I dare say, Australia. That lapse of political judgment saw Mr Greiner forced from the premiership.

PARA.TAB: More recently in the Australian Capital Territory, we should consider the Liberal opposition's actions in the Legislative Assembly where the leader, Kate Carnell, has just completed a backflip on the cannabis laws. Acknowledging that the Liberal Party has handled the issues badly, that assembly has had to amend the legislation which her party virtually helped pass. This backdown comes after strong pressure from various quarters, including the police and the Australian Medical Association, who all agree that the whole issue has not been thought through.

The list of the federal government's positive moves is very impressive. Whether it be in our western suburbs of Sydney, where I proudly represent the electorate of Prospect, in the country areas of New South Wales, in the state of Victoria or on the Gold Coast, our government has been actively pursuing very progressive programs. As part of our government's commitment in Working Nation, the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Crean) and his very effective team have been making significant inroads into unemployment and are creating job opportunities. Hardly surprisingly, in discussing Working Nation's objectives and listening to others' views across Australia, the government's ideas have been met with enthusiasm and certainly with confidence.

The federal government is now working with many of our large companies to get people talking, to get them thinking and, most importantly, to get them actively working together to alleviate unemployment. The government is creating strong links with industry, the unions and the community at large. Results have been very reassuring. Recent DEET figures show that the number of skilled vacancies in major metropolitan newspapers has risen. This result sees increases in 12 out of the 16 major occupational groups, which means that the level of skilled vacancies has risen by more than 56 per cent over the past year. There is also good news about decreases in Australia's foreign debt. The latest figures show that net foreign debt fell for the fourth quarter in a row. Commentators have welcomed this result.

By contrast, but perhaps not surprisingly, the shadow Treasurer, the honourable member for Higgins (Mr Costello), has attributed the improvements to state governments and to the private sector. I personally believe that his refusal to give due credit to the federal government illustrates how petty he and his coalition partners are about the issue. He either clearly lacks understanding and knowledge or just refuses to understand what it is we are about.

The list of worthwhile government initiatives is a very long and proud one. Through DEET's NETTFORCE projects, for instance, the federal government is campaigning to generate 17,000 new jobs in the Gold Coast region over the next six months. In central western New South Wales, by actively encouraging employers to take on additional employees, particularly the long-term unemployed, our government's endeavours should lead to an extra 5,500 new jobs in that area. Overall, since the launch of Working Nation in May of this year, there has been a substantial impact on long-term unemployment. We have now seen a reduction of almost 90,000 in the number of long-term unemployed people since March 1993.

Contrast that with the coalition's performance and specifically look at the Liberals in Victoria. The Victorian Premier has become notorious for his ability to reduce the quality of life for so many people. We all know full well, unfortunately, the difficulties that the Premier has created there for ordinary, everyday, hardworking Australians. That really does not warrant any further comment.

In my own state of New South Wales, where the Fahey Liberal government reigns, from 1991 until the federal government established a task force to identify transport links between Kingsford Smith airport, known as Mascot, and the proposed new airport, the New South Wales government has not participated in any planning to link those two airports. Earlier this year, the federal Minister for Transport (Mr Brereton) announced intentions to identify and plan for road and rail links between those two airports. He established the task force to work with the New South Wales government.

The New South Wales Liberal coalition government has not been easy to negotiate with, stipulating its involvement would be dependent on a Commonwealth government commitment to provide up-front funding of both road and rail links, including a $120 million funding commitment towards the city to Kingsford Smith airport rail link. Wanting to secure cooperation, our Commonwealth government attempted, as much as possible, to develop a good working relationship with the New South Wales government over this issue. But the New South Wales government would not agree to the State Rail Authority carrying out the engineering study for the rail link unless the Commonwealth gave a commitment to pay for the lot once again. Even after the Commonwealth made $200,000 available for that rail study, New South Wales continued to baulk at having any involvement in that engineering study. Eventually, the New South Wales Liberal coalition government reluctantly agreed to participate.

As well, despite receiving millions of dollars from the federal government to improve our national highways, the financial year of 1993-94 saw the New South Wales government divert some $50 million to non-road purposes. If New South Wales continues to divert a considerable proportion of its discretionary spending to consolidated revenue, how can the federal government treat seriously calls from New South Wales to allocate more money for New South Wales roads.

The recent outcry about noise and low flying aircraft has certainly sparked a new controversy and debate about the opening of a third runway at Sydney's Mascot airport. Eyes will soon turn to developing the proposed airport at Badgerys Creek in Sydney's west. Certainly building the airport at Badgerys Creek has its attractions. It should lead, as I am informed—and statistics back it up—to the creation of thousands of jobs not only in constructing the airport and transport links but also in the companies that will relocate to our area. It also has scope to increase opportunities in the manufacturing and tourism sectors.

The federal Minister for Transport recently announced that three route options have been identified for the new national highway link between Prestons and Cecil Park in Sydney's west and that an environmental impact study will commence to determine the best route. The Prestons to Cecil Park link is the southernmost of the three sections of the western Sydney orbital. It is proposed that this new road take long-distance heavy vehicles out of Sydney's local and arterial road system and form part of the link from Kingsford Smith airport to Sydney West airport.

Regarding all aspects of the airport, however, on behalf of the constituents I represent, I would urge planners to consider carefully all implications for people residing within the area. We must learn lessons from experience and we must plan to provide adequate infrastructure. We have the chance now to get it right from the outset.

The federal government in its Working Nation document committed itself to a longer runway at Badgerys Creek being finished by 1999. But various people now want that $73 million spending to be brought forward to the next calendar year and another $47 million allocated to the FAC dedicated to immediate construction of Badgerys Creek. I have personally written to the federal Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories, Senator John Faulkner, outlining in detail my concerns about all aspects of the proposal and its impact on people in my electorate.

I favour a further EIS being conducted under the auspices of the Commonwealth environmental portfolio, taking into account the full potential impact for people who live, work or engage in other day-to-day activities in proximity to those proposed flight paths of the proposed airport. Any EIS should be capable of withstanding the test of public scrutiny. Anything less would fail to convince the community and may raise doubts about the intention of long-term airport operations.

We cannot fast-track construction at Badgerys Creek without an updated full environmental impact statement on the issue. A very detailed EIS was completed in 1985, and I have read it, but many changes have occurred in western Sydney over the nine years since that EIS was completed. The 1985 EIS suggested a runway of 1,200 metres but in 1991—and I am pleased to say following a great deal of pressure from western New South Wales members—the then Minister for Transport changed the length of the runway to something like 1,800-odd metres. Also, following further representation to our federal minister, we have now announced the construction of an international standard 2.9 kilometre runway instead of the 1.8 kilometre general aviation facility that was originally planned for Badgerys Creek.

A whole host of environmental issues must be considered such as air quality and pollution, fuel, flooding, water run-off and the effects of a completed international airport on run-off. We need a reassessment of the noise maps, and guarantees that aircraft will remain in the corridors already set down. The new site for the airport is very close to Horsley Park, Bossley Park, Smithfield, Greystanes and Fairfield—all areas and suburbs within the electorate that I represent. I have consistently recommended a very cautious approach to this development because of the potential for adverse impact on the area.

Bearing in mind that the proposed airport is to be operational 24 hours a day, the possible situation for many people is very serious. Planners must think about the implications each time a heavily laden aircraft flies low over Sydney's most densely populated western region. They should particularly give consideration to take-off and landing in the early hours of the morning and the impact it would have on residents' lives. I wonder whether the planners and so-called experts realise the amount of noise generated by aircraft landing or taking off at 2 a.m. or 3 a.m. This is what we must give consideration to.

I certainly sympathise with those people who are affected by the opening of the third runway. But I will say most sincerely that many people purchased properties in that region knowing the airport was there. Certainly, many have known it has been there for many years. Conversely, though, some people within my electorate had never contemplated having an airport in the area, even though now many welcome it—and certainly our council does. Years ago some made an initial choice to live in the quiet rural areas of the electorate and others, who have moved in since the 1975 subdivision started, would not have had any inkling that an airport could be constructed in the area and that they could end up under a flight path. I think that choice has now been taken away from a lot of people. As an article on flight paths, which appeared in last Saturday's Weekend Australian, so very logically puts it:

SPEECH.PARA: The opening of the third runway and the unsynchronised commissioning of the new air traffic control tower meant residents got a Big Bang taste of 2010 conditions.

I have used that quote in my speech today because what I am really saying, on behalf of the people I represent, is that we do not want the big bang effect in the Prospect electorate. What we do want is adequate planning and consideration for people's welfare; what we do want is a continued guarantee from our minister and our government that, when that construction is put in place, it will be done efficiently and, as I have said repeatedly, with infrastructure so that the communication links by rail and road are completed.

PARA.TAB: We want to make sure that what we plan to build today will take us well through the 21st century. We want provisions and facilities in the western region of Sydney that are going to be classed as second to none, because we do not want to be second-class. I believe that we have the intent, the ability and, certainly, the means by which our planning policies can be put in place so that the people who are affected will not be placed in the same position in which they have recently been placed in the Mascot-Kingsford Smith area.

I believe most sincerely in what our government is about. I believe in what we are about in our white paper and our employment creations.
