I believe in the sincerity with which we have, at all times, openly dealt with the public of Australia. But I will again insist—both to the minister, as I have in the past, and to all others in this House—that we do the job well. Let us plan it correctly and adequately. Let us at no time in the future—and, if it is not us, the people who follow us, who stand up and represent their constituencies in the same proud way as we who have been elected and are here today do—have to wear the bad decisions of something that we have been part of today. I would not like to see that happen in the future. Most particularly, I put it on the record that I would like to see adequate planning put into place so that we can proudly proceed to the future and not be ashamed of what we could leave behind for others to bear the brunt of.

On behalf of the constituents whom I represent, I commend the government for all the actions it is now taking. But I will ask it again to make sure that a lot of thought is given before we rush in. We have not in the past rushed into something like this; I do not believe that, because of outside pressures, we should now turn around and try to quick start a project that needs a lot of planning to be successful and, most importantly, to be done correctly. I put this on record in the House in the appropriation debate whilst at the same time commending the government and the ministry on what we have been able to do—it may be happening slowly, but it is happening—with industry and particularly with the people we represent: those long-term unemployed, those who did not have a place in history and who are very important. We as a government, through the white paper and the statements we have put into place, have been able to offer them a future—a future with opportunities and, most importantly, a future where this Labor government will go from strength to strength. I commend the bills to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cobb Mr M.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I am sure that you, like other members in this chamber, will be aware of the famous sports people that come from the electorate of Parkes: I guess the most famous would be Phillip Adams from Forbes. No Australian has won more Commonwealth Games medals, whether they be gold, silver or bronze, than Phillip. He has been a great ambassador for Australia in pistol shooting. Even as recently as yesterday, we had two Narromine athletes performing well for this country. Glenn McGrath plays cricket for Australia. Who could forget seeing, on our television screens last night, that famous inswinger cleaning up one of the English batsmen? Further, when I got back to the motel and turned on the TV, there was Melinda Gainsford winning the indoor 200 metres, beating even as famous a person as Cathy Freeman. But it is not about them that I want to talk today. I wish to talk about cleaning up drugs in sport. The athletes that I have just mentioned have been exemplary in this regard.

PARA.TAB: For some time now, the world has been suspicious that China is guilty of using systematic doping to produce artificial world champions, particularly in swimming—though positives have turned up in drug testing of competitors in canoeing, athletics and other sports. If we look at swimming, we see that, of the world's top 25 rankings for each swimming stroke, in 1991 China had six listings; a year later that had increased fourfold to 24 listings; and a year later, in 1993, that had increased fourfold again to 96 listings. Such a meteoric rise in itself is suspicious, particularly as only one of those listings was a male, with the rest being female. The very top performers won six medals at the world's swimming championships in Perth in 1991; but this year, 1994, in September, in Rome at the Foro Italico pool, they won 24 medals. What is particularly notable is that all the medal winners this year were female; in fact, they won 12 of the 16 gold medals, and not one male Chinese swimmer made a final. That in itself causes a suspicion that they may be taking drugs. Only last month in October at the Asian Games in Hiroshima, the women won all 15 gold medals in swimming.

With this meteoric rise, there has been the very physical evidence, I believe, especially to the trained eye, of the use of drugs, particularly anabolic steroids, the testosterone derivatives, and human growth hormone. Looking at the female Chinese swimmers, we see about them a lot of non-feminine characteristics. There are the deep husky voices of the girls. At the world championships when Lu Bin came in and won the 200 metres freestyle, as well as being a relay competitor, her deep baritone voice apparently shocked the audience, including the 60 journalists, there. She said that she was not on drugs and that these accusations against Chinese female swimmers were racist.

But, apart from voice, another characteristic is excessive body hair, where it is not shaved, of course—particularly facial hair. Most alarming is the thickening and protrusion of the mandible, the lower jawbone. I guess equally if not more worrying are the characteristics that we do not see, some of which may not turn up for years—damage done to the liver from trying to detoxify the testosterone floating around in these athletes' bodies; the diabetes problems resulting from it; and, later in life, most tragically of all, the infertility problems caused by damage done to the reproductive systems of these girls.

Throughout all these accusations, the Chinese officials, including government officials, denied that any doping was going on. The athletes themselves have denied that any doping was going on. The accusers have been called racists. Even Juan Antonio Samaranch, the Chairman of the International Olympic Committee, who supported Beijing against Sydney for the 2000 Olympics, dismissed these allegations and declared China `very clean'.

The pattern that I have outlined amongst Chinese athletes, particularly the swimmers, is all very similar to what the world went through in the 1980s with happenings in East Germany before the Berlin Wall came down. Only in today's December edition of Swimming World, which has just been released in America, there is a very interesting article showing, from the opening up of the Stasi files—the Stasi, of course, being the East German secret police—that every East German world-class swimmer was doped. The evidence is there recorded. The testosterone levels—the male hormone levels—in those German female swimmers were very great indeed.

Of course, testosterone injected into females accelerates muscle growth and reduces the recovery times between events. A normal male will have about 40 parts per cubic centimetre of urine. There is some testosterone normally in a female but it is about five parts per cubic centimetre. In a normal individual walking around, the ratio of testosterone to epitestosterone—which is the natural preform of testosterone—is one to one. It can rise, abnormally, in exceptional circumstances to three to one. The International Olympic Committee has set a standard ratio of testosterone to epitestosterone at six to one. So, if people test positive to testosterone, there is no doubt that they take the drug.

Kristin Otto, the East German swimmer who won six gold medals at Seoul in 1988, had a ratio of 17 to one. According to the files, there were other East German girls whose levels fluctuated between nine to one and 12 to one. So the East German swimmers were a total pack of cheats, nothing more and nothing less.

Over the past two years, and before a recent event which I will come to in a minute, five Chinese swimmers have tested positive. The five includes Yang Aihua, who won the 400 metres at the world championships. Her test at the world championships turned up clear but she was tested randomly two weeks later, before the Asian Games, and she tested positive. According to one newspaper report, the Sydney Morning Herald of 3 December, her test results were held up for several weeks:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . to allow a suitable time to elapse between Samaranch's comment—
that the Chinese were very clean—
and the proof that Chinese sport was anything but very clean.

These five positives that have turned up over the last two years are equivalent to the total positive results in swimmers of all countries over the last 22 years. Indeed, 45 Chinese athletes overall—and that is outside swimming as well—have tested positive since 1987.

PARA.TAB: At the Asian Games, something else happened. A surprise test was done on the swimmers three days before the games, not after, and 11 Chinese athletes turned up positive, including eight female swimmers. Those who tested positive included Lu Bin, who tried to scale a wall to avoid being tested after an event. She won the 200 metres at the world championships in 1:56.89.

Le Jingyi, who holds the world record, which she set at the world championships, for 50 metres of 24.51 and for 100 metres of 54.01, was excluded from the eight swimmers who turned up positive. She is the girl we have all been seeing on our television sets in recent weeks. She has very broad shoulders which taper down to a narrow waist. She looks like she has swung out of a tree with a gorilla and she would be the envy of every male bodybuilder in the world. She tested negative, but surely there is no doubt that she also is positive. I might just add that testosterone particularly helps the sprinters—and she is a 50-metre and a 100-metre sprinter—because of the bulk they put on. The benefit gained from using testosterone starts to dissipate when you get up to the distance events, such as the 800 metres.

It appears that the Chinese athletes have been able to avoid testing positive when they have been tested after the competition events because of such devices as flushing, whereby they use diuretics to flush out of the body the urine with the high testosterone in it so that the urine sample taken later is a dilute one. Apparently they have also been using masking drugs, which block the kidneys from excreting testosterone. By using these flushing and masking techniques, the drugs can be flushed out of the system within 48 hours.

So it is obvious that it is vital to use random testing of athletes and what is called `out of competition' testing of athletes to pick up this use. In the Chinese program, only about 20 per cent of their total testing is out of competition testing whereas in Australia 50 per cent of the tests fall into this category. We need these tests to be done to establish baseline levels for individual athletes.

When the Chinese were tested, Lu Bin's level was very high indeed. I guess that the testosterone levels floating around in the bodies of Lu Bin and Le Jingyi would probably be equivalent to the level of the combined teams of the Canberra Raiders and the Brisbane Broncos. I say to the world international swimming community—particularly to the Chinese community—that, if they want their female swimmers to look like males, to act like males and to swim like males, they should ban them from the female events and let them compete in the male events.

I believe that this is a human rights issue. Perhaps it should be taken up by the United Nations and perhaps education programs for female swimmers should be put in place. Yang, the 400-metre swimmer who has turned up positive, trains under Zhou Ming at the Guang Zhou Military Club, along with sprinter Le Jingyi, who won four gold medals and set four world records at the world titles, and the dual backstroke world champion, He Cihong. I would say that there is no doubt—the circumstantial evidence is very heavy indeed—that the coaches know what is going on with these swimmers, even though one of them did not test positive.

I would stress that it is not just the athletes who take the drugs but those who administer them who are particularly at fault. The Australian stance on coaches who are found administering drugs to athletes is that they should be banned not just for two or four years but for life. I believe that at present the swimmers are banned for only two years. So they can compete at one Olympic Games, be picked up with a positive test, dry out and compete at another Olympic Games. I believe they should be banned for four years, including one Olympic Games, and that all their medals and previous records should be stripped off them when that happens. I also believe that a country with a large number of athletes who test positive should forfeit its right to compete for a number of years until it can show that particular sport is clean to the satisfaction of International Olympic Committee standards.

TALK.START.PARA: —It's outright cheating.

—It is outright cheating, as the member for Gippsland says. China complains that there is a high cost in this testing. But, if it is spending millions of dollars on putting its athletes through these sorts of military training programs to try to gain some world kudos, which it is, it can throw a few of those dollars, or Chinese yuan, aside to do the drug testing which goes with it. The Chinese have to be responsible in this regard.

PARA.TAB: As far as the Australian athletes go, I feel very sorry indeed for former athletes such as Michelle Ford, who was denied higher medals because she competed against East German swimmers who were drugged. I feel sorry for our swimmers who have come back from the world championships, such as Elli Overton, Susan O'Neill and Hayley Lewis who would have been higher placed were it not for those Chinese cheats who came in ahead of them.

I praise the work of Steven Haynes and Nicki Vance of the Australian Sports Drug Agency, who are doing such great work there, and others who have spoken out, like Paul Quinlan, who is the AIS swimming manager and the Vice-President of the World Swimming Coaches Association. I also praise the outspoken words of coaches such as Forbes Carlile, Don Talbot and Otto Sonnleitner, who is the Australian Swimming Coaches Association chairman, who are calling for stiffer penalties.

I say to China to get rid of its cheats and to lift its standards on having disregard for the lives of the individual swimmers. Possibly some of the swimmers who are taking these tablets orally think they are taking vitamin pills and do not realise what in fact they are taking. That was certainly the case in East Germany. If that is happening in China, it is all the more reprehensible. While this is going on, China at this stage is not fit to host international events such as future Olympic Games and future Asian Games.

I am very fond of Chinese people. The people of Chinese extraction who have settled in Australia are wonderful, hardworking citizens who have set a great example to other Australians. Chinese people can stand up in the world and hold their heads high in their own right. Chinese athletes do not need coaches and government officials directing them to take performance enhancing drugs.

The International Olympic Committee should realise that the game is up with China, as it was with East Germany. The IOC should take strict action to clean up drug misuse in sport. It is the IOC's duty to play a strong role to ensure that the world of sport is free of drugs. It should ostracise the countries and the coaches who encourage drug taking. It should take appropriate strong action against athletes who test positive in the future.

TALKER.NAME: Ms CRAWFORD
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Housing and Regional Development)

TALK.START.PARA: —It gives me great pleasure to speak today on the appropriation bills. As most of the honourable members in this House will recognise, appropriation bills are about money and the funding of government programs. A major issue connected with appropriation and state-Commonwealth funding arrangements is that dealt with by Hilmer in looking at national competition policy and through that at the concept of a national electricity grid.

PARA.TAB: While people, in principle, support the concept of a national electricity grid, it is a different issue when the power poles required for that grid are to go through their home and affect their livelihood or, more importantly—as the good citizens of Boonah would argue—they are to go through a recognised scenic rim. Over 200 people attended a public meeting in Boonah last week to voice their opposition to the proposed route for the QEC east link. They have formed themselves into a group called the Boonah Citizens Opposed to East Link.

It befits the government to listen to those community concerns and to evaluate them so that, if the option is chosen to put powerlines through there, the decision is made with all the facts to hand and taking into consideration all the issues that the community has raised. Many of the issues raised at that public meeting had not been brought to the attention of the QEC.

The area in which the QEC intends to place these powerlines covers the Mount French National Park, the Mount Greville National Park, the Main Range National Park, the Mount Barney National Park and the Lamington National Park. These areas are recognised as having value to the community. These areas should be preserved and their character should be preserved.

The area itself is recognised as being part of the scenic rim. It embraces a number of shires and it has changed from a dairying community to a tourism community. That is particularly important. It has nine outdoor education establishments for school children and it is the largest area that provides such facilities in south-east Queensland. Over 10,000 students per year visit this area to participate in outdoor education pursuits.

Those establishments have chosen this area because of its beauty and because of its access to both the mountains and the water—although, sadly, there is not too much water at the moment. This area has been chosen because it provides a unique opportunity for our young people not only to develop themselves and to learn the kind of self-esteem and self-confidence which come from outdoor education but also to learn to value the environment which they have access to. That is one issue.

The other issue has been the pursuit of tourism as the area has attempted to diversify from fairly intensive dairy farming. Indeed, over 10,000 adults a year visit this area on wilderness holidays. Mount Barney lodge camping ground cites how it offers the opportunity to share our wilderness heritage. Yarramalong advertises indoor recreation with privacy, no overcrowding, and horse riding facilities. The national horse trails go through this area. O'Reilly's mountain resort is there. Tamborine Mountain and Willowbank Raceway are there. There is a whole range of things.

This whole area has a historical perspective as well as its tourist attractions. It is believed by those people who are working in that area that they will not be able to continue their tourism operations if the skyline is ruined by unsightly, hideous powerlines.

One of the important attractions of the area is the fact that it is the leading parachuting centre in Queensland. At Boonah there is tandem and free-fall training. Gliding is also very significant. We have the Kooralbyn Parachute Centre and the ultralight operation located in Boonah. All of those operations are placed at risk if the QEC east link connection goes through this area. How on earth can people parachute if they are in danger of falling onto powerlines? How can people glide if they are in danger of falling onto powerlines? How can people fly ultralights if they are in danger of falling onto powerlines?

I also point out that Mount French is classified as 26. For those people in this chamber who do not know what 26 means, it can be equated to degrees of difficulty, and 26 means that this is an international peak. It is where our Olympians go to train for their mountain climbing. It is where those people who hope to climb the Himalayas also go to test themselves. Why would they want to climb to the top of Mount French lookout and see ugly powerlines in front of them? Of course, they do not want that and nobody who is reasonable would want it.

There are very real concerns about people's livelihoods, people's quality of life and, more importantly, people's incomes in a community which has shown it can diversify. It is, however, still a very large farming community, producing carrots, Queensland pumpkins, avocados, fruits and flowers.

A matter of real concern is an admission by the QEC that it uses chemicals under its powerlines to keep the grass at bay. Does a farmer who has to put up with these terrible powerlines through the middle of his farm have any guarantee that the chemicals used by the QEC to keep the grass at bay will not find its way onto his carrots or pumpkins? All of us have been made very conscious of what is happening with the use of chemicals, particularly in the international meat market. Not only do farmers lose control over their property, but they have no control over what the Queensland Electricity Commission may be doing with chemicals. That is one very real concern for quite a large number of the farming community.

We can say categorically that the people whose livelihoods are at risk, whose whole quality of life depends on the recreational and national environmental parks in this area, are vigorously opposed to the QEC east link going through that area. They would argue that this area is designated national park; it is designated heritage. It is part of our history and, as such, should be preserved and should be pristine.

Tourism is now very much a part of the livelihood of that community. The power link would be totally and utterly destructive of ecotourism. People parachuting, gliding or flying ultralights would no longer have clear airspace. The Olympic climbers and our mountain climbers who go to Mount French to test themselves would no longer enjoy the conditions they do now.

I bring to this House, with all the weight I can muster, the views of those residents who were at the Boonah council chambers last week. They expressed their very precise and very clear objections to the placement of the QEC east link through their area. They object not because they are necessarily opposed to the QEC east link—although people did raise issues as to whether this was necessary, and whether in fact the kind of electricity that would be generated in the link-up would be important—but because, if they are to survive as a community, they need that area to remain pristine. They need that area to remain as part of our heritage in order to develop their livelihoods through tourism, through outdoor education and, indeed, through the kind of farming to which they have now adapted.

There are a couple of other concerns which have come about, with some of the changes and some of the moves that we have seen, through governments seeking to become more competitive and perhaps more financially secure. Within this area we have also had a second action by the Department of Primary Industries, which took over the water resources management of Moogerah Dam at Lake Moogerah. Unfortunately, the dam is currently only operating at 9 per cent capacity, and we all hope and pray for a break in the drought.

As if that situation were not bad enough, we now find that the children's play equipment in the area has been taken away and that the area is being only scruffily maintained. The citizens there are very concerned. They believe that in this, the International Year of the Family, it is wrong that this very popular family area—where people can take their own lunch, have their children play and be very much part of a family situation—can have its playground equipment removed in the middle of the night because of certain financial constraints on government departments, and it is wrong that the kinds of maintenance and facilities needed are no longer available to families.

This is particularly important, given that we have school holidays in the next week or two. Given the constraints of the financial impact of the drought upon them, very many local people will not be able to go very far from home, and this is a very popular place for family gatherings to be held. What could be more delightful than children being able to play on playground equipment, with parents bringing their own food and using the barbecues there, and doing so in an area which is relatively pleasant and not just scruffily maintained?

I urge this House to give some consideration to the community's concerns when we are discussing the appropriation bills and the finances which we see translated from the federal government to the states. We are, after all, appropriating Australian taxpayers' dollars. It is their money. Our people pay taxes to ensure that government services run; and all of us need to be very conscious that there is no question that the concerns and needs of the community need to be addressed.

We are, after all, a government about people, and I urge this parliament and this government to do what they can to ensure that the needs which were expressed last week by the people of Boonah are heeded and taken into account when government decisions are made. While we may think about a national grid and look to savings with the sharing of electricity and so on—all of which, of itself, may be valuable—when we are standing here we perhaps fail to recognise that the communities out there, at the very heart of what we are doing, may not want this.

These people certainly do not want the QEC east link in their national parks, because it will destroy their livelihood. The very reason for their living in that community will be gone, because those pristine environments—those national parks which are part of our heritage—will in fact no longer be as they are now; and neither will our farmers be able to continue to give us guaranteed clean food. In the debate on this appropriation bill, I give voice to the needs of that community and bring those needs before the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to use the consideration of the appropriation bills to review the state of the economy and where Australia might go. This is the appropriate occasion in the House for that kind of activity. The current situation of the economy is a delightful one, as has been said a number of times in the last day or two from this side of the House. The rate of economic growth is measured at 6.4 per cent and even if those figures have to be revised downward, as is possible because it seems extraordinarily rapid, it is quite clear that the economy is now growing very strongly, that the level of economic activity is high and that therefore there will a strong rate of economic growth and a strong rate of employment growth, which is what we all want.

PARA.TAB: The principal problem of the Australian economy at present is the level of unemployment. It has fallen significantly from its peak but it is still over 9 per cent, and we want that to come down rapidly and to remain much lower. One of the principal requirements for that is for the level of economic activity to remain strong.

The rate of inflation is also extraordinarily low. At less than two per cent, less than half the OECD average, that is less than half also the rate amongst our trading partners, and there is no significant sign of that rate of inflation increasing. It is quite clear too that business investment is growing strongly and that there is also strong growth in many exports. Of course, the drought is retarding growth of primary exports, which is a tragedy for the rural sector. The government has a package in place to try to offset that to a limited extent but the drought is containing the growth of the whole economy and, until the drought breaks, we will not see the uniform spread of economic activity that we want to see.

Given those situations and the fact that we still have a significant current account deficit, it is important to try to maximise growth of employment, to minimise the impact of that on the current account deficit and to minimise the impact of it on inflation. The question is how we do that, and it is not an easy policy balance to achieve.

We all want to avoid increases in interest rates and taxation but, on the other hand, it is crucial to ensure that this recovery, this strong period of economic growth, is sustainable. That cannot happen if we go into a too rapid boom in a way that leads inevitably to a recession later on. So the question is what balance of policies the government and the Reserve Bank should use to ensure sustainability.

Many people, particularly from the financial markets, have been arguing that interest rates should be increased yet again. I think they neglect the fact that, since the September quarter increase in the national accounts, there have already been two increases in interest rates, increases totalling one and 3/4per cent, the most recent of which was towards the end of October. It is quite clear that those increases would not have made any impact at all on the activity in the September quarter, and it is therefore appropriate to wait awhile before any further decision is made on interest rates.

Some of the commentary from the financial markets suggests that the government and the Reserve Bank should act as if what is happening at this very moment, the beginning of December, is what was measured for the September quarter. That is an oversimplification. It is highly likely that the growth rate will remain strong now, but it may be somewhat less than it was measured to be in the September quarter, because of the impact of those two interest rate increases. It is quite clear, for example, that housing activity is already tailing off a bit. I know, from anecdotal evidence, of business people who have deferred investments that they were planning, because of the two increases in interest rates that have already occurred, and because they fear that there may be more in the pipeline and they fear the cost that those increases would cause them if they were to invest further now.

I think responsible policy would suggest that there should not be any further increases in interest rates for some time, until it is possible to accurately and comprehensively evaluate the impact of the two increases in interest rates that have already occurred, and the consequences of that impact for every part of the economy. It is important to do that, of course, in ways that take account not only of statistics but also of the evidence that comes from the business sector, the housing sector and the consumer sector, in so far as that can be assessed. Of course, since the Christmas period is always a period of very rapid activity—a turbulent period, if you like, in measured terms—it would be wise to leave further decisions until late January or February.

It is good to see that the Reserve Bank has today decided not to announce any further increase. I hope that it will take no further action for at least a couple of months. One would hope that it would then find that further increases were not necessary. We want to avoid interest increases in so far as we possibly can, because they increase the cost of investment and they increase the cost to home buyers and buyers of white goods and cars, and we want the level of economic activity to remain as strong as is possible. One of the lessons of the last decade was that interest increases can be very damaging. That is the lesson, not only from Australia but also from other countries.

Therefore, we want to be quite cautious about any increases that occur. The fact that increases are happening in the United States does not mean that they are appropriate policy here, not least because real interest rates in Australia are already—still—well above those in the United States, despite the fact that there have been half a dozen increases there. Because our inflation rate is so low, the real level of interest here is still high, by historical standards and by international standards. We ought to remember that.

As well, we need to remember that when interest rates rise the exchange rate rises. That has happened in the months that have followed the increases in interest rates here. Increases in the exchange rate make adjustment of the current account deficit more difficult. For those reasons, as well as for the reason that we want employment growth to be maximised, we should be very cautious about any further increases in interest rates.

Of course, we have to find ways of containing demand. It seems entirely appropriate for the government to be seriously thinking about very modest, progressive increases in taxation. It is something new in the Australian environment, since the last decade and a half, for there to be serious consideration of what should be done about taxation. During the last decade we had a whole series of reductions in taxation, which were no doubt widely welcomed. But it is responsible, as the Treasurer said yesterday, to use taxation, as well as monetary policy and policy about outlays, as countercyclical policy.

At a time when outlays have been severely constrained, when there are strong demands for improvements in education or health or welfare, or for spending on the arts, the environment or infrastructure, and those demands are entirely justified, it seems right to consider the possibility of using taxation as well as outlays as a countercyclical tool.

The question then for the government is how to do that. All of us would have our appropriate suggestions to make, but I would want to emphasise that the changes should be carefully targeted and should be progressive. In other words, they should be imposed on areas where people can more readily afford them; in other words, they should be imposed on high income earners rather than low income earners or middle income earners or perhaps on certain areas in the business sector where they will not discourage investment.

Such areas are available. Let me mention just a couple. A very obvious area would be to halve dividend imputation. Australia is, I am told, perhaps the only country, but at the very least one of the few countries, with 100 per cent dividend imputation. Most countries in the OECD have half dividend imputation. That is a benefit, of course, only to those who own shares. By definition, that is principally those who are on upper incomes or the more wealthy. To halve dividend imputation would still give them some of the benefit of that policy but it would save about $900 million in revenue forgone. That would be an equitable measure. It would bring us into line with a lot of the rest of the Western world, and it would not discourage the purchase of shares. I think that that is a very serious possibility that ought to be considered.

Another course which many people mention would be to do away with negative gearing. That too is a tax policy that is of benefit to those who are by definition relatively well off, who can benefit from the effect of their assets on their net income. I think a lot of people judge that abolition of negative gearing would be a progressive policy. Another possibility would be changes to some of the tax treatment of superannuation, particularly for very high income earners.

Other possibilities are available but those ones would be quite well targeted. They would be progressive policies which would not discourage investment, which would bring us into line with much of the rest of the Western world, which would not be discriminatory and which would be paid for by those who can most readily afford them. It is important to consider those possibilities, as well as the possibility of perhaps a higher marginal rate for people on over $70,000. There is nothing sacrosanct about the upper limit at present of $50,000. That too would make the income tax system rather more progressive.

I have explored these ideas with quite a lot of care in a book that I wrote with a friend at the Australian National University, John Quiggin, and we have done quite a bit of research on them. Therefore I make these suggestions on the basis of quite a bit of careful thought, and I hope that they will be considered by the government.

I conclude by repeating that what is happening at present is in large measure the result of sound policy over the last few years. The economy is now growing strongly. The problems are the delightful ones of a strong recovery. The issues for the government are how to ensure that that recovery can be sustained so that employment can go on growing in the ways that we all want. Employment growth will occur mainly in the service sector, and a lot of it in the human service sector. To build up the revenue base allows some of that growth of employment to be in the area of publicly provided human services like education and health, areas where there are desperate needs for improvement.

The example that seems to me to be most powerful is that at the beginning of this year 140,000 people who applied to go to technical and further education colleges were not able to find places. Therefore, it is a very high priority to build up the number of places available so that those people can get the skills that they need for the working life that they want and so that Australia can have the benefit of a more skilled work force.

For some of the additional revenue to be used for improvements in the number of TAFE places would be welcomed very widely in the community. Since TAFEs are the most widely underfunded areas of education, I think that is one of the highest priorities for use of any additional revenue that is available. No doubt, some of the additional revenue would rightly be used for reducing the deficit. It should also be used in ways that will maximise growth of employment, and the TAFE sector is a particularly good example. I conclude by reiterating the centrality of the employment goal and the need to ensure sustainable economic development in ways that will also include increased equity, which would in turn contribute to making the economy more humane and sustainable.
