DEBATE.TITLE: FINANCIAL MANAGEMENT AND ACCOUNTABILITY BILL 1994Cognate bills:COMMONWEALTH AUTHORITIES AND COMPANIES BILL 1994AUDITOR-GENERAL BILL 1994

PARA.TAB: Consideration resumed from 29 June.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: This bill, together with the two others that are part of the same package, is to replace the Audit Act 1901. That act is one of the few Commonwealth laws that have operated continuously since they were passed by this parliament in its first session after federation. Its intended replacement, therefore, represents something of a landmark in the history of Commonwealth financial administration. The Audit Act is not being replaced simply because it is old. In fact, it has proved remarkably robust over its 93-year life in providing for the procedural framework for Commonwealth financial administration and for the audit of the Commonwealth's activities. But too many of its basic concepts and structures reflect their 19th century origins to an extent that ignores and in some cases even impedes modern management practice and contemporary expectations for public sector accountability.

PARA.TAB: These limitations were recognised by the Joint Committee of Public Accounts in the course of its comprehensive inquiry into the operations of the Audit Office. In its report 296, tabled in April 1989, the JCPA recommended that the Audit Act be replaced with more modern legislation, with separate acts to deal with auditing and financial administration. In giving effect to that recommendation, the government believes that clarity would be served best through the adoption of three new acts. It is proposed that there be an Auditor-General Act to provide for the powers and functions of the Auditor-General. In relation to financial administration, however, Commonwealth bodies differ according to the basic legal financial status that each one has—namely, whether the body has the legal capacity, in its own right, to acquire ownership of money and other assets coming into its possession, or whether it acts only as a financial and custodial agent for the Commonwealth, without acquiring separate legal ownership of such money and assets.

Consequently, it is proposed that there be a Commonwealth Authorities and Companies Act to specify certain matters that are to apply to the operations of financially autonomous bodies—that is, Commonwealth bodies that have legal ownership of money in their own right; and a Financial Management and Accountability Act, to apply to the financial operations of agencies—that is, Commonwealth bodies that financially are agents of the Commonwealth in that the bodies acquire no legal ownership of the money that they raise and spend. That money, in the constitutional sense, directly comprises the `Treasury of the Commonwealth'.

Mr Deputy Speaker, you may recall that, upon introduction of the package of these three bills on 29 June 1994, the House agreed that the legislative package be referred to the Joint Committee of Public Accounts for its consideration and advisory report. JCPA report 331 tabled on 22 September 1994 is the result of that process. I believe that the committee is to be commended for its quality analysis and recommendations, the great majority of which the government accepts. In that regard, I foreshadow that the government will be moving a number of amendments to the bills to pick up the recommendations of the JCPA accepted by the government, together with several other minor changes the desirability for which became evident as a consequence of reviewing the bills to address the JCPA's examination.

I now wish to provide an outline of the proposed Financial Management and Accountability Act. The proposed act is concerned with the regulatory-accounting-accountability framework for dealing with and managing the money and property of the Commonwealth. It will specify responsibilities and powers necessary for the efficient, effective and ethical use of the resources lawfully available to the Commonwealth to carry out its programs; and it will provide appropriate mechanisms to ensure that the stewardship and management performance of those who are responsible for those resources can be made visible and thereby allow them to be held accountable. The proposed law will add substance to the spirit of the public sector financial reforms that have been a feature of this government's administration over the last decade. At the same time, the proposed Financial Management and Accountability Act is intended to preserve the traditional strengths of the Audit Act's key principles of financial control and, where possible, to clarify and simplify them.

The explanatory memorandum accompanying this bill deals comprehensively with its features. There are, however, a few elements that I would like to mention specifically. The definitions of `Agency', `Chief Executive', `official', `public money' and `public property', between them, describe the proposed boundaries of the act's application. Within those boundaries, the principles set down in the act will be fleshed out, where necessary, by subsidiary legislation—regulations and finance minister's orders—to provide procedural substance for the day-to-day application of those principles. Such a legislative framework is patterned on the structure established by the Audit Act for regulations and finance directions, except that, unlike finance directions, which are administrative in character, provision is made for finance minister's orders to be tabled as disallowable instruments. The legislative framework will be completed by instructions which chief executives will be authorised to issue to officials of their agencies.

The act will preserve the unique role of the Minister for Finance, which is central to the orderly functioning of the Commonwealth's financial administration. The finance minister is, for all practical purposes, the custodian of the constitutional `Treasury of the Commonwealth' so that the range of statutory powers and responsibilities for the proper custody of the Commonwealth's money is vested in that office. The finance minister will retain the sole power to agree appropriate banking arrangements for public money and to make orders concerning the handling of receipts and withdrawals of public money and its investment. The existing power under the Audit Act to arrange overdrafts and advances from banks has been clarified to specifically limit such arrangements as short-term cash management tools—overdrafts on operational bank accounts for up to 30 days; borrowings from banks as advances paid to the Commonwealth for up to 90 days; and other types of credit arrangements, to be prescribed by the regulations, such as those represented by credit card and cabcharge transactions, for up to 60 days. It should be noted that these arrangements confer no power for the Commonwealth to spend otherwise than as authorised by parliament through appropriations.

One of the most visible changes to be brought about by the proposed Financial Management and Accountability Act is in relation to the accounting classifications of money in the Commonwealth's possession. The trust fund established by section 60 of the Audit Act is to be abolished and replaced by two purpose based funds—the reserved money fund and the commercial activities fund. Apart from components of the reserved money fund that may be established pursuant to other enactments, the components of these two funds will be established or varied by finance minister's determinations. The effect of such determinations will be to specify the kinds of money that may be drawn from the consolidated revenue fund or loan fund and credited to the particular component and the purposes on which that money may then be spent.

Since the spending of money from such a fund is in all respects an appropriation, the proposed act will require that these determinations by the finance minister be tabled as disallowable instruments that do not take effect until the period for disallowance has passed. This procedure is more visible and provides a greater measure of parliamentary control than has traditionally been the case in the establishment of trust accounts under the Audit Act.

Payments of public money, including debiting a fund against an appropriation, will be controlled by a system of `drawing rights', to be issued by the finance minister. This system is predicated on the fact that the laws made by parliament relating to appropriations, variously compelling or permitting the executive government to spend, always specify the fund being appropriated and the purpose of the spending. Such laws may also specify an amount and a time frame. It would be a breach of section 83 of the constitution for spending to occur in any instance outside of those parameters, so the act will stipulate that the finance minister has no capacity to issue valid drawing rights that are inconsistent with the terms of the relevant appropriation law and will make it an indictable offence for an official or minister to knowingly spend, or seek to spend, otherwise than in accordance with a valid drawing right.

The act would create a standing appropriation out of which rewards could be paid in certain circumstances for information furnished that led to the apprehension of persons defrauding the Commonwealth. The government is serious about deterring and detecting fraud against the Commonwealth, and the potential for this measure to assist in that battle cannot be overlooked. Nevertheless, the government acknowledges the recommendation of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Banking, Finance and Public Administration in its report on the inquiry into fraud on the Commonwealth, Focusing on fraud, tabled in November 1993, that there be no such formal scheme of rewards. The response to that report, including that recommendation, is being considered by the government and will be announced shortly. Should it transpire that the government accepts the committee's recommendation, the government will move for this clause's removal from the bill.

The act would put into the principal legislation the powers that are presently carried only in finance regulations in relation to providing a source of authority for the Presiding Officers to approve expenditure under appropriations for parliamentary departments.

The present Audit Act is generally silent on matters of management performance. The new act seeks to remedy this through particular responsibilities being expressly placed on chief executives of agencies for which they may then be held accountable. They are to be required to manage the affairs of their agencies efficiently, effectively and ethically to the extent allowed by law. They will also be required to implement fraud control plans and establish audit committees. The accountability mechanisms to mesh with these responsibilities will include powers of the finance minister to obtain financial statements and other reports more frequently than annually from agencies.

Importantly, it is proposed that chief executives be permitted to subdelegate to officials any of the act's finance minister's powers or functions, unless the minister has imposed a restriction prohibiting or limiting such subdelegation. These arrangements for subdelegating are intended to achieve a major strengthening in the financial framework. Chief executives are better placed than the finance minister to manage, to monitor and to control the activities of those officials who perform the delegated tasks. It will thus be practicable to hold chief executives accountable to the finance minister in these respects, whereas it is currently quite impracticable to do so under the existing Audit Act's delegation structures where thousands of individual officials are directly delegated by the finance minister. The government believes that this proposed law represents a significant landmark in sharpening and strengthening the framework of Commonwealth financial administration. I commend the bill to the House.

SPEECH.PARA: COMMONWEALTH AUTHORITIES AND COMPANIES BILL 1994

PARA.TAB: The Commonwealth Authorities and Companies Bill 1994 is one of three bills forming the package of legislation to replace the Audit Act 1901. The bill seeks to replace and enhance part XI of the Audit Act 1901, which currently provides standard financial provisions for Commonwealth authorities and certain other bodies. It is also intended in due course that the proposed Commonwealth Authorities and Companies Act will replace individual financial provisions contained in the enabling legislation of authorities not subject to part XI.

As I foreshadowed in the second reading speech for the Financial Management and Accountability Bill 1994, the government will be moving a number of amendments to this package of legislation to pick up issues that have been considered following the report on the three bills by the Joint Committee of Public Accounts on 22 September 1994.

The underlying purpose of the proposed Commonwealth Authorities and Companies Act is to replace, with a single set of requirements, the myriad of variations on a similar theme scattered throughout the enabling legislation of Commonwealth authorities and the constitutions of Commonwealth companies. The approach proposed by this bill would enable the accountability requirements of Commonwealth controlled bodies to be viewed as a whole and should significantly streamline the focus of the government's and the parliament's interest in this area.

Broadly, the bill proposes a single set of core reporting and auditing requirements for directors of `Commonwealth authorities' and sets out standards of conduct for executive officers. Many of these requirements are modelled on comparable areas of the Corporations Law as well as best practice currently applying to individual authorities. The bill also proposes a single set of requirements for ensuring that `wholly-owned Commonwealth companies' keep ministers and the parliament informed of their activities.

In particular, this bill seeks to extend the mandate of the Auditor-General to be the sole external auditor of all Commonwealth authorities and companies, and their subsidiaries, without exception. At the same time it would modernise the requirements for the Auditor-General's reports on authorities making them consistent with those required by the Corporations Law.

In some areas, the bill traverses ground that is covered, to varying degrees, in the enabling legislation of authorities and the constitutional documents of companies. These areas of overlap will be removed by consequential amendments to the enabling legislation and are contained in the Audit (Transitional and Miscellaneous) Amendment Bill 1994, which I propose to introduce shortly. Similarly, it is intended to replace areas of overlap in the memoranda and articles of association of Commonwealth companies with cross-references to the proposed Commonwealth Authorities and Companies Act.

For the purposes of the bill, a `Commonwealth authority' is, in essence, one established by an act as a body corporate for a public purpose and which holds money on its own account. A `Commonwealth company' is one in which the Commonwealth has a direct controlling interest—that is, there is no interposed entity between the company and the Commonwealth.

All Commonwealth companies will be subject to the requirement for the Auditor-General to report on their financial statements, and the financial statements of their subsidiaries, and for their annual reports to be tabled in the parliament. However, only `wholly-owned Commonwealth companies' are to be subject to the other provisions in the bill relating to companies. This reflects the difficulty—in the case of Commonwealth controlled companies which have private shareholders—of imposing a general regime which requires the provision of plans and reports only to ministers: namely, a risk of oppression actions under the Corporations Law by minority shareholders who might perceive discrimination against their interests.

I will now briefly outline the main provisions of the proposed Commonwealth Authorities and Companies Act. The annual report is seen as the centrepiece of directors' accountability to the parliament. The bill proposes that directors of Commonwealth authorities must prepare an annual report containing a report of operations, financial statements and a report by the Auditor-General on the financial statements. The report of operations and the financial statements must be prepared in accordance with finance minister's orders and the directors and the Auditor-General must certify whether, in their opinion, the financial statements give a `true and fair view' of the matters required to be reported.

I should mention that the proposed obligations on directors, as individuals, will replace more general obligations on authorities under existing arrangements. This approach is similar in principle to that applied to companies by the Corporations Law and is intended to clarify the accountability arrangements. I should also mention that the finance minister's orders will be disallowable instruments, thereby ensuring an ongoing role for the parliament in determining the reporting obligations of directors of Commonwealth authorities.

The directors of both Commonwealth authorities and Commonwealth companies will be required to give the responsible minister a copy of their annual report, or annual general meeting documents, which the Minister must in turn table in each House of the parliament.

There are a number of other reporting obligations proposed by this bill. The finance minister may require Commonwealth authorities and wholly owned companies to prepare half-yearly or quarterly financial statements. The statements must be given to the responsible minister within two months after the end of the period to which they relate and must be tabled in each House as soon as practicable. It is envisaged that this requirement to prepare interim financial statements will mainly be applied to bodies with a high degree of independence, such as government business enterprises—GBEs. Of course, as the government, from time to time, develops new approaches to providing the services now provided by GBEs, there may be a need to look again at how the proposed act will apply to those bodies.

Directors will be required to keep the responsible minister informed of the operations of Commonwealth authorities and wholly owned companies, including their subsidiaries, and to give the responsible minister and the finance minister such reports, documents and information as they may require.

Where the finance minister requires such reports, documents and information it is intended that, in the normal course, he or she will first consult with the responsible minister and provide a copy of such reports or documents to that minister. Such consultative arrangements have not been included in the bill, because of longstanding policy, reaffirmed by successive governments, that as a general rule the internal operations of government should not be reflected in legislation.

Directors must also notify the responsible minister of certain proposed activities such as significant acquisitions or disposals of shares or businesses, changes in business activities or involvement in partnerships, trusts or joint ventures. However, the responsible minister may give written guidelines as to the coverage of the matters to be notified and may in writing exempt the directors from notifying particulars of proposals to form or participate in the formation of a company.

Directors of a government business enterprise, whether constituted as an authority or a company, must prepare a corporate plan at least once a year and give it to the responsible minister. This is a key planning document that will provide the responsible minister with financial and other performance information.

The bill also contains a number of miscellaneous provisions relating to the governance of Commonwealth authorities and wholly owned Commonwealth companies. It proposes that the responsible minister may, after consulting with directors, notify them of general policies of the government that are capable of being applied to the authority or company concerned. The directors must ensure that such policies are carried out and, as far as practicable, ensure that they are also carried out in relation to any subsidiaries. Such policies cannot be in conflict with any statutory obligations of a particular authority or company. This provision is intended to cover government policies that are applicable to the Commonwealth public sector in general—for example, policies relating to trade contact with foreign countries or equal employment opportunity.

Nevertheless, in recognition of their special roles, and so as to avoid any misconceptions in so far as the Australian Broadcasting Corporation and the Special Broadcasting Service are concerned, I intend to propose consequential amendments to their enabling acts through the foreshadowed Audit (Transitional and Miscellaneous) Amendment Bill that will make it abundantly clear that this provision cannot affect the editorial policy or independence of those bodies.

The bill also provides that directors must establish and maintain an audit committee. The government views this as a step in improving internal control and communication within Commonwealth authorities and wholly owned companies as well as the accountability of their management. It will also ensure that directors have appropriate assistance in the discharge of their accounting and financial reporting obligations.

Consistent with the government's response to a recommendation by the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration in its 1989 report on government companies and their reporting requirements, the bill provides that a Commonwealth authority must ensure that none of its subsidiaries does anything that the authority itself does not have power to do. This does not, of course, preclude the parliament from passing legislation to empower a subsidiary to perform a particular activity that exceeds the powers of its parent.

The bill imposes standards of conduct on executive officers of Commonwealth authorities broadly equivalent to the standards already imposed on executive officers of companies by the Corporations Law. Executive officers include directors and any other persons who are concerned in, or take part in, the management of the authority. Specifically, the bill provides that `executive officers' must at all times act honestly and exercise a reasonable degree of care and diligence in the exercise of their powers and the discharge of their duties. Also, an executive officer, or former executive officer, must not make improper use of inside information, or of his or her position as an executive officer, in order to gain an advantage for any person, either directly or indirectly, or cause detriment to the authority. Both criminal and civil sanctions are provided for contravention of these provisions.

In addition, a director of a Commonwealth authority who has an interest in a matter that is being considered, or about to be considered, by the board must, as soon as possible after he or she becomes aware of the situation, disclose the nature of the interest concerned at a meeting of the board. The director must not participate in deliberations on the matter concerned unless the board or the responsible minister determines otherwise.

Finally, in accordance with the government's response to another recommendation by the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration in its report on government companies and their reporting requirements, the bill provides that the responsible minister shall table in each House particulars of any new or varied direct Commonwealth interest in a company. The particulars required are to be prescribed by regulation.

The proposals put forward in this bill will have no direct impact on government revenues or outlays. However, I am confident that, through the implementation of a more streamlined and consistent operational and accountability framework for Commonwealth authorities and companies, improved performance and value for money will be achieved both for the Commonwealth and for Australians generally. I commend the bill to the House.

SPEECH.PARA: AUDITOR-GENERAL BILL 1994

PARA.TAB: This bill is one of the package of three bills to replace the Audit Act 1901. The other two bills are the Financial Management and Accountability Bill 1994 and the

SPEECH.PARA: Commonwealth Authorities and Companies Bill 1994. The purposes of the Auditor-General Bill are to continue the statutory office of the Auditor-General for the Commonwealth of Australia; to specify the powers and functions of the Auditor-General; to establish the Australian National Audit Office; and to provide, in turn, for the independent audit of the Australian National Audit Office.

PARA.TAB: The bill draws heavily on the recommendations of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts, JCPA, in report 296—The Auditor-General: ally of the people and parliament. The effect of the bill's proposed provisions will be to support the continued functional and professional independence of the Auditor-General from the executive government. The corollary is that the Auditor-General's special relationship with the parliament is protected.

As I foreshadowed in the second reading speech for the Financial Management and Accountability Bill 1994, the government will be moving a number of amendments to this package of legislation to pick up issues that have been considered following the report on the three bills by the Joint Committee of Public Accounts on 22 September 1994. I now wish to provide an outline of the proposed Auditor-General Act.

The bill specifies there is to be an Auditor-General for the Commonwealth of Australia and details the appointment and conditions of the office. The Auditor-General will continue to be appointed by the Governor-General on the recommendation of the appropriate minister—which, under the administrative arrangements orders, will be the Prime Minister. Under arrangements proposed in this bill, prior to advising the Governor-General, the Prime Minister must consult with the finance minister, the chairman of the JCPA and a nominee of the Leader of the Opposition. As recommended by the JCPA in report 331, the government will seek an amendment to the provision in the present bill to include a requirement for the Prime Minister to also consult with the chairperson of the audit committee of parliament, as appropriate. The bill also includes provisions for the removal of the Auditor-General by the Governor-General following a petition by both houses of the parliament in the same session.

The Auditor-General has a broad mandate to be enshrined in legislation, replacing the existing arrangements whereby the Auditor-General's mandate is only partly derived from legislation and partly from government policy. The Auditor-General will have a mandate to undertake the audit of the financial statements of all Commonwealth bodies. In addition, the Auditor-General may undertake performance audits of Commonwealth bodies at his or her discretion, the only exception being in respect of government business enterprises—GBEs—where the accountability framework established by the government requires GBEs to focus on performance and to improve the return to the Commonwealth as shareholder.

Despite the focus on performance by GBEs, the government nevertheless proposes that parliament or a minister may request the Auditor-General to carry out a performance audit of a GBE or GBE subsidiary. However, the government has reflected on the need to continue the principle, as already accepted under the Audit Act, of forbearance in consideration of the investment interests of private shareholders in partially privatised Commonwealth companies. Performance audits are an extra feature on the accountability landscape peculiar to public sector bodies. It does not follow, however, that the often high parliamentary profile given the reports of such audits would always be beneficial to the interests of the companies' private investor/shareholders. The government will, therefore, be proposing an amendment whereby a performance audit of a GBE company would be invited only if the company was wholly owned by the Commonwealth.

The bill seeks to permit the Auditor-General to enter into an arrangement with any person or body to conduct financial statements audits or performance audits, or to provide services that are of a kind that are normally performed by auditors. These arrangements would be at the discretion of the Auditor-General and be undertaken where he or she considers there is a benefit to the Commonwealth. The bill proposes that the Auditor-General and authorised officials have full and free access to information, documents and premises. These powers are considerable in their scope but are necessary if the Auditor-General is to fulfil his or her obligations to the parliament. The information gathering powers are complemented with strong secrecy and penalty provisions for any person performing an Auditor-General function.

The bill seeks to establish the Australian National Audit Office as a statutory authority with the sole function of assisting the Auditor-General. The staff of the Australian National Audit Office are to be appointed or employed under the Public Service Act 1922, as a reflection of its status as a core public service. Nevertheless, should the staff's existing skills and expertise need to be augmented from time to time, the bill also seeks to preserve the Auditor-General's flexibility to engage any person—for example, to contract with auditors from the private sector—to assist in the performance of an Auditor-General function. The government sees the establishment of the Australian National Audit Office as a statutory authority as an important symbolic step to demonstrate its commitment to the independence of the Auditor-General and his or her office.

Further, the bill would establish the office of independent auditor, who is the parliament's auditor of the Australian National Audit Office. It provides for the appointment and conditions of the office which, as far as are appropriate, mirror those of the Auditor-General in relation to his or her audit functions for the balance of the Commonwealth. The independent auditor is to be a part-time statutory officer appointed by the Governor-General on the advice of the appropriate minister, who will have first consulted with the chairman of the JCPA.

The independent auditor is to hold qualifications and have the experience determined necessary by the minister after consultation with the chairman of the JCPA. The government will seek an amendment to this provision to include a requirement for the minister to also consult with the chairperson of the audit committee of parliament, as appropriate. As previously indicated, the government has drawn heavily on the recommendations of the JCPA in framing this legislation.

While the committee's recommendations have not been taken up in their entirety, the provisions of this bill and the complementary provisions in the other two bills in the package ensure that the Auditor-General can fulfil, independently, the role demanded by this parliament, and with all the professional and functional freedom required for the task. The Auditor-General plays a vital role in giving credibility to Australia's system of parliamentary governance, and this legislation will preserve and strengthen that role. I commend the bill to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prosser Mr G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The package of bills presents a long overdue improvement and overhaul of the Audit Act 1901. The bills provide for greater scrutiny of government operations and businesses and for greater independence of the Auditor-General. The Australian people have a right to know that their money and interests are being adequately looked after by the Commonwealth. It is especially important when dealing with a government such as this one, which rules by grubby deals and bias. I take this opportunity to condemn the government for its handling of these bills as they come before this House.

PARA.TAB: It is ironic that the coalition, which represents many millions of people throughout the nation, could not get hold of a copy of the government's amendments after the government established its direction in regard to the bills. The government is wrapping itself in greater accountability, while at the same time deliberately seeking to reduce the effectiveness of parliament and its scrutiny of bills. This is representative of this government's complete disdain for the parliament and its effect on its representatives.
This government fears accountability. Evidence of the fear of accountability of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) is found in the

SPEECH.PARA: fact that he and his ministers decided to face parliament only twice in a sitting week to answer questions. This grubby little incident serves as a stark reminder of why these bills are so sorely needed. This government cannot even deal with these bills concerning open and honest government in an open and honest way.

PARA.TAB: The Financial Management and Accountability Bill provides stringent new requirements for the handling of Commonwealth funds. Its scope covers the underlying principles that are to govern the activities of persons in organisations that financially are agents of the Commonwealth. The fundamental principles of financial control contained in the Audit Act 1901 have been incorporated in these bills. This bill is intended to improve the quality and clarity of understanding of the Commonwealth financial management framework and to sharpen accountability for financial management performance. This, again, is entirely appropriate.

There should be strict controls over how taxpayers' finances are managed. It is a great pity, however, that the greater accountability requirements within the bill are not carried over into government policy. This is a government of mates for mates. The ordinary Australian rates a mention only once every three years when the Prime Minister promises the world and then reneges on those promises.

This government is typified by waste, shady deals and taxpayer funded buy-offs. There are numerous examples of these. One only has to recall the sports rorts affair, the maritime union buy-off, the Prime Minister's table, the Prime Minister's paintings, and the credit card controversy within the Lodge itself. Sadly, tight financial requirements will not always be prevalent in this government's case.

What will stop all this is a government with integrity which is in touch with the things that matter to ordinary Australians, not a government, such as the present one, which uses taxpayers' money to buy more and more true believers. It is for this reason that the coalition must always be on its guard against government attempts to restrict and limit parliamentary scrutiny. True to form, this government has sought to do just that.

I refer to the disallowance provisions for commercial funds. The standard provision for disallowance is 15 days. What does the government want to do? It wants to strip away parliament's oversight by taking the disallowance time down to just five days. What is the hurry? Is the government so badly organised that allowing parliament to have proper scrutiny would disrupt financial plans? Does the government view parliament with contempt and as something to be avoided? Surely, a Commonwealth entity which has need for commercial provisions can take account of parliament's sittings in its plans?

Call me old fashioned, but I like to think that parliament and its elected representatives should still figure in the minds of Commonwealth entities. Remember parliament? You are sitting in it! Parliament is the place that looks after the interests of ordinary Australians, those people who do not figure in the ALP's grandiose plans. At least one group still represents the cares of ordinary Australians, and that is the coalition.

In order to uphold the interests of ordinary Australians in this House, the coalition will be moving an amendment to standardise the disallowance provisions. The parliament must be given sufficient time to scrutinise instruments which will affect the lives of the people we represent. I certainly hope that the government will have enough integrity to change its mind and vote with us, but that would be running against form.

I turn now to the Commonwealth Authorities and Companies Bill. This bill will enhance part 11 of the Audit Act 1901, which currently provides standard financial provisions for public authorities and certain other bodies. It will also replace individual financial provisions contained in the enabling legislation of authorities not subject to part 11.

The Commonwealth Authorities and Companies Bill will provide a single set of core reporting and auditing requirements for directors of Commonwealth authorities and set out standards of conduct for executive officers. Many of these requirements are based on comparable Corporations Law as well as the best practice applying to individual authorities. The Auditor-General's mandate will be extended to all Commonwealth authorities and Commonwealth companies without exception, and this is how it should be.

The public has a right to expect that public businesses are following sound financial reporting. For too long there has been this hole in Commonwealth law. Commonwealth companies have been expected to act in a commercial sense or attain best practice but the auditing provisions have not been able to back this up. Of course, the best way to obtain best practice in government businesses is to expose them to competition from the private sector. Why should the taxpayer be sinking money into an enterprise which can most effectively be operated in the private sector?

Where a Commonwealth business can operate in the commercial marketplace to the benefit of the economy, it should be allowed to do so. The marketplace will impose far greater discipline with lower cost and at lower prices than any amount of government tinkering and social engineering. This has at last dawned on the government and so they have stolen the coalition's principles in this area as well, albeit only to the extent allowed by its ACTU masters. As usual, the ALP's rhetoric far outstrips its actions.

Modern financial management and accounting principles are an important support to the principles of greater commercial practice. It is a truism, however, that merely updating financial requirements will not force companies to act commercially. Where possible, government businesses must be allowed to take their chances in the marketplace if consumers and the nation are to get maximum benefit from the policy.

Typically, however, the Labor Party has also bastardised this principle for petty political reasons. I refer, of course, to the government's spineless response to the Maritime Union thuggery and intimidation. Rather than rule in the interest of the nation, the government acted to protect and pay off its mates. Of course, the Minister for Transport (Mr Brereton) the minister for backflips, was only too happy to dip into the taxpayers' purse so that his union mates could have more comfort in the workplace. So much for exposing businesses and their work practice to competition in the market. But it does not stop there.

The so-called privatisation program of the government is a farce. Privatisation is clearly the best way of exposing appropriate government business enterprises to full commercial reality. But this government could not sell heaters in the Arctic. On the Qantas float, it would be fair to say that the Minister for Finance, the honourable member for Swan (Mr Beazley), is having trouble getting the nose wheel down for the sale. In the sorry saga of ANL, while the government is throwing taxpayers' money around and desperately trying to come up with a sale, ANL's finances are dead in the water.

So it really is not good enough to simply put out new legislation on accounting requirements. This must be backed up by active policies to expose Commonwealth companies to commercial pressure and best practice. But given that the Keating government has completely dropped the ball on micro-economic reform, there is little chance of the hard decisions being made. It is the Auditor-General's bill where the government has again dropped the ball. To be effective, the Auditor-General must be truly independent and answerable to the parliament, not the executive. The executive must not be able to apply pressure—either implicit or explicit—to gain a more agreeable finding.

This bill improves the powers of the Auditor-General to gather information and ensure that taxpayers' interests are being looked after. It establishes the office of Auditor-General for the Commonwealth and sets the Auditor-General's functions. The Auditor-General will have new, stronger powers of entry and information gathering. The coalition fully endorses these new principles, but would prefer to put in place even stronger safeguards of the Auditor-General's independence. We believe in this because, unlike the government, the coalition has nothing to fear from an independent Auditor-General. The coalition believes that the people's representatives should have oversight of the Auditor-General.

While it is correct to increase the financial and functional independence of the Auditor-General by providing independent powers of spending within the appropriation, we must do more to ensure that the Auditor-General is an instrument of the parliament. The coalition is strongly of the view that oversight of the Auditor-General should be done by an Audit Committee of the Parliament by modifying the Joint Committee of Public Accounts. This committee will be a permanent feature of the parliament; it will not exist as a whim of the government.

Government business enterprises are an important sector of the economy. They are frequently an important input to the economy. For this reason, they must be functioning efficiently and effectively. To assist in this, the coalition feels that they should be open to the scrutiny of the Auditor-General and, through that office, the parliament. The coalition will be moving an amendment to allow the Auditor-General to conduct performance audits of public enterprises wherever desired if there is significant or complete government ownership.

The Auditor-General should not be constrained by ministerial veto or lower house votes. If the Auditor-General has concerns about the performance of a GBE, then the Auditor-General should rightly be able to investigate that matter. I cannot think why the government would oppose this. Perhaps greater scrutiny will help prevent more ANLs and taxpayer-funded buyouts.

TALK.START.PARA: —ANL—there's a reason.

—As my colleague quite rightly points out, ANL is a very good example of the point that we are making. But perhaps that is the problem. If I ran a business as badly as this government clearly runs its businesses, I would not want an independent auditor dropping in and looking over my shoulder. You never know what inefficient practices might be hiding under various rocks. The government will of course say that if it is a GBE then it is operating in a commercial environment and does not need an independent auditor doing inconvenient performance audits. However, one only has to mention the letters ANL to bring this argument undone.

PARA.TAB: If I were a Labor minister who had just been party to handing out millions to prop up the long-term failure of an enterprise, I would stay well clear of that argument. There is clearly a need for performance audits and we will be proposing amendments to the bill accordingly. We are aware, however, that some GBEs have private sector holdings. To this end, the Audit Committee will be able to prevent random audits if it is satisfied that there is sufficient private sector involvement to impose market discipline on poorly performing GBEs.

One of the most important tasks is the selection of the Auditor-General. There must be no hint of political patronage or subversion of responsibilities to the Australian people. For this reason, the representatives of the Australian people must have a say in who is selected. The coalition will be moving an amendment that the Leader of the Opposition and the Audit Committee of the Parliament must also give their approval in selection. I do not mean consult with the Leader of the Opposition and the Audit Committee; I mean approval must be sought. Consultation can be an exchange of letters, which can later be discarded. I am sure the government would not want this and it is just an oversight on its behalf, but we have to be sure. This approval will ensure that all appointments are sound and non-political, as they should be.

The Auditor-General performs a most serious responsibility—that of ensuring that the funds and agencies of the Australian people are properly managed and maintained. To this end, it is important that the Auditor-General be able to attract quality officers. For this reason, the coalition will be moving to allow the Auditor-General to have greater control over salaries and staff conditions. While the Auditor-General will have to heed the government's industrial relations policy, the Auditor-General should be able to offer competitive packages to attract and keep the best people. To an effective Auditor-General, the people themselves are the most important assets, and the Auditor-General must have the freedom to treat them accordingly.

I feel confident that the Australian people would wish to see a strong and effective Auditor-General so that the rorts can be dug out and exposed to scrutiny. It is this that the government runs from, like Dracula from light. With these bills it will once again be up to the coalition to finish the job. The government started but could not make the hard yards on the issues that matter to raise accountability to where it belongs. The coalition amendments will expose the shortfalls in this bill. As I mentioned previously in my address, the opposition will be moving a number of amendments to the Auditor-General Bill and the Financial Management and Accountability Bill.

There are a number of issues which the member for Forrest raised, and which presumably members of the opposition generally will take up, with which I would have some sympathy. PARA.TAB: The member for Forrest criticised the government in connection with what he referred to as the government's conduct with these bills, and he made reference to the government's trying to avoid accountability. The bills were the subject of very exhausting and exhaustive examination by that committee. The result was Report 331, which I think contains 39 recommendations—most of which have been adopted by the government.

TALK.START.PARA: —The important ones haven't been.

—I will be dealing with some of those which the member for Forrest refers to as the most important. PARA.TAB: Let me make it perfectly clear that I will not be embarrassed about voting with the government on this legislation. TALK.START.PARA: —You can change your mind from day to day.

—In view of that interjection, let me make this point: up until recent years, since 1901 when the Commonwealth was established, those people who have tended to monopolise national government in Australia, in the Commonwealth, have been members of the coalition. The Audit Act, which we are now in the process of replacing, was the fourth item of legislation enacted by the new Commonwealth government back in 1901. That legislation, which has undoubtedly had numerous amendments, has existed until now. It was this government which put into place not only this legislation but all of the processes which have led up to it.

PARA.TAB: We are too often amused by some of the absurd positions which are adopted by the opposition. I mentioned in passing that the legislation was first enacted in 1901. As I said, there have been many amendments. To a very large extent, those amendments have sought to respond to changing circumstances. But this is the first comprehensive, overall review leading to the complete restructuring of the government's audit legislation. It is a complete, new, comprehensive, more appropriate and contemporary approach to the whole question of financial accountability within the public sector.

The basic reason for this legislation is that the present act, that act which has persisted with amendments since 1901, has become increasingly less able to accommodate the needs and the realities of the modern public sector. This inadequacy was recognised in the 1989 report of the Public Accounts Committee on the Auditor-General. That report recommended that the act be repealed and replaced with legislation which was more in tune with present day realities, which was more effective in addressing their needs and which allowed greater flexibility in the financial management of public sector operations. The government accepted that recommendation. This legislation is the result.

The Public Accounts Committee, as I indicated, became involved as a result of the Minister for Finance referring the legislation to it on 29 June this year. On that same day, as a result of a motion in the Senate, the Public Accounts Committee had referred to it the question of the establishment of an audit committee. As a result of both of those references to the Public Accounts Committee we now have this very comprehensive report—report 331—of the Public Accounts Committee. The committee tabled its report on 22 September. The government has considered that report. This legislation represents a modification of the initial legislation as a result of many of those recommendations made by the Public Accounts Committee.

This package comprises three bills: the Financial Management and Accountability Bill, referred to generally now as the FMA Bill; the Commonwealth Authorities and Companies Bill, referred to more generally as the CAC Bill; and the Auditor-General Bill. The general construction of this legislation was referred to in some detail by the Minister for Finance in his second reading speech. But let me refer very briefly by way of background to the essence of this legislation. The FMA Bill, for example, establishes appropriate arrangements for financial management and accountability within Commonwealth agencies.

For the purpose of the legislation, Commonwealth agencies are those departments and statutory authorities whose enabling legislation does not give them legal ownership of money or property separate from the Commonwealth. Those Commonwealth authorities and companies which do legally own money or property on their own account are those which have been picked up in the CAC Bill. That legislation has been necessary in particular to draw together, to coordinate and to integrate all of the existing provisions which are scattered through diverse and disparate sources.

The legislation is designed to make consistent and explicit the accountability requirements for each type of Commonwealth entity. The Auditor-General Bill—and this is the legislation to which most attention is being given by the government and by way of amendments proposed by the opposition—is a very comprehensive piece of legislation. It not only establishes the offices of the Auditor-General and the Independent Auditor but also describes their powers and, as the minister indicated in his second reading speech, it establishes the Australian National Audit Office as a statutory authority to provide resources and support services to the Auditor-General in the carrying out of the responsibilities which he has.

It is interesting to note the comments the member for Forrest made about accountability and whether or not the government's conduct in relation to these bills has been adequate. During the inquiry which the Public Accounts Committee undertook it had occasion to deal with a letter written in response to an approach by the PAC to the Secretary to the Department of Prime Minister and Cabinet, Dr Keating. Dr Keating concluded his letter by saying:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . it is difficult to think of any Bills which have been subject to longer and more extensive consultation before being presented to the Parliament.

There is no way that the claims of the kind that the member for Forrest has made can, in any real sense, be substantiated. I will now refer to the background to the reference of those three bills to the Public Accounts Committee.

PARA.TAB: The Procedure Committee in its report entitled About time referred to old standing order 221 which permitted bills of the parliament to be referred to a select committee following their second reading. No bills had ever been referred under that provision, although the standing orders had been suspended on occasions to refer a bill to a joint select committee immediately following the minister's second reading speech. The Procedure Committee considered that a procedural mechanism to permit a bill to be referred to a standing committee needed to be provided formally in the standing orders and it made an appropriate recommendation.

That recommendation has been picked up in new standing order 217A. That particular provision provides a more effective mechanism by which legislation can be referred to committees. Since that special provision was made a number of bills have been referred to committees. For example, on 4 May a bill was referred to the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs, on 11 May a bill was referred to the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology, on 7 June a bill was referred to the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs, on 29 June this package of three bills was referred to the Joint Committee of Public Accounts and on 25 August the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Crean) referred the Employment Services Bill 1994 to the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs.

As a result, what we have done is introduce, where necessary and appropriate, a new process into the legislative continuum—the initiation of legislation, the preparation of legislation, the work of Parliamentary Counsel, the political party processes, cabinet consideration and so on. Another stage has been introduced as a result of these changes. I referred to this earlier when I said I welcomed and applauded the change. I think it has been a very desirable change. The effectiveness of that process is reflected not only in the very effective way in which the Public Accounts Committee gave consideration to these three bills but also in the quality of report which it brought down and now, the final stage in this process, the fact that the government has responded favourably to so many of the proposals.
That was an undertaking given by the Minister for Finance when he moved the motion to refer the legislation to the Public Accounts Committee. Referring to the three bills, he said:

SPEECH.PARA: These bills, like few others, will ultimately have an impact on the entire field of government activity, simply because almost every action of the government has a financial implication.

PARA.TAB: The JCPA was the body which initiated action to replace the Audit Act and the government believes that it should be the body to formally examine, in the first instance and on behalf of the parliament, the proposed outcome of this action.

SPEECH.PARA: He concluded with a statement which really underlines the sincerity with which the government adopted this process. The minister said:

PARA.TAB: As I have indicated, virtually by implication in the things that I have been saying, the government is not so proud of its authorship in this regard that it is going to take umbrage at getting additional advice from any sources and we look forward to the consultative processes yet in hand.

SPEECH.PARA: Of course, the way in which the government has responded to that report indicates that that was not an idle statement by the Minister for Finance. It is one which the Minister for Finance quite clearly has honoured by the way he has responded to that report.

PARA.TAB: I mentioned that the opposition was taking up some of the particular items of the Public Accounts Committee report in connection with what it had identified as some of the more important elements of the legislation. Certainly as far as the Auditor-General legislation was concerned, I would agree that they are some of the more significant. The particular recommendations from the Public Accounts Committee report that are picked up in these issues are recommendations 19 and 20, both of which are concerned with the capacity of the Auditor-General to conduct performance audits of GBEs.

The opposition proposes with its amendment to allow the Auditor-General to at any time conduct a performance audit of a Commonwealth authority or company. If that amendment were successful, the Auditor-General would then have unilateral power to decide whether or not those performance audits would be undertaken.

The provision the government has is that the performance audits be undertaken by the Auditor-General in two circumstances: first, if there is a request made by the responsible minister; or, second, if there is a resolution of both houses of parliament. I do not believe that is unduly restrictive. I do not think there would be any difficulty, in the case of a good relationship existing between the Minister for Finance and the Auditor-General, as there should be, with the Auditor-General, if he or she were to become aware of any inadequacies which would appear to justify a performance audit, having some discussion with the responsible minister in connection with any other government authority, agency or entity and seeking that request.

Let us be clear about this. If in a situation of that kind it became apparent to the Auditor-General that some sort of performance audit was necessary or desirable and a request was made to the minister for the request to go back to the Auditor-General, the minister would need good grounds to knock that back. The whole question of public accountability and public transparency in relation to issues of that kind indicates that any minister who sought to refuse a request of that kind would be very foolish indeed if the grounds for the request were clearly sufficient.

Recommendation 28 of the Public Accounts Committee report is concerned with the conditions under which staff of the audit office should be employed. The suggestion has been made—this has also been picked up by one of the proposed amendments of the opposition—that it should be withdrawn from the Public Service Act provisions and that the Auditor-General should have the power to negotiate the terms and conditions under which he or she employs staff.

That certainly would provide the Auditor-General with greater management flexibility. It would perhaps also provide the Auditor-General with the opportunity to attract and keep the necessary staff. I have not yet seen within the Auditor-General's office where this does not exist. I have never seen any significant deficiency in the operation of that office. It has an enormous and a very effective output.

Recommendation 33 concerns the appointment of the Auditor-General. The recommendation was that approval should be sought from the Leader of the Opposition or his or her representative, the Public Accounts Committee and the Audit Committee. The appointment of auditors-general has always been transparent. I have not noticed people making any claims in Australia that the appointments have been deficient. These are matters which can be revisited from time to time, but again I do not believe it is a matter of very great substance.

Recommendations 37 to 39 concern the question of a separate audit committee. The government has chosen to establish a separate audit committee rather than have those responsibilities absorbed by the Public Accounts Committee. (Time expired)

The chairman and the majority of members of the Public Accounts Committee are members of the Australian Labor Party. They all put their names to this report.

PARA.TAB: Today, the Minister for Finance came into the chamber and said that he wanted to disallow and ignore the report. He is heavy handed, heavy footed—and heavy headed at times because he does not appear to pay enough attention to the detail of his great portfolio. What have we seen here? The Department of Finance, through the Minister for Finance, has disagreed with the report of the Public Accounts Committee. I remind the House that the Department of Finance is responsible for the bookkeeping processes of the Commonwealth. The Auditor-General is an individual, and his position is as an individual attached to the parliament. He is a creature of the parliament.

We have roles as parliamentarians in this great liberal democracy that the member for Charlton referred to. He is prepared to deny his role as an elected member of parliament and bow down to the Department of Finance because it happens to disagree with the Auditor-General. I am shocked. The member would not put his name to a dissenting report. In this report, he agreed with every recommendation that the Public Accounts Committee came forward with.

The Australian Labor Party is prepared to back the Minister for Finance and the Department of Finance against the Auditor-General, which means denying the Auditor-General the capacity, given by this parliament, to do his job. After proper consideration, deliberation, taking of evidence and close discussion behind closed doors, the Public Accounts Committee arrived at certain decisions on behalf of the parliament, yet today the member came in and said, `No, that was all wrong. The Department of Finance is right.'

TALK.START.PARA: —A bipartisan approach.

—As my colleague interjects, there was a bipartisan approach. I can find no disagreement in this report, yet today those opposite are all coming into the House and saying, `We are going to disagree with this.' I just cannot understand it. This is not the process of the parliament that I thought we would see apply to the Public Accounts Committee. The Minister for Finance himself is a past member of the Public Accounts Committee. Surely he understands the role of the parliament here—or maybe he was present only in body and not in spirit at some of those meetings where I was the Deputy Chairman of the committee. I remember him being there in body—that is hard to avoid seeing—but I do not know whether he was there in mind and spirit. Today he seems to be changing the role of the parliament.
—He is ratting on the parliament.
—As my colleague says, he is ratting on the parliament.
—On the committee.

—And he is ratting on the committee whose recommendations he should uphold and endorse. Let us look at the detail of the way in which this works. An independent auditor is the only protection the parliament and the people of Australia have against the government departments doing the wrong thing. We are ultimately responsible for their actions. Our servant, the Auditor-General—an independent person—has the function of examining the accounts of all of these departments, and he should have that function.

PARA.TAB: How can we discharge our responsibility here in this parliament if the Auditor-General is not free of ministerial control? He reports to the parliament, goes to those great departments and examines not only whether their adding and subtracting are right but also whether the efficiency of their programs is right. We need to have that. In part, you are denying that process by going against a report that you yourself signed. An independent auditor is a great protection for the citizens of this nation against the abuse of government departments.

On many occasions members of the Public Accounts Committee have sat aghast as somebody appearing before the committee has explained a misinterpretation of the administration of public funds, and on occasion members of the Public Accounts Committee have disclosed the misallocation of funds to the point of fraud. The Public Accounts Committee and the Auditor-General are protections for the Australian people. We have stopped fraud, we have prevented the abuse of funds, and saved the taxpayers hundreds of millions of dollars in this process. I would have thought that you would see that today and say, `Yes, we really want to have a refinement of that independence of the auditor.' I would have thought that you would have endorsed the recommendations of your own report.

The other great truth of this process is that not only is the independence of the auditor critical but also we must have a process where ministers and departments are answerable to somebody. It is no good ministers just going into the cabinet room and being responsible to the Prime Minister. We as parliamentarians have a responsibility to our electors to see that ministers and their departments administer funds properly. The policy items and the political processes are a matter for debate—that is fair enough—but when it comes to the expenditure of public moneys and the way in which they are used ministers need to be squeaky clean and be answerable to the parliament.

On those two grounds, I think this is an important report and an important response. The government has failed to fully demonstrate its understanding of the need for an independent audit office and of the role of the Public Accounts Committee. If the Public Accounts Committee and the auditor are used properly, they are great tools for governments to be able to disclose misallocation of funds and inappropriate administration. It is a strengthening tool for government to be able to use the Auditor-General and the Public Accounts Committee. No minister should be ashamed of sending something off to the Auditor-General, because that enables the electorate to gain confidence that the right thing is being done. So I cannot understand why the minister is chary about pursuing the recommendations of the Public Accounts Committee.

I only have to give the House one recent example of the necessity of this process. In the last 24 hours we have had in the House two ministers trying to defend the administration of the Child Support Agency and the terrible mess and abuse that its examination by one of the parliamentary committees disclosed. Those ministers would be far better off saying: `Why not have the inquiry adopted by the parliament?' That is the way it should work. This is the tradition of the great Public Accounts Committee stretching back decades to Henry Bland, who founded it. It goes right back to that time. You are leaving a tradition that you should not walk away from.

The role of the Public Accounts Committee has been to work without dissent and you have presented a report without dissent. It is a great shame that you now choose to support the government's decisions in the way it has provided legislation. It is obvious that you do not agree with the government and that you do agree with your report, or you would not have signed it in the first place, but you are not prepared to say so and you are not prepared to vote so—

TALK.START.PARA: —Absolutely.
—I hear you saying now that you do agree with your report and you disagree with the government. Is that right?
—Of course I do.
—You cannot agree with both. Do you agree with the government and the report or do you just agree with the report?
—I agree with the report.

—With the report. The member upholds the report and therefore he should cross the floor. Why shouldn't he? It is a simple matter. Let me outline some of the problems that the member disclosed in his speech where he sought to say, `The committee is right but I am going to support the government.' Recommendation No. 33 of the committee says that before making a recommendation to the Governor-General the minister must seek the approval of the following: the Leader of the Opposition in the House of Representatives or his or her nominee, the Joint Committee of Public Accounts and an audit committee of the parliament. That is a reasonable thing. That sets that person in the confident position that he or she has the endorsement of the whole parliament, both sides of the House, and there is no political game playing.

PARA.TAB: That is a very sensible recommendation endorsed by all parties. It goes to the nub, the very reason, of why we have an independent auditor. Here we have carried it one step further so that the parliament can agree through the political processes to the name of that person. That is one of the processes the government has chosen to reject. Is it because there is a difference of opinion between Mr Taylor and the Minister for Finance, or the Department of Finance? Is it because the minister himself has decided that he does not want an independent auditor, that he wants to be able to put his finger upon the person who becomes the Auditor-General? Is that the reason why the minister will not agree to the committee's recommendations? Why has the minister chosen to ignore this recommendation?

TALK.START.PARA: —He is coming into the House.

—As a former member of the Public Accounts Committee he should understand the need for an independent auditor. If you have looked around Australia and seen some of the splendid work done by auditors in state governments where they have disclosed the shortcomings of Labor administrations and you do not want that to occur, tell us the reason why there cannot be agreement on the appointment of the Auditor-General because, once established, he is a great strengthening process, a great strengthening mechanism for the Minister for Finance and the whole administration of government.

PARA.TAB: Government members have claimed that they are open to the liberal democracy of the parliament. I encourage them to demonstrate that. `Open, liberal democracy' are the words the member used. I invite government members to put their money where their mouth is, to support their own report

TALK.START.PARA: —And cross the floor.

—And cross the floor. Finally, I believe the opposition's proposal is a strengthening of the committee's recommendation to ensure that the auditor has the right to conduct an audit of the government business instrumentalities at any time of his choosing. I have given the example of the Child Support Agency. Another example is the Australian National Line, where the Auditor-General ought to have the right to move in, select and take up an audit that he thinks needs doing on the efficiency of the operations of a government instrumentality. I notice that the Minister for Transport (Mr Brereton) has just come into the chamber. How could anyone rely upon him to send a reference to the auditor for the administration of the ANL, the CAA or any of those bodies that he is responsible for? He would never do it. The auditor ought to have the right to move in on the minister and say, `Laurie, you are blowing it. I am going to have a look at your stuff and see whether or not your agencies are doing the right thing.'

PARA.TAB: Debate (on motion by Mr Les Scott) adjourned.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Transport. Minister, did you read and initial on 28 July of this year a private briefing note from your department which stated that local residents and councillors to the north of Sydney airport were `substantially underestimating the expected increases in aircraft movements over their suburbs'? Did the same briefing note say that there would, in fact, be a fourfold increase in take-offs over suburbs to the north following the opening of the third runway at Sydney airport and a 140 per cent increase in overall traffic? Why did you conceal this from Marrickville councillors when you met them on that same day? Is it not a fact that when it comes to aircraft noise you have conned the people of Sydney?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Brereton The Hon L.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did meet with the Marrickville councillors late in July of this year and I informed them of exactly what I believed would be the impact of the opening of the third runway—that is, the parallel runway—at Kingsford Smith airport later on in the year. I indicated to them that it would have a very significant impact upon everyone in that flight corridor. Of course, I was well placed to make that observation to them.
—A fourfold increase?
—Indeed, I indicated to them in the clearest of terms that the increase would be in accordance with the environmental impact statement—
—A fourfold increase—you didn't say that, did you?

—That predicted a fourfold or more increase in traffic on the north-south axis. That is the reason why back in 1989 I was indicating that I thought it was far preferable to build at Badgerys Creek than to build the parallel runway. I was doing that at a time when the Leader of the National Party was leading the charge for the third runway.
—Absolutely.

—Between 1988 and 1989, the member for Hume put out not one, not two, not three, not four, not five, not six, not seven, not eight but nine separate press releases all calling for the parallel runway to be constructed and to be constructed immediately. Later in the debates today I am sure I will have ample opportunity to refer to some of the quotes contained in that material, but at this stage let me just recount to the Leader of the National Party what he had to say on 13 August 1991, way back then, in light of the environmental impact statement which I indicated to the Marrickville Council in the middle of this year would be consistent with what would occur when the runway opened. The Leader of the National Party said:

ANSWER.PARA: Any further delay in deciding on a third runway for Mascot could mean loss of life as well as economic insanity.
The Federal Government must make three decisions. Firstly, to accept the expert advice that the third runway is environmentally more friendly than the present two runway setup.
That is what he had said to say. This is based on the EIS. He also said:
. . . secondly, that safety is of paramount importance and finally that the vital tourist industry must no longer be choked off through lack of sensible economic thinking.

I can agree with you about No. 2 and about No. 3, but you have quickly forgotten about No. 2 in your call in recent days for the reopening of the east-west runway. You are aware, as I am aware, that the Civil Aviation Authority has said that, on the strongest of safety considerations, it should not operate across parallel runways and to do so will compromise safety.

PARA.TAB: At the time I was raising concerns about the parallel runway development, every one of you sitting opposite was leading the cry of the banshees. The lot of you; every last one of you. There it is there! This is bigger than Acme Fightback. This just happens to be all of the press releases issued by you lot during the period from 1988 through to 1991. There are press releases from the honourable member for Bennelong, Mr Howard, the nine that I referred to from Mr Sharp, and some terrific press releases from the Leader of the National Party. There is a whole heap from the member for Fadden, Mr Jull. The right honourable member for New England got into the act; he could not stay away from it. And there are some from Senator Brownhill. Mr Blunt himself put out nine separate press releases all saying, `Build it. Build it now and damn the concerns.'

TALK.START.PARA: —And you did! You did!
—The member for Gippsland is a bit excited this afternoon.
—Mr Fife, Mr Moore and Mr Cobb all get a big mention in that folder, but we will have a chance to discuss that later on this afternoon.

—Mr Speaker, I rise on a point of order. We do appreciate the accolades being given to us by the Minister for Transport, but I point out that the question did relate to why the minister concealed this from Marrickville councillors when he met them that day. Would the minister please come back to the question.
—The minister is responding to the question. I think, in conclusion, as he has indicated, this is a subject for some discussion this afternoon.
—Yes, indeed. On that note I might finish this answer. Thank you, Mr Speaker.

—Has the Minister for Finance seen reports of comments by Mr Bolitho, the former chairman of ANL, and the member for Hume concerning the Auditor-General's report on ANL? Does the minister accept their claims on the findings of the Auditor-General?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Bolitho's current comments are largely a rehash of his media statements of 16 September. The variation being that he invokes the Auditor-General's report, tabled on Monday, as supporting his position. It does no such thing, as even the most perfunctory reading of the report would make clear.

PARA.TAB: With regard to valuations of ANL, which was the central matter in Mr Bolitho's statements, the report makes clear the different bases for the various figures that have been bandied about. The report clearly states that the financial statements, such as ANL's 1992-93 accounts, do not purport to be a valuation of the company and the amount shown as equity does not purport to be an indication of the net value of the entity.

The key finding of the report is that `there is no necessary inconsistency between the audited 1992-93 financial statements and the August 1994 Price Waterhouse-Salomon Brothers report', which hardly supports Mr Bolitho's views. Mr Bolitho has also artificially set ANAO's confirmation that ANL was a going concern for the purpose of its 1992-93 accounts against the negative valuation put on it by Price Waterhouse-Salomon Brothers.

That misses these very important points. The ANAO states that financial statements prepared on a going concern basis do not purport to be the actual value of the entity at that point in time, even as a going concern. The audit office assessment of a going concern was largely predicated on an undrawn credit facility of $75 million, which was underpinned by a perception of government support: that is, government ownership was crucial in the positive book value of ANL.

The Price Waterhouse-Salomon Brothers had a very different starting point. They started from the premise that the government wished to sell a substantial part of ANL. Based on their extensive consideration of a number of factors, including ANL's operating environment, poor operating performance and forecasts, they took the view that even if the government resumed a net debt of $180 million of ANL, as would most likely be required by any prospective purchaser, a partial or total trade sale or flotation of ANL was not viable in view of the fact that, even without financing costs, ANL's prospects were bleak.

While favouring an informal liquidation, they canvassed other options such as retention, which they deemed likely to involve major expense on the government's part, and restructuring with a view to a future trade sale as well as suggesting that further study be undertaken.
