In effect, the government assigned the task of further study to the current ANL board, whose task it is to restructure ANL as a viable entity. I note in passing that the shadow minister for transport said on AM this morning:

ANSWER.PARA: The head of the Department of Finance asked the Auditor-General to water down the criticisms the Auditor-General was making about the way this whole business of the sale of ANL has been handled.

He went on to refer to `very serious accusations being made by the Auditor-General himself'. There have also been other references by journalists to criticisms in the report of the actions of public officials.

PARA.TAB: In fact, there are no criticisms or accusations, serious or otherwise, made by the Auditor-General in his report at all. This is the very point which the Secretary to Finance took up with the Auditor-General in his letter to him of last Friday evening. The fact that the general observations of principle, made by the Auditor-General in his report, have been misconstrued amply demonstrates the basis of the concern of the Secretary to Finance.

For the record, I have no basis on which to question the discretion of public officials who advised the government on this matter. Ill-informed commentary to the contrary is neither fair to the officials nor a productive way to further the debate.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed, again, to the Minister for Transport. Why did the government open the third runway ahead of the completion of the new control tower and radar systems, when to do so would result in a reduction of capacity and create unnecessary additional noise over large sections of Sydney? Will the minister admit that this has led to one airline alone—that is, Ansett—receiving 30,000 complaints about delays in a single day, with 91 per cent of its flights through Sydney being delayed? Will he admit that his decision has reduced the capacity of Mascot from 64 movements per hour to 50 movements per hour, while at the same time increasing aircraft noise to intolerable levels for those under the flight paths? Will the minister finally be honest with affected residents and the travelling public and accept his responsibility for this total fiasco?

—The impact of noise at Kingsford Smith airport is very sadly, I must say, consistent with the environmental impact study that was carried out, to which the Prime Minister referred in this House earlier this week, which indicated that, whilst 182,000 people were formerly affected by moderate or severe noise nuisance, under the new arrangements the number of 95,000 is much lower. That said, the fact is that one must feel very intensely for the 95,000 or so people who are at the moment experiencing the impact of the construction of the parallel runway. It is for that reason that cabinet will be considering, in the next day or so, a range of measures to tackle the question of alleviating this nuisance.

PARA.TAB: It may be appropriate if I indicate to the House the sequence of events in respect of the timing of the opening of the parallel runway. On 1 February, which was right at the very start of my time as Minister for Transport, I wrote to the Chairman of the Civil Aviation Authority seeking advice on the best means to further improve safety at Sydney airport. I did so, against the backdrop of real concerns that had been expressed about the simops arrangements at Kingsford Smith—that is, the simultaneous take-offs and landings arrangements—which, of course, from a safety point of view, are not as optimum as parallel runways. That letter was prompted by concerns that had been put to me about the relative safety of simultaneous runway operations being used at that time in comparison with other possible methods of operating the airport. The Civil Aviation Authority wrote back to me on 15 February proposing a phased introduction of operations on the new parallel runway system to take advantage of the expected early completion of the new runway by the Federal Airports Corporation.

In that advice to me on 15 February, the Civil Aviation Authority advised that operations could commence as early as September 1994, which is when it anticipated the new runway would be completed, by controlling traffic from the existing control tower, although there would be an initial slight fall in peak hour capacity. With the use of parallel runways, Sydney airport no longer requires the extensive use of simultaneous runway operations. Therefore, an already safe airport becomes that much safer.

That was the backdrop to the timing of the opening. On the interim basis of the runway, the operations have very little impact as far as noise nuisance is concerned for the most affected people—the residents living in the corridor to the north of the airport—who are bearing the burden of the increased traffic. They bear that burden because, in the last month since operations commenced, some 30 plus per cent of take-offs have been to the north as a result of prevailing winds.

When the wind blows at more than five knots apparent north, for safety considerations, planes need to take-off into that wind. Some planes can handle it better than others, but the fact is that the airport has to revert to northern take-offs to suit some classes of planes, and that of necessity means that all planes have to take-off to the north in those circumstances. That has resulted in a very real impact.

That is no different from the impact that will exist when the new tower opens in February or March next year. In respect of the new parallel runway, there are no take-offs to the north under the environmental impact statement. We are now seeing take-offs to the north, which is a noise nuisance factor of about double that of landings, principally brought on by the wind considerations at Kingsford Smith. That will not change at all.

That somehow people are being exposed to greater noise nuisance than they should as a result of the airport being opened before the control tower is a total furphy. The fact is that a lot of planes have deviated from the flight paths in the last month. Lots of concerns have been very gravely expressed about the number of take-offs to the north, which is the very issue that cabinet will be addressing in the next day or so.

TALK.START.PARA: —Will the full length of the east-west runway be available?

—The Leader of the National Party asks whether the full length of the east-west runway will be available. Let me make it very clear to him and to the House that the east-west runway is available for those situations when there is too much cross-wind to operate the parallel runways. That is the case now, and will continue to be the case in the future. Let us be quite clear about that.

PARA.TAB: On the first five days of operations of the new airport arrangements after the parallel runway was opened, because of exceptional westerly winds which prevailed in Sydney and, indeed, right across New South Wales at that time, the east-west runway was used exclusively. For those first five days, the burden of noise was overwhelmingly carried by people in the east-west corridor. That will be the case whenever that runway is required for operational reasons.

Having said that, it needs to be understood that in those circumstances only one runway is being operated, and operating one runway drops the capacity of the airport down to 30 to 40 take-offs and landings per hour. The big problem facing Kingsford Smith airport at the moment is the tremendous expansion in demand for its services during the peak periods.

It has been stated by the Civil Aviation Authority that, between February and November this year, the demand for take-offs and landings at Kingsford Smith airport during the peak hours on the peak days has gone up by 50 per cent. With that unbridled demand in the peak hours on the peak days, the whole of the additional capacity at Kingsford Smith will readily be swamped. Indeed, there will be very extensive queuing and circling when the east-west runway is the only runway available as a result of safety considerations brought on by wind factors.

For all of these reasons, the parallel runway at Kingsford Smith, as a result of the opening of which we have already seen volumes return almost to those of previous operations—that is, it is back up to over 61 take-offs and landings per hour—is operating satisfactorily and safely, but we need to, and we intend to, very seriously tackle this issue of noise nuisance, which is the subject of such grave concern for all people living under the flight corridor.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Employment, Education and Training. What progress is being made in implementing the training wage?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Crean The Hon S.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Paterson for his question. Indeed, very good progress has been made. Today I have been informed that next week South Australia will move to fast-track award by award the training wage in that state. The House would be aware that, under the federal system, the national training wage was ratified by the federal commission as far back as 4 September. But what has been required is a mirroring of it in the states. With the South Australian operation in place, we will have effectively mirrored it in the states of South Australia, Victoria, New South Wales and Queensland. Tasmania has also legislated to give effect to it. This leaves Western Australia alone in not taking steps to secure the wage.

PARA.TAB: The training wage that we have introduced is not the cut-price, punitive, training-in-name-only wage that was proposed by the opposition at the last election. This is a genuinely award based rate. It is linked to a national training framework. It is industry responsive and supported by industry. I also remind the House that, whatever uncertainty people might think surrounds wages in the current environment, there is no uncertainty under the training wage because these rates have been set for 12 months. Anyone taken on under a traineeship arrangement incorporating the training wage is exempt from the unfair dismissal provisions of the IR act.

As important as this progress has been, it is not the training wage alone that will help us secure the new training places. We have announced other measures, including funding for new traineeships, secured agreement from the states for a vocational training system and significant new funding to the vocational education and training sector. Today I spoke with the ACTU's regular council meeting and received from that meeting—

TALK.START.PARA: —That must have been revealing.

—It was very revealing because we received from that meeting a commitment to 37,000 new traineeships that the ACTU will get out and support the marketing of. That is on top of what is already happening in the system at the moment. If those opposite have any doubts, I remind them of what the Australian Chamber of Manufactures had to say earlier this week. Allan Handberg, the chief executive of that association, said:

ANSWER.PARA: . . . job opportunities in manufacturing for school and tertiary leavers are the strongest since the 1980s.
. . . apprenticeship and traineeship intakes have been building up steadily throughout the year and the trend is expected to continue.
Trade training opportunities are becoming available right across the board.
Some companies in the automotive sector, for example, are planning to double or treble intakes during the period ahead.

Not only is this commitment a recognition and an endorsement by the employers and the ACTU; it also builds on what is already happening. I simply say to the House that it is only this government that could secure such a partnership of commitment because it is prepared to deal sensibly with both sides of the industrial fence and to secure agreements that commit and that work. I am confident that with this new commitment today we will see important continuing progress being made in the coming year in getting the level of unemployment down.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Transport. Is it true that the original chief deceiver of the people of Sydney over the Sydney airport is the Prime Minister? Is it true that the Prime Minister was the great advocate of changing the original third runway plan, which would have meant more aircraft flying over water instead of over people's homes? Is it a fact that the Prime Minister is responsible for the lifestyle-destroying aircraft noise levels over suburbs to the north of Sydney airport? Is it true that, while the Prime Minister's stupidity caused the noise problem, your deception and incompetence have caused the anger and chaos, and that both of you are to blame?

—We have heard it all now. For the people who never stopped baying for this development, the people who chopped down a forest of trees to put out literally thousands of press releases to see this runway built to come along now, in 1994, and say that this is all the current Prime Minister's fault is really to stretch everyone's credulity.
—But you built it. You did!
—Order! The member for Gippsland will control himself.
—Who built this airport?
—The fact is that, whilst this debate was raging, there were many in our party who felt that it was better to do Badgerys Creek first, and I was one of those.
—Is that still your view?
—Order!
—Having said that—
—So, if you don't agree with the decision, why don't you resign?
—whilst there was some diversity on our side of politics—
—Punch resigned; why don't you? You fraud.
—Order! Those on my left will cease interjecting.

—the fact is that the opposition was absolutely unanimous in wanting it built and wanting it built immediately. Indeed, you said so a thousand days in a thousand ways. You called for it to be built regardless of the environmental consequences.
—Now answer to the question. Come on.
—Order! The member for Flinders!

—Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order under the standing order relating to relevance. My question was whether it was the Prime Minister who was responsible for changing the original third runway plan—

PARA.TAB: Government members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order!
—You cannot run the opposition. Don't try to run the House.
—Order! Those on my right.

—the change having led to aircraft take-offs and landings over the suburbs to the north of Sydney airport. The minister is not even beginning to answer that question. It is not a question of what press releases people put out; it is a question of what the Prime Minister did.

PARA.TAB: Government members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Resume your seat. Those on my right! The Leader of the Opposition has raised a valid point of order. The minister is coming to the response.

—The opposition asked about the position of the Prime Minister. I think everyone has known about the position of the Prime Minister, which was no different from your position in saying that it should be built—
—The Prime Minister is the one who changed this.
—Order! The Leader of the Opposition will not continue to interject across the table.

—in accordance with the environmental impact statement. That was his position. The environmental impact statement said it all in 1991. It said exactly what the impact would be. Today, you come long crying crocodile tears for those people who are worse off. The concern that is being felt in that area is one that the government will address. It will address it very seriously with the assistance of the Prime Minister himself.
—He is responsible for it.

—He, like all of us, wants to see that gateway to Australia, the airport that carries more than 50 per cent of all of the air traffic throughout the whole of Australia, continue to serve the economic interests of this state, but, at the same time, to see adequate protection for the people who suffer the noise nuisance.
—He didn't worry about this in 1989.

—That will be some support which I will be looking for and which I very much expect to have when the matter is addressed in cabinet discussions tomorrow. It seems to me that, without that sort of support—which means bringing forward our programs and tackling noise with the various measures that have been suggested—we will not be minimising the impact of what is a very necessary piece of infrastructure, that is, Kingsford Smith airport.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Development Cooperation and Pacific Island Affairs. I refer to press reports concerning discussions with Papua New Guinea on the Australian aid program. What progress, if any, has been made on that subject?

—I thank the honourable member for her question. It is the case, as members will know, that each year there is a range of discussions between Papua New Guinean and Australian ministers, generally involving half a dozen ministers from each side, alternately in Papua New Guinea and in Australia. That annual PNG-Australia Ministerial Forum took place in Melbourne last Thursday and Friday. Among the wide range of matters discussed was the future of our aid program. That is a very important strand of our relationship with PNG and, given the crucial economic problems—I think it is fair to describe them in that way—PNG is facing, it was a very timely discussion.

PARA.TAB: We on the Australian side take the view that, in view of the fiscal and foreign exchange problems PNG is facing, which have led to the floating of the currency in PNG, amongst other things, there is simply no alternative to the PNG government negotiating and, importantly, then implementing a reform package with the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank. We think that should take place as soon as possible. Indeed, during those meetings we had assurances that the discussions with the World Bank would continue in January.

In that context, an international support package is being talked about, but the figure—I see there were some references in the reports, which the honourable member referred to, to a figure—is still something that needs to be assessed. We made the point very firmly that any Australian support for an economic reform package to Papua New Guinea is dependent on Papua New Guinea negotiating a satisfactory agreement with the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank and, as well as that, on Papua New Guinea itself undertaking significant economic reforms. Two of those reforms are improving its own collection of revenue and increasing public investment from its budget. I emphasise that Australia's participation in that package would be most unlikely to involve any new or additional aid to Papua New Guinea, over and above the amounts which we are committed to supplying under the treaty.

As far as our current aid program to Papua New Guinea is concerned, things are going well. Our budget support is being progressively replaced with much needed public investment programs, particularly in the areas nominated by Papua New Guinea of infrastructure, health and education. We also agreed during the discussions with Papua New Guinea that there would be full transparency in how those aid programs were progressing and that we would find ways of increasing the flow of public information. It was agreed that the review of the treaty of development cooperation, due to be conducted in September 1995, would proceed and that that review would consider matters including Papua New Guinea's economic situation, the implications of the World Bank-International Monetary Fund adjustment programs and progress in implementing Australia's programmed aid. It was also agreed that planning for the review would commence shortly and that a working group would start meeting by April.

In the context of the discussions, I was happy to be able to announce an $11 million project to assist sustainable forestry in Papua New Guinea, a matter of some concern in Australia as well. The project will improve education of forestry personnel and assist Papua New Guinea in the monitoring of logging activities. In announcing that, I urged Papua New Guinea to ensure that appropriate sustainable forest policies were implemented in line with the outcomes of the South Pacific Forum meeting in Brisbane. One move in that context would be to increase the level of export taxes on logs to improve the returns of logging to Papua New Guinea.

Finally, I was able to present Papua New Guinea ministers with a report prepared by AIDAB on the damage to public infrastructure following the volcanic eruptions in Rabaul. That information will help them make the necessary decisions on the restoration or relocation of facilities in East New Britain and I believe it will be most valuable in that context.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Transport. Why is the CAA refusing to answer questions about Sydney airport and its flight paths? Despite the minister's promise to release details of standard flight paths last week, why has the CAA still not released information about flight paths or other operations at Mascot? Has the minister instructed the CAA to withhold information from the public, local councils and the media? Is this, with his own black-ban on the Sydney Morning Herald, yet another confirmation of the government's deception of the public over the third runway?

—In respect of the first part of the honourable member's question, he will have to ask the CAA. In respect of the second part of his question, those standard flight paths will be made available just as soon as I have taken them to the cabinet and we have been in a position to consider them and the range of other measures necessary to improve the position of those living in the north-south corridor who are currently experiencing very severe noise nuisance as a result of the airport's operations.

—My question, which is addressed to the Minister for Social Security, concerns the final report of the strategic review of the pensions income and assets test released earlier this week. Is the minister aware of criticisms of the report for rejecting the option of a so-called universal age pension? Does the government agree with the report's recommendations in this area? Do any of the criticisms that have been levied have any validity at all?

—I thank the honourable member for his question. On Monday this week I, on behalf of the government, received the report on the review of the pensions income and assets test conducted by the independent consultant Ageing Agendas, which has worked on this matter over a considerable period together with a very broadly representative reference group of retiree organisations, the finance industry and relevant government departments.

PARA.TAB: I think its report was a good, solid piece of work, which flowed out of a thorough consultation process, and it was very comprehensive in its review of the issues. It has put forward some 50 recommendations that will be considered in a budget context, and we will be developing a considered response to the report next year in that context. There is one recommendation in the report that, I can indicate, the government will be accepting now, and that is that the government maintain a targeted approach to pension provision. The alternative to that, which has been espoused by some, is the so-called universal pension, which in effect means paying pensions to everybody, irrespective of any assets or income test; in other words, completely removing any means testing.

As anybody who is remotely honest concedes, the reality is that that is simply unaffordable. We are talking about a cost of some $5 billion a year arising from removing all income and assets testing on pensions. It is also inequitable, and this has been confirmed in a study of the proposals by the retirement income modelling task force, which is a group of officials from Treasury, Finance and Social Security. Not only is it unaffordable; it is inequitable in its impact.

Contrary to the claims of the member for Berowra, proposals in this area were properly considered by the review. Just because a proposal is rejected does not mean that it was not properly considered. The honourable member for Berowra tries to have two-bob each way. A press release put out on the day said that he has an open mind on universal pension, saying that he will `continue to examine any proposals for a universal pension'. What profound dishonesty that is! This is the party that persistently criticises us for not making enough progress in cutting the deficit yet it criticises any suggestion that taxes might rise or that a government might increase its revenue. This is the party that says it has an open mind on a proposition that would have an annual budgetary impact of $5 billion. This is the sort of dishonesty that we get.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. For the minister to accuse me of dishonesty—
—Just a minute.
—It is a point of order, Mr Speaker.
—Yes, and when you get the call you may certainly proceed. The honourable member for Berowra.

—Mr Speaker, my point of order is in relation to the manner in which the minister raises comments about the efficacy of comments in terms of dishonesty when he misrepresents and does not quote fully from the statement I put out. He should not use the term `dishonest' in relation to me in this matter when I clearly said that we recognise the inherent difficulty in introducing a universal pension.
—Order! Now you are debating the issue. Resume your seat.
—Mr Speaker, on the point of order, there is ample opportunity for positions on misrepresentation to be made after question time, as every member knows. It is not a point of order.

—Order! I again remind all members in this place—that equally goes to ministers—that they should be careful of the language that they use. I say to the member for Berowra that there are other opportunities in this House, if he believes that he has been misrepresented, to try to correct that record. I call the minister.
—I might take them.
—It is patently, obviously untenable—
—Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. Under standing order 75, no member shall use offensive words.
—I have already ruled on the matter. Resume your seat.
—The minister has accused the member for Berowra of dishonesty—

—Resume your seat! I warn the member for Warringah. This is the second time this week when he has stood up after a ruling has been given in respect of points of order taken and he has chosen to argue the toss.

—It is patently untenable to be saying, on the one hand, that the government needs to do far more to cut the deficit, that the government needs to not raise any revenue or increase taxes in any way, shape or form and then, on the other hand, to say that you are seriously considering a proposition with a budgetary cost of some $5 billion.

PARA.TAB: There has been some reference to a proposal by the Institute of Actuaries. That proposal has been looked at by the retirement income modelling task force that I made reference to earlier. The institute attempts to fund the proposal by cutting the base rate of pension by $7—is that what the honourable member for Berowra proposes?—by freezing the superannuation guarantee charge; by more rapidly increasing the pension age for women, with further increases for both men and women in future; and by changing superannuation tax concessions. RIM suggests that by 2003 around $3 billion of national savings would be lost each year as a consequence of doing that.

The honourable member for Berowra also referred in his press release to the possibility of taxing the pension benefit which, as far as I can see, can only mean abolishing the pension rebate, the effect of which would be a cut of $11.40 per week for single pensioners. These are the sorts of things that you have to do to make a universal pension cost-effective, to use the honourable member for Berowra's terms. He knows full well that there is not the slightest chance in the world that a government of which he was a member would introduce such an arrangement. There is not the slightest possibility of that, and he knows it. He ought not to be dragging these sorts of propositions before the electorate in what I say is this thoroughly dishonest way. He knows that what he is putting forward cannot be done. It is just an absolute joke for a party that professes concern for fiscal rectitude to put forward—

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. Under standing order 75, no member shall use offensive words. The minister has again accused the member for Berowra of being dishonest. I find that offensive, and he should withdraw.

—Order! Resume your seat. If the member for Warringah had listened to some of the comments that have been made here even this afternoon, he might have similarly found that other people found words offensive. I have already said—
—The member for Banks might just consider his position.

PARA.TAB: Opposition members—Name him!

TALK.START.PARA: —I got thrown out for that!
—Order!
—I got thrown out for interjecting on you.
—Order! Thank you for reminding me. As I was saying, members should consider carefully the language of their responses in this place. I believe the minister has finished.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Fischer Mr T.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Transport. The minister will be aware of comments by the Auditor-General in relation to ANL and other matters that:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . the actions and statements of those involved in the sale process can influence the perceptions of the market to the point where the seller will be perceived as a distressed seller.

Further, the minister will also be aware of allegations raised by the former chairman of ANL on last night's 7.30 Report that the minister's comment that ANL could not be given away `would damage ANL and its sale value'. In view of these statements, will the minister accept responsibility for his bungled handling of ANL's sale, costing the taxpayer tens of millions of dollars? If not, will he agree to establish a full, open and independent inquiry into the events surrounding this matter?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Brereton The Hon L.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Have no fear. I will take full responsibility for ANL during the whole of my stewardship of it. I am proud of the fact that the very first thing I did in respect of ANL, in March of this year, in concert with the Minister for Finance, was recommend to cabinet that there should be an independent due diligence study done of the affairs of ANL. I did it against the background of a very dismal financial performance by the corporation. It is a corporation that seemed to get it wrong year after year.
—You had it for 12 years, for heaven's sake.
—The member for Gippsland is getting very excited. The member for Gippsland!
—Look what you did to it!
—Order!

—We got it in dreadful shape. This is an outfit that said in 1991 that it would make a profit of $32 million and actually made a loss of $5.3 million. It is an outfit that said it would make a profit in 1992 of $21.4 million and actually made a loss of $26 million. It said it would make a profit in 1993 of $14.8 million and made a profit of $2.7 million. In 1994 it said it would make a profit of $7.9 million and it actually has come in with an estimated resultant loss—we will not have of confirmation of it—of between $10 and $20 million.

PARA.TAB: If you look at ANL's performance, over the last four years it has lost on average some $24 million each year. It was for that reason that the government commissioned due diligence. It was for that reason that when the due diligence report, duly carried out by Price Waterhouse and Salomon Brothers, was presented to the cabinet, the cabinet made a very important decision, and that was to request that I approach the directors of ANL and seek their resignations with a view to the installation of a new board in an attempt to rescue the company.

The day when I made my comment that you could not give it away—which was a pretty fair representation of the state of the outfit—was a day when I indicated that the government had decided to withdraw it from sale. So all this talk about its sale value being talked down is just so much nonsense. The very day I made that remark was the day it was withdrawn from sale.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, but you are going to put it on the market soon.
—Order! I warn the member for Gippsland.

—I have been reticent to criticise the former chairman of ANL. I want to differentiate between his position and that of a number of directors of ANL who only joined the board of ANL shortly before the board was changed. I do not hold them responsible for any of the woes of that company, but when an outfit that so consistently gets it wrong year in and year out, that says it is going to do X and it does Y and it comes at an enormous cost to the taxpayer, then the minister who does something about it ought to quite properly be pleased that the issue has been tackled. I noticed in the program last night Mr Bolitho saying that not only should we have rescued ANL but we should have moved from 25 per cent shareholding in Australian Stevedores to 100 per cent shareholding in Australian Stevedores.
—You were the one who wanted to buy the shares.
—I will come to you in a minute.
—Order! The member for Ryan might not bait the minister.

—This is the biggest stevedoring outfit in Australia. It is an outfit in which ANL has a 25 per cent shareholding. It was Mr Bolitho's wish that the government under deadlock-breaking provisions which he had negotiated with the other two shareholders, Howard Smith and Jamieson Equities, Mr Corrigan's outfit, should proceed to go from 25 per cent to 100 per cent ownership. That was, as I characterised in this House, a $280 million ask because, firstly, you had to buy Howard Smith for $28 million using your pre-emptive rights, then you had to be prepared to go into the auction with Corrigan and buy him out for at least the same amount of money, and then you had to take on the whole capital expenditure program that is in their three-year business plan. And on top of all of that you had one other responsibility, which was to assume the debt of Australian Stevedores.

PARA.TAB: The end result of that was $280 million of further taxpayer commitment to Australian Stevedores. What for? So that we, the government, could nationalise and run the biggest, greatest stevedoring company in Australia. I think the cabinet made a very sound decision. It was not my decision; it was a decision finally taken by a subcommittee of cabinet comprising the Prime Minister, the Treasurer, the Minister for Finance and me. If I was enthusiastic to clean up ANL's problems, that was nothing compared to the enthusiasm of the other participants on that cabinet subcommittee; but clean it up we will and cleaning it up is exactly what we are doing at this moment.

It was suggested on the program last night that there was a five-day maritime strike—a strike brought about by the government's decision to sell its 25 per cent shareholding in Australian Stevedores. We either had to buy for $280 million or sell our quarter share. Let me remind the House—because these little urban myths have a habit of being perpetuated by one or other of the players in this—that the five-day maritime dispute came about as a result of the unions attempting to force the government to commit the taxpayer for the $280 million. The government, to its credit, said that it would not be forced to follow that course of action. Instead, the strike commenced at noon on the Thursday and on the Friday afternoon we disposed of our 25 per cent.

TALK.START.PARA: —And you went sailing.

—Actually I went to John Newman's funeral in Sydney, if you would like to know what I was doing that afternoon. We made the sound decision on behalf of the taxpayer because we managed to obtain the same price as Howard Smith managed to obtain—$28 million. Howard Smith is a reputable public company and one that acts pretty responsibly. If we had not taken that action and Howard Smith had moved to sell, as it was doing the following week, to Jamison, as a 75 per cent owner it would have been in a position to greatly devalue this government's 25 per cent. We may not have got anything like $28 million.

PARA.TAB: In conclusion, what was going on in the opposition while all this was happening? We had two statements on the one day. We had the shadow minister for privatisation and public administration, the member for Ryan, saying this to me:

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister must face the fact that under public ownership, ANL does not have access to the capital necessary to provide for a successful reconstruction and for ANL to return to long-term profitability. The minister should accept the recommendation of the due diligence report for a Managed Trade-Down of ANL Limited (effectively an informal liquidation).
The member for Ryan was saying that we should liquidate. At the very same moment, the shadow minister for transport was putting out an entirely different press release saying:
Only majority privatisation—
not liquidation—

and the most effective would be full privatisation—will attract substantial new funding and the solid customer base and broader management expertise that the line needs if it is to become fully competitive and able to capture the opportunities that expanding trade could offer.

If ever I have seen someone, to his discredit, captured by the industry and blundering down the path that would see the government accepting further losses, it was certainly not the member for Ryan but was certainly the member for Hume.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs. The minister would have seen media reports stating the government's intention to install Anzac Day on 25 April as Australia's national day of commemoration to recognise this country's war dead and all those who served in war. Due to the significance of next year as the 50th anniversary of the end of the Second World War, could the minister inform the House whether the government's intention will be carried out prior to Anzac Day 1995?

—I thank the honourable member for his question. Naturally, most Australians attach a very solemn importance to Anzac Day. Some time ago in this House the member for Melbourne Ports, Mr Holding, and the member for Cook, Mr Dobie, in a bipartisan approach brought a private members motion to this House in which they asked exactly for this. The ex-service community has for some time been concerned that, as time goes on, the importance of Anzac Day could be diminished, with younger generations coming up who may not be aware of the debts that are owed to those people who have fought not only in World War I or World War II but also in other wartime conflicts.

PARA.TAB: Accordingly, the government tomorrow will be introducing a bill in this House to enshrine Anzac Day in legislation as the day of commemoration, and we will provide that 25 April of each year be known as Anzac Day. I want to thank all members of this House because I am certain that the legislation will be accepted—the honourable member for O'Connor publicly said that he would accept it. I am sure that it will be passed, and I have every confidence in ensuring that it will be passed in time for Anzac Day 1995, which will mark the 50th anniversary of the end of World War II.

In conclusion, I take this opportunity—it will probably be my last opportunity to do so this year—to thank all our colleagues from both sides of the House for the marvellous work that they are doing in their electorates with respect to the Australia Remembers year. I know it is going to be great. It has been taken up with a great deal of gusto by all Australians and I expect that the celebrations and commemorations next year will be something to behold.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Moore The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Transport. Now that the minister has confirmed that he views the ANL as a basket case, it is worth reminding the House of a quote of his:

QUESTION.PARA: Let me tell you a thing or two: I did not have to do anything to devalue ANL because ANL has been and continues to be in quite a . . . deal of strife.

The Auditor-General this week confirmed his original assessment that ANL was an ongoing concern, able to meet its debts as and when they fell due. In view of the Auditor-General's direct contradiction to the minister's statement, does the minister admit that he was wrong to say that ANL could not be given away? Will the minister accept responsibility for the mess that he has created, or does he believe that the Auditor-General was not telling the truth?

TALK.START.PARA: —The only way that ANL could continue was to draw down on its promissory note, on its government guaranteed facility. The fact is that ANL, as I said, was in—and remains in—a considerable amount of strife. This is the company that wrote to me in August of this year indicating that it required a drawdown on its promissory note in order to pay the wages.
—Yes, because you had lent the money to Corrigan to pay for the shares.

—I am glad that you said that. You are the third one to pick up this theme. It was a theme that Laura Tingle, until yesterday when Quentin Dempster joined her, was the only journalist to adopt. The theme is that somehow the government had advanced money to Chris Corrigan in order that he could buy the government's shares in ANL. What existed was a commercial arrangement for a deferred payment of three months. No money changed hands whatsoever. Here is the shadow minister, with all of his stock exchange background, wandering into the House saying, `You lent them the money.'
—It needed the money to pay the wages.

—All that the directors of ANL did was enter into a normal commercial arrangement which involved a 90-day settlement of the balance of the $28 million; that is, the difference between the 20 per cent deposit that they paid and the full purchase price of $28 million.

PARA.TAB: There is nothing in the Auditor-General's report that I have anything to be concerned about. ANL remains in great difficulty and Neville Wran, Malcolm Turnbull and their fellow directors are working at trying to rescue it at the moment. If you looked at the balance sheets of ANL, and even if you were to pick up the $180 million debt which is attached to ANL—

TALK.START.PARA: —What about Neville Wran?
—Order! The Deputy Leader of the Opposition!

—you would find that it would still be losing money and losing money consistently month after month. That is the reality of ANL's position and we are intent on doing something about that. That is what due diligence was for, what the proposal to have the ALP conference allow for privatisation of at least a majority, or indeed all, of ANL was all about and what the work Neville Wran and the board are pursuing at this very moment is all about.

PARA.TAB: Let me repeat that I have no problem at all with the Auditor-General's report other than one gratuitous paragraph that people should not talk down the value. As I have already said to the House, the day I said ANL was not able to be given away was the day we had earlier announced that it was withdrawn from sale. I suggest you should read and study carefully the Auditor-General's report.

TALK.START.PARA: —He said you were wrong.
—He says no such thing at all. You go and read the report.
—The member for Gippsland has been warned.

—It is a bit like the member for Hume, who this morning was calling for my resignation. He has called for a number of resignations down through the years, as these press files of mine indicate. When challenged by the journalist to give a single issue of substance revealed by the Auditor-General, he was dumbfounded. All he could say was, `Well, there is serious concern here.' He could not instance a single matter of concern, a single matter of substance; and nor can any of you. That is your problem. So go and read the report before pretending that it is something it is not.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training. Is the minister aware of claims that primary school children in Western Australia are not receiving tuition in languages other than English? Can the minister advise whether the Commonwealth provides funds for the teaching of languages other than English? Can the minister advise the House whether the Commonwealth has reduced funding to the state of Western Australia which might have brought about this situation?

—I thank the honourable member for Perth for the question. I acknowledge the close interest he takes in the work of schools in the electorate of Perth and the many opportunities he has given me to visit schools in his electorate. I can assure him that there has been no reduction—none—in the Commonwealth's funding support for language programs other than English language programs in Western Australian schools.

PARA.TAB: This year the Commonwealth provided Western Australia with more than half a million dollars under one program, the priority languages incentive element, and a quarter of a million dollars under another program, the community languages element. Both these are elements of the school language program. The Commonwealth will maintain this level of support in 1995. In addition, the Commonwealth is to provide $67.7 million over the next four years to support increased enrolments in key Asian language studies among students from years 3 to 10 around Australia. The languages concerned are Indonesian, Chinese, Japanese and Korean. The national Asian languages studies strategy for Australian schools, NALSSAS, was agreed to by the Council of Australian Governments earlier this year and, of course, that included Western Australia.

The Commonwealth appreciates the considerable benefits of fostering a multilingual population and it recognises the provision of appropriate funding as a key part of that process. For that reason, we provide considerable funds to the Western Australian government for this purpose. If schools in Western Australia are unable to offer classes through an alleged lack of trained teachers, there is no justification—none—for claiming that the fault lies with the Commonwealth. The Western Australian government has been provided with the funds. It is the Western Australian government's responsibility to use those funds and to provide the classes.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister for Transport

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Transport. As the minister whose negligence, deceit and incompetence have delivered chaos in the sensitive area of aviation safety—
—Order! Order!
—Mr Speaker, I rise on a point of order. In phrasing a question in this place you cannot use imputations, epithets or—
—Nor can you in answers.
—Yes, you can. Unfortunately, you can.
—You cannot reflect on a member in your answers.
—You certainly have a wider authority in answers than you have in questions.
—Oh, we have noticed that.
—And who wrote—
—Order! This is not a debating point! The Leader of the House on his point of order.

—The point of order is: under those standing orders, written by Mr Sinclair many years ago, there is a clear requirement that you eliminate from those questions anything like epithets and imputations. What is absolutely evident from the presentation by the Leader of the Opposition is that he was doing precisely that.
—I have already this afternoon requested members in this place on both sides to be careful—
—It is 144, Kim.
—The member for O'Connor!
—I am just helping him out.

—I have already said that I have referred both sides of this place to the fact that language can be offensive and I have repeatedly asked people to consider that. The Leader of the House has rightly pointed out that the standing order says that imputations of improper motive, epithets and so on should not be contained within the questions, and rightly so. However, no such standing order exists which defines that in answers. But I would ask the Leader of the Opposition, in coming to his question, to perhaps consider carefully his introductory comment.
—Thank you, Mr Speaker. As I said, as the minister whose total negligence and incompetence in relation to his handling of his portfolio has delivered chaos—
—Mr Speaker—
—I know you don't like it, pal.
—Order!
—Look, they always run away from a debate, don't they?
—Go on; spit the dummy.
—They always run away from it.
—Resume your seat!

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr Beazley

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. Standing order 144 states:

INTERJECT.PARA: (a) statements of facts or names of persons unless they are strictly necessary to render the question intelligible and can be authenticated;

TALK.START.PARA: —This is absolute hypocrisy.
—Order! The Leader of the Opposition!
—The Ian Sinclair standing orders, which we have operated under in this place, make amply clear that the opposition leader's statements are out of order.

—Mr Speaker, on the point of order: obviously the standing orders require a great deal of interpretation by you and obviously you allow a great deal of liberty. Over the years you have been asked to interpret standing order 145.

PARA.TAB: Government members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The member is speaking to the point of order.

—Earlier on this week, in interpreting standing orders in this place, you allowed the phrase `champion deceiver'. In doing so, you raised to a new high level the acceptable form of language and the acceptable form of interpretation in relation to the standing orders. There is no going back from that. Having allowed that kind of interpretation on a standing order in this House this week, such a loose interpretation, you cannot now selectively and rigorously interpret the same standing orders in relation to standing order 144. Any ruling you now give must be consistent with the way you have interpreted standing orders this week in relation to the same set of standing orders. On that basis, such words must be allowed and must be ruled to be in order in questions.
—I thank the Deputy Leader of the Opposition—

PARA.TAB: Mrs Crosio interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I warn the member for Prospect. I thank the Deputy Leader of the Opposition for yet again drawing my attention to words which people have chosen to use in this place and reminding me of something that earlier this week I allowed. As I recall it, it was contained in part of an answer. In fact, my research has indicated that the source of that phraseology, or something very close to it, emanated from honourable members in this place to the left of me.
—So what?
—So I have allowed that, as has been approved within this place. As far as questions are concerned—
—Let's have a first. Let's just make it even, shall we?
—The Leader of the Opposition is making a habit of talking back to me.

PARA.TAB: Government members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Those on my right! I have suggested to members—and I do it yet again—that, under standing order 144, which we have all just heard read out, there are certain phrases and ways in which questions can be put. The Leader of the Opposition did—and I thank him for doing so—change the wording and that took out what I considered to be the offensive part of the introduction to his question. I ask him to now get on with it. I would advise all members, from both sides, when phrasing questions, to be careful of the provisions of that standing order.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Transport. As the minister whose negligence and incompetence have delivered chaos in the sensitive area of aviation safety, massive increases in aircraft noise for tens of thousands of Sydneysiders, increased delays and inefficiencies at Sydney airport, confusion and backflips over industrial relations legislation, a rising level of industrial disputation, and the loss of tens of millions of dollars of taxpayers' money over the ANL debacle, I ask him: when will he do what he should have done long ago and resign? Or will this minister for chaos continue to cling to office only because his mate, the Prime Minister, will not do what he should and sack him?
—It is appropriate that this should end as it began back in 1988, when John Sharp was calling for the resignation of none other than Gary Punch, the responsible minister—
—He did resign! He did resign.
—Order! The House will come to order.
—He was calling for his resignation on the basis that he would not proceed immediately with the construction of the third runway. Indeed, he was not the only one who was called upon to resign.

PARA.TAB: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The minister will wait for a moment and resume his seat. The minister may proceed.

—It did not begin and end with Gary Punch because, within a matter of weeks, the opposition had called for the resignation of the then Minister for the Environment, Graham Richardson, on the basis that—
—He has gone too.
—Yes, that is right.
—Strike three, and you are out.
—Order!

—And I tell you what: he was around for many years. But what was the basis of the opposition's call for his resignation? The basis of its call was that he was standing in the way of the construction of this runway.

PARA.TAB: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order!
—You've had it.
—Order! Those on my left!

—Now the Leader of the Opposition, who represents a party committed to the construction of that runway, the party that bayed for it, the party that represented the cheer squad for it, when it is finally built and open, comes into this House today and calls for my resignation. I am going to treat that call as seriously as it deserves—and that is not very seriously at all.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sharp Mr J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That this House censures the Minister for Transport for his failure to exercise proper ministerial standards and the maladministration resulting from his failure to perform his portfolio responsibilities.

SPEECH.PARA: In the last few minutes as we have sat here, we have seen a very good reason emerge as to why the Minister for Transport (Mr Brereton) should resign forthwith from that post. Only a few moments ago we were reminded by him of people who preceded him in ministerial posts, people who had important responsibilities, who did the right thing eventually—and that was to resign.

PARA.TAB: The minister reminded us of the honourable member who was the Minister for Aviation Support back in 1988, now the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel (Mr Punch), who did the right thing and resigned. He reminded us of the former minister for the environment, the former Senator Richardson, who did the right thing and resigned. Thank you very much, Minister, for reminding us today of those who have gone before you who have ultimately seen the light and resigned. They resigned because they knew ultimately that the right thing was to act in a proper fashion because their ministerial responsibilities were beyond them.

I do not think there has been a minister of this government over the last 12 months who has got himself into more trouble than the man sitting opposite us here today, the Minister for Transport. Just cast your mind back over the last 12 months and think of the great controversies that have been involved in federal politics and of the person who has been at the centre of those controversies. It is none other than the Minister for Transport, the honourable member for Kingsford-Smith. There is a cartoon character—

TALK.START.PARA: —Danger Man.
—Danger Man. Is it not amazing that the person who is responsible for aviation safety in this country is nicknamed `Danger Man'?
—By the Prime Minister.

—The Prime Minister (Mr Keating) was the man who named him, who gave him that nickname. Is it not also amazing that the day-to-day responsibility for aviation safety in this country is held by an organisation whose headquarters is called `Fort Fumble'. So we have Danger Man and Fort Fumble looking after aviation safety in this country.

PARA.TAB: There is a cartoon character that many of us would be familiar with called Flash Gordon. This character manages to get himself into trouble all the time. No sooner has he stumbled his way through one lot of trouble than he stumbles into the next. The person who best fits the description of Flash Gordon here in this parliament is the Minister for Transport. No matter what he does, and no matter how he goes about it, he walks straight into controversy and trouble; and no sooner has he got out of that trouble than he gets into more trouble.

The reputation that the Minister for Transport brought to this House when he was elected to the federal parliament in 1990 was one that certainly gave the impression that he, in his former role in the state parliament, was the equivalent of having an albatross around your neck. We all remember the reputation that this man had as the minister for public works in New South Wales. We will all remember the problems that the Wran-Unsworth government had in its dying days. Honourable members will remember the former Premier of New South Wales Barrie Unsworth, the old cardigan killer. Many people thought he was not all that bright. But I tell you that Barrie Unsworth was bright enough to know that, coming up to the election, the biggest albatross around the Labor government's neck in 1988 was none other than Laurie Brereton. What did he do?

TALK.START.PARA: —He sacked him.

—He demoted him and sacked him, and that is exactly what the Prime Minister here in the Commonwealth parliament should be doing to the same man. The situation surrounding the minister's carriage of his ministerial responsibilities here in this parliament are equal to or worse than they were back in 1988 when Barrie Unsworth got rid of him. When Barrie Unsworth got rid of him it was too late, the damage was done. I think you will find that, unless this minister is prepared to have his head put on the plate, what the Minister for Transport did to Barrie Unsworth in 1988 is what he is going to do to Bob Carr in 1995. You just watch.

PARA.TAB: There has been a lot of controversy surrounding the Minister for Transport. He is a bit like a lightning rod for attracting controversy. Whether it be in the portfolio of industrial relations, whether it be his handling of the third runway controversy and all of the surrounding noise problems in Sydney, whether it be the handling of ANL or, indeed, the handling of aviation safety, this minister has got himself into hot water—on each and every one of those issues.

Today in the House we saw how the minister and his colleague the Minister for Finance (Mr Beazley) were trying to deal with the problem of ANL. Many of us would have watched the 7.30 Report last night to see the former chairman of ANL, Bill Bolitho, go on national television and make some very serious accusations about the way in which this minister has carried out his ministerial responsibilities as far as the privatisation and sale of ANL are concerned.

Mr Bill Bolitho, a man whose reputation is unsullied throughout the business community and who is probably the most respected person in the Australian shipping industry today, went on national television and made some extraordinary and serious accusations about the propriety of the way in which this minister has carried out the sale and privatisation process of ANL.

During this week, we also saw the Auditor-General's report being tabled in the Senate. What did the Auditor-General's report tell us? It told us three things. Firstly, it drew some very serious questions about the process by which the Price Waterhouse-Salomon Brothers report on, and valuation of, ANL was undertaken. The importance of that report on, and valuation of, ANL is that the Minister for Transport based all of his actions surrounding his decisions with ANL on that report. Yet the Auditor-General, in his report tabled in this parliament during the week, draws into question the whole process of the Price Waterhouse-Salomon Brothers valuation mechanism for the ANL. That is the first thing the report tells us.

Secondly, the Auditor-General in his report makes the point that he has been very concerned about certain public officials making public utterances which have the potential to damage the value of ANL. We heard earlier today the Minister for Finance trying to tell us that this was not directed in any way at the Minister for Transport. Yet the Minister for Transport got up here a little while later and said that the only thing in the Auditor-General's report he was worrying about was the gratuitous advice that had been levelled at him.

Do you know what the Auditor-General was saying? The Auditor-General was saying that the big mouth of the Minister for Transport has cost this country tens of millions of dollars. Why? Because he gave a press conference on national television and said, `You could not give ANL away.' We are in the business of trying to sell ANL. It is a business that is worth many millions of dollars. Yet this man went out and said that we could not give it away. In the process of doing that, he damaged the value of that business irreparably. That is the second thing the Auditor-General's report tells us.

In addition to that, the Auditor-General attached an addendum to his report—a rather unusual thing for him to do. It is a letter from the Secretary to the Department of Finance—no doubt at the instruction of the Minister for Finance—requesting that the Auditor-General alter some key paragraphs in his report which are implicitly critical of the comments of the Minister for Transport about the value of ANL. That is what this letter is all about. It was unusual for the Auditor-General to do that—but necessary because he felt that, unless he made it quite clear that an attempt had been made to try to whitewash this report, people would not note the gravity of the situation surrounding this whole process of trying to sell ANL.

The net result of this is that it has cost us a lot of money. So far it has cost us $20 million to fix up the strike of the Maritime Union of Australia which was created by this gentleman in the process of his handling of ANL. In addition to that, it will cost us more. We have already heard that next year we will have to have written into the budget an extra $50 million to try to keep this business that this man has now taken full charge of afloat for another 12 months. We also see that it will cost us money because of the big mouth this man has got. The views he has expressed, which he thinks are important, such as that ANL could not be given away, have cost the taxpayers of Australia a tremendous amount of money.

As I said, Bill Bolitho made some extraordinary claims on the television last night. Over the last few weeks, we have also had several articles written by Laura Tingle. The minister referred to them in his comments today in question time. Those articles by Laura Tingle go to the whole propriety of this government. They refer to a secret loan of $22.4 million given by the company that this minister claims is bankrupt and that you could not give away to the company that was buying ANL's shares in Australian Stevedores. Yet today we heard the Minister for Finance and the Minister for Transport saying, `This was not a loan; this was just a deferred payment. It was exactly the same deal that Howard Smith had with Jamison Equity when it sold its 25 per cent shareholding in Australian Stevedores.'

Let me tell you that it was not the same deal and the minister knows that. In fact, he knows it very well. The Australian Stevedores shares that Howard Smith owned were not handed over straightaway to Jamison Equity. It did not lend Jamison Equity the money. This government with its secret deal, which Laura Tingle has highlighted to us, actually gave a $22.4 million loan to Jamison Equity, handed over all the shares and gave the seat on the board of Australian Stevedores that ANL had directly to Jamison Equity. None of this was done by Howard Smith. There is a clear and distinct difference. This government would have us believe that the deal that it did with Jamison Equity was exactly the same deal that Howard Smith did. It was not.

Last night I had dinner with some people who were present at the finalisation of the sale of the Australian Stevedores shares to Jamison Equity. They told me that everything Laura Tingle wrote in that article is absolutely and utterly true. That makes some of things that this minister and the Minister for Finance have said over the last few days quite wrong.

So we have these quite reasonable and proper concerns about the propriety of this government and the administration by this minister of his ministerial responsibilities. These are serious concerns. If the Prime Minister does not deal with these sorts of concerns, Australia's taxpayers will continue to lose many millions of dollars due to the incompetence of this man.

In the process of trying to cover up his actions over ANL, the minister has worn the tag that he justly deserves and that is of being the champion deceiver. This man is the champion deceiver. We heard the term used in this House earlier this week, but nobody better fits the term of champion deceiver than the Minister for Transport.

When talking about the champion deceiver, let us look at the third runway and the problems that Sydneysiders are experiencing at the present time. We have heard from this minister that we cannot have the east-west runway up and running again because it would be unsafe. Do you know the reason why the east-west runway is not going to be up and running again? It is not because it is unsafe. It has nothing to do with that at all.

If we go back to an article in the Australian Financial Review of 23 March 1989 we find a detailed account of how the government changed its mind about the third runway; and who was responsible for changing the government's mind about the third runway. The article, which was written by Geoff Kitney, makes interesting reading. It states:
After looking at various configurations, Mr Keating proposed that the new north-south runway be fully operational from both directions and the old east-west runway be virtually made redundant.
The effect of this change was dramatic.

SPEECH.PARA: That is the reason why the east-west runway is not being opened now. The significance of that is that the 10,000 people who rallied at Leichhardt Oval last Saturday expressing their concerns about the problems of noise over Sydney due to the opening of the third runway are saying that one of the best solutions to the problem is to open the east-west runway. We are not going to get it opened because the Prime Minister was the man who directed that it be closed. The reason why it was closed was explained further on in the same article. It states:

PARA.TAB: The political significance of Mr Keating's proposal was that the noise impact on the most marginal Labor seats of Barton (1.1 per cent) and St George (3.7 per cent) would be greatly reduced, while the areas where noise would increase would be the safest Labor seats—Sydney (20 per cent) and Grayndler (10 per cent).

SPEECH.PARA: We now know why we have all these problems over Sydney with the third runway. It has nothing to do with the east-west runway operating simultaneously with the other two north-south runways being unsafe. It is all about grubby politics—politics designed to advantage nobody else but the Labor Party. The man responsible for it is the Prime Minister. But the man who is covering for him, the champion deceiver, is going around trying to convince us that we cannot have this east-west runway up and running because it would be unsafe. This is yet another example of the way in which this minister is not honestly and properly administering his portfolio responsibilities.

PARA.TAB: Another thing that earns him the title of champion deceiver is the meeting he held with some local government officials from Marrickville Council on 28 July this year. The minister was in possession of a report which indicated that the local government officials who were meeting with him had seriously underestimated the degree of noise they would experience as a result of the opening of the third runway. This minister, according to those officials, did not tell them about that report. He kept that report secret.

That report only saw the light of day when it was subpoenaed to be heard in the Federal Court hearings of November of this year. That is the reason that report became public. That is another clear example of the way this minister has deceived the people of Sydney over the noise levels they would experience as a result of the third runway being up and running.

Another thing that earns this minister the title of being incompetent is that he opened the third runway months ahead of the rest of the facilities at Sydney airport being ready. You have to ask yourself: why did the minister open the third runway months before the new air traffic control tower would be open? Why did he open it 12 months in advance of the new radar system being able to be used? That is a very good question.

The net result of that is that 91 per cent of all flights going into Sydney airport are currently delayed. Ansett experienced up to 30,000 complaints from travellers in one particular day. The capacity of Sydney airport has been reduced from 64 aircraft movements per hour to 50 craft movements per hour. We have gone out and spent over $200 million building the third runway, we have opened it, because this man decided to do it, months in advance of the rest of the facilities being available for use and the net result is the creation of an enormous mess at Sydney airport.

Indeed, Peter Young, representative of Ansett Airlines, said yesterday that the airport infrastructure in Australia is completely broken at this moment. In the process of breaking it, this minister has destroyed the lives of hundreds of thousands of Sydneysiders over the last few weeks because he has not been prepared to deal properly with the issue of noise levels for Sydneysiders. The reason is that his Prime Minister is the man who made the decision to close the east-west runway for grubby, political purposes. That is why those people are suffering at this time. That is why the opposition moves this censure motion against the Minister for Transport.

In relation to ANL, he carried out those actions of sacking the board of ANL, of appointing his old mate Neville Wran to run the ANL board for the next six months and of calling ANL a business that you could not give away. We know that all of that was done for grubby, political purposes—because of the ALP that was coming up in September.

We now know the truth of the situation as to why Sydneysiders are living a complete hell of a life at the present time. It is because of this government's grubby, political deals for their own grubby, political ends to try to win votes and seats in Sydney. We now know the reason. It is all due to this minister's incompetence and his inability to properly carry out his ministerial responsibilities.

That is why this man should go. That is why this man was nicknamed years ago by the Prime Minister as Dangerman. That is why, if he is not careful, he will become the albatross around the Keating government's neck, like he was the albatross around the Unsworth government's neck all those years ago.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the motion seconded?
—I second the motion and reserve my right to speak.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brereton The Hon L.J.

TALKER.NAME: Mr BRERETON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister for Transport)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen some censure motions in the 25 years I have spent in public office—I have seen plenty of them—but I have never seen a weaker one than the one we have seen here this afternoon, moved by the member for Hume (Mr Sharp).

PARA.TAB: A censure motion is supposed to be the most serious thing that can happen in the parliament. A censure motion is a debate in respect of charges that should go to the very integrity of the minister being challenged. What did we see in the contribution from the honourable member? Not a single significant charge, but a lot of mealy-mouthed rubbish and recycled press releases—of course, he is the king of the press releases—but nothing to sustain the charge that I should be censured by this House.

Having said that, I take the opportunity provided to me for the next 15 minutes to deal with some of the issues that have been discussed here this afternoon. I deal particularly with this question of Australian National Line and the actions of the cabinet, given effect to by me, in respect of its financial circumstance.

As I have said to the House, the position of ANL was one causing us grave concern. We acted decisively and properly in order to make sure that taxpayers' interests were protected. We acted to make sure that ANL did not continue to haemorrhage to the average tune of $24 million per year—year in and year out. Indeed, the whole of the process I have instituted on behalf of the cabinet has been aimed at protecting taxpayers' interests, just as was the decision to sell the 25 per cent share in Australian Stevedores, which has been referred to by the honourable member this afternoon. It was a decision taken in order to eliminate a potential liability, which the trade union movement was trying to force us into, to spend $280 million and nationalise the greatest stevedoring company in Australia.

I have indicated to the House before the nature of the problems facing ANL, but I recount them. The fact is that the due diligence report this year from Price Waterhouse and Salomon Brothers, in no way cut down by the Auditor-General, indicates that ANL over-estimated its profit forecasts, year in and year out. In fact, in September 1990 the advice of the board of ANL to the government was that its shipping terminals and business would earn it $32 million. They lost ANL $5.3 million. The same month, June 1991, the board was forecasting to the government that everything would be okay and that it was going to make $21.4 million in its shipping and terminal businesses. That was its projected profit for the next year. The result was a dismal loss of $26 million recorded by June of 1992—a turnaround of $47 million in 12 months.

What was happening during this process? The board of ANL, chaired by Mr Bolitho, was indicating that everything was going to be all right, that everything was going to come up roses in the garden. In fact, it is worth recounting that Mr Bolitho, in his press release of 16 December 1993, claimed that ANL as a whole would at least break even in 1993-94. The result for 1993-94 will be somewhere between a $10 million and $20 million loss, the same sort of loss that it has sustained year in and year out.

It was only in February of this year that ANL went on the public record in the Australian saying that the company could expect solid profits for the next few years. We now know, as a result of the work of Salomon Brothers and Price Waterhouse, the very dismal state of that business. It was only six months after that that the company itself was coming to us saying that it wanted to draw down its promissory note, saying that it did not have sufficient funds to pay its bills.

The fact is that ANL has only survived so long by selling assets. This is the bottom line. Mr Bolitho went on television last night—the member for Hume has relied on him for some of his comments—and talked about profitability. My challenge is: what profitability? We have not seen profitability for years. If you take out the selling of a large part of its fleet—it has already sold most of its fleet—and you take out the sale of its future income stream, another little trick aimed at keeping the company afloat, then you find that the figures for ANL are even more appalling. These sales are not revealed in those figures of an average $24 million a year loss that I have given, but in the process ANL has flogged off most of the fleet.

ANL has gone further than that. It has sold the cash flow in respect of some remaining elements of the fleet. If you take out those extras, you find that ANL has pranged not just for the last four years but for six of the last seven years. When I come along, in concert with the Minister for Finance (Mr Beazley), and say that we are bringing in outside experts and that a due diligence study will be carried out, and when that due diligence study reveals the true state and nature of ANL and the government acts decisively, you have the hide to criticise us. Even then, as I have revealed in the House today, you could not get your act together. The shadow minister for privatisation is saying one thing and the shadow minister for transport is saying another. One is saying `liquidate' in respect of ANL; the other is saying `prop up'. Where do you get off?

You talk about credibility. You have no credibility on this matter. The government was properly concerned about ANL in terms of the approach of the board of directors. It needs to be remembered that Mr Bolitho was there for 10 years. During that whole 10-year period, the company paid $20.7 million in dividends to the government. I repeat: in the whole of the 10 year-period, the government got $20.7 million. During that time, the government pumped $160.5 million into the company in debt forgiveness or equity injection. During that period, the taxpayer went down the gurgle hole to the tune of $140 million.

Someone had to do something about that situation. It was not just that money that had been lost. The current debt of ANL sits in the books at $180 million. That $180 million has to be picked up at the end of the day by the taxpayer. The government acted decisively and did something about that, and you have the hide to come into this House and challenge us in this censure motion against me. We have done the right and courageous thing in regard to ANL—the sort of thing that you would never do and never did during the many years that you had the carriage and control of ANL from 1975 to 1983.

You left ANL in 1983 in the most appalling condition, which was why we had to pump $160.5 million of equity injection into it. You avoided your responsibility for ANL in the most scandalous manner. For you to have the hide to come in here and challenge us when we have done the right thing in respect of this matter really defies credulity.

I have indicated to the House that, even were we to eliminate that $180 million of debt, the company would still be losing money month after month. Of course ANL needs restructuring, and that is exactly what this government is committed to. This afternoon there have been a number of—I cannot call them charges because there were no charges levelled against me—

TALK.START.PARA: —Wet lettuce.
—Yes, wet lettuce.
—There were 10 wet lettuce leaves.

—I think there were only three or four wet lettuce leaves that were flung across the chamber at me, and one concerned Bill Bolitho. At least Bill, for all his problems, had the decency to go on the radio this morning and say, `I have a king sized chip on my shoulder.' That I can understand. I know how he feels.
