If you had been associated with something for 10 years, if you had put your life's work into it and you had been asked by the minister of the day, for very good reason, to stand down, of course you would have a chip on your shoulder. The opposition should not be relying on Bill Bolitho, the man with the chip on his shoulder, as a basis for any censure motion against me.

PARA.TAB: Yet opposition members come in here saying that we have lost tens of millions of dollars as a result of my saying, `You could

SPEECH.PARA: not give ANL away'—which was a pretty fair remark—on the day that I announced we were withdrawing it from sale. In the papers this morning, ANZDL indicated that it wants to bid for ANL. It said that the issue of its reputation will have no bearing whatsoever on what price it pays. The company will base its price, as will all the bidders, on the basis of the worth of the company. It will have the assistance of a very good due diligence procedure carried out independently by Price Waterhouse and Salomons to assist it.

PARA.TAB: I make no bones about the matter: I hope that we can see ANL privatised. I sincerely hope that the trade union movement can take a stake in that privatisation. I hope that we can see ANL recover from its parlous state and be reborn. It will be a different sort of line, but that is the approach the government has taken. We are doing something about it. We are doing the sorts of things that you would never do.

The next wet lettuce that came across the table was the Laura Tingle charge. Now there are four of them in the cart. There is Laura Tingle, Mr Dempster, who is formerly from the 7.30 Report, the shadow minister for privatisation and the shadow minister for transport, all of whom are saying that there is something in this charge. The directors of ANL negotiated a sale—a very favourable outcome from the government's point of view—to stop us being reduced to a minority shareholding. They secured $28 million. Because that afternoon they could come up with only 20 per cent by way of a deposit and they were given 90 days to settle—that is a deferred settlement—that is characterised as the basis of a censure motion against me.

This was a standard commercial arrangement entered into by the directors of ANL and Malcolm Turnbull, who was the negotiator on behalf of the government, yet in some way that is supposed to represent the basis of a censure motion. What an absolute wet lettuce. It is characterised here as a loan. No money changed hands; it was a deferred settlement. Yet there is something wrong with it! What a load of nonsense.

The third damp lettuce concerned the third runway. Opposition members asked why the east-west runway cannot be opened. The attempt to charge the Prime Minister of Australia as the person responsible for airport noise in Sydney is about as sincere as John Fahey's charge that all of this was done to assist Bob Carr, whose electorate is on the east-west corridor. Who is it coming from? In the case of John Fahey, it is coming from a man who less than a year ago called for 24-hour access in and out of Kingsford Smith airport. It is coming from the colleagues of John Fahey sitting opposite here. In the run-up to the last election, we all remember the performances of the member for Fadden (Mr Jull) and the Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Tim Fischer) when they said that there should be a removal of the curfew. Yet they expect there to be some credibility in this charge that somehow or other the Prime Minister is responsible for the noise.

The majority of people in Sydney are much better off. That does not mean that this government does not take with absolute seriousness the plight of those people who are worse off. It is for that very reason that we are committed to restricting the flight paths. It is for that very reason that we are committed to very substantial penalties against people who fly outside those flight paths. It is for that very reason that we want to bring forward the sound amelioration program so that we can treat the worst affected areas. It is for that very reason that we want the new operational requirements at Kingsford Smith to make sure that the minimum number of people are exposed to noise.

Yet you come in here today and talk about opening up the third runway. What you are doing is arguing for more planes into Kingsford Smith, not for jets on the east-west runway. You know that you cannot do that. You are arguing the position of Hazelton Airlines and the position of Graeme McMahon of Ansett. You think that, if all of the propeller planes take off and land to and from the east, you will be able to put more jets on the north-south axis. You know full well that jets cannot take off on the new parallel runway.

In the view of those opposite, that means that five, 10 or 15 more jets per hour can take off when the conditions would mean take-offs to the north across that corridor of people directly under the flight path to the north. That is what you are really about. You are using this to undermine the micro-economic reasons for the development of Badgerys Creek; a second airport that can meet the demands of Sydney and can provide the hubbing arrangements to adequately cater for all of the flights that are currently being demanded. I have told you today that the increase in flights is between 48 and 50 per cent only in the last nine months. That was the third damp lettuce.

No-one should be deceived by any of this, least of all the poor individuals who are suffering at the moment from noise exposure on the north-south runway. You are attempting to dupe and deceive them by saying that their lot can be made better by opening the east-west runway to propeller planes, knowing all the time that more and more jets will be taking off over the top of them.

The member for Hume finished up by saying that it was an enormous mess. I am proud that this government is tackling all of these issues vigorously—whether they be ANL, aircraft safety, the new Civil Aviation Safety Authority, the restructure of the Civil Aviation Authority or the measures that will be discussed by cabinet tomorrow—to guarantee that we have the airport that Sydney needs and the maximum protection for people. We reject utterly this censure motion as being a total waste of the parliament's time. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Connolly Mr D.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I second the motion. One of the characteristics of a discredited government is that it tries to pass the buck on to somebody else. That is what we have seen in this debate today and what has been affecting the people of Sydney so grievously in recent weeks. The third runway was opened on 4 November this year. On 29 November, a crowd of some 2,000 people attended a hastily organised meeting at the Petersham Town Hall to protest against the increased noise levels. I was at that meeting. A shadow minister was at that meeting. A number of state Labor members in the area, including the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, Dr Refshauge, were at that meeting.
—How many federal members were there?
—The interesting thing was that there was not a single federal member—
—Not one?

—Not one single federal member bothered to turn up—or maybe I should say that they were not game enough to turn up. Had the Minister for Transport (Mr Brereton), who has just spoken, been there he would have noted, among other things, the intention of people to lynch him. They believe—and rightly so—that, as the minister, he has to carry the responsibility for the total disruption to the lifestyle of thousands upon thousands of Sydney residents. One of them made the point, which I thought was rather cryptic, that Mr Brereton's street should be made runway No. 4.

PARA.TAB: More recently than that, last Saturday at Leichhardt Oval, 10,000 people came out on this issue. Yes, it is serious. Yes, it is important. Yes, it does affect the lives of these people. The one characteristic that brought those people together was not just noise and its clear physical and psychological effect upon them and their families, but the firm belief that they have been misled by this government that for so long has carried out, under the protection of silence, a series of activities which were ultimately going to cause massive losses to the character of their lifestyle, to the value of their homes—to their very sanity. When we heard those people speaking at those public meetings, we heard from the heart what ordinary people are suffering because of the circumstances over which they have absolutely no control.

It is fine for the minister to tell us why the east-west runway cannot be reopened. It is fine for him to protect himself on the grounds that the CAA says that there are safety reasons. Of course, safety in aviation is of fundamental importance. But the sad fact of the matter is that there are political considerations in this area. The honourable member for Lowe (Mrs Easson), who is in the chamber here today, knows that she has been sacrificed. She knows that she is the loser of this outcome, and she knows that the government has made a decision that Barton, St George, Sydney and Grayndler are more important than the seat of Lowe. Let me assure her of one thing: we are on her side. The boundaries of this problem do not stop at the Parramatta River. This problem goes well beyond that—well over Lane Cove, well over Hunters Hill and right to the very edge of Ku-ring-gai National Park. Even the animals in the park are complaining.

We were not told about this. My constituents were not told. People in Chatswood were not told. People up in Wahroonga and Turramurra were not told. I had an engineer do a survey this week in west Pymble, and he picked up 88 decibels of sound. It might be worth members knowing that on the race track those very noisy sports cars are not allowed to go over 100 decibels. So when you are talking about 88 decibels in a valley—that is where this person did the test—you can see easily what the effect of noise is on the people who are caught in this environment. Geography has them caught, and the sound reverberates through their homes and through their lives.

Version 6 of the Sydney (Kingsford Smith) Airport noise management plan was issued in March 1994. When you go through this document, you find these interesting tables outlining the effect that the noise would have on people. It talks about the aircraft noise effect on people by the year 2010. It almost puts you into that somnolent sense that it is over the hill, far away; that it is not really going to be an issue for the people of today. But it is a problem for the people of today; it is a very real problem on a daily basis.

The questions asked and the analysis which was carried out was very interesting. Was it going to affect conversation, watching TV or listening to radio or music? Would sleep be disturbed by noise? There is an analysis of the number of people who would be affected by the noise: 26,800 would be seriously affected; 127,700 would be moderately affected; 100,000 people would have their conversation disturbed; and 135,300 would be disturbed whilst watching TV or listening to radio. I love the preciseness of these figures. A mere 59,000 people would have their sleep disturbed. The document claims that the total number of people in that group in the population who would be affected by the airport is 417,600 people. My mathematics may not be marvellous but it seems to me that, on the basis of this survey, every single person has been affected to a significant degree by the noise generated by this airport. That survey was done on the basis of the anticipated problems in the year 2010.

We have been told by the minister today that, in this year alone, the use of Mascot airport has gone up by over 50 per cent in those peak periods. If the increase is 50 per cent in one year, what is it going to be by the year 2010? The people of Sydney demand answers to these problems. They believe, and rightly so, that this analysis which apparently took place was either wrong or was organised in such a way that people were never told the truth. I, like many other members in this House who have been affected by this problem, have received numerous letters from constituents who make these points. They ask us to be their voice in this House. They ask us to say to the government, `You are ruining our lives. Why did you do this to us and why didn't you give us a fair warning?' Mr K. Lane of Turramurra wrote:

SPEECH.PARA: Before the runway opened we had only 5—10 planes going over our house a week. Now it is about 80 a day.
A person in St Ives wrote:
The chief culprits are the 747s . . . at times, they are only a few hundred metres overhead (despite the airport being some 10kms away from us). . .

The interesting thing is that this analysis done by the government never at any stage suggested that the problems of the airport were going to go beyond a clearly defined area, the northern boundary of which would be the Parramatta River. Not one of the maps provided by the authority, by the government, by the minister, by his department, shows a single indicator of any noise problems north of the Parramatta River or the Lane Cove River. Yet the fundamental fact of the matter is that those figures of the number of people affected by sound are absolutely flawed. The real figure is probably twice that. I think we have a right to know why that is so. Why were those figures so wrong? Why was that analysis so wrong? Why were people not told? Why was this whole exercise carried through with such a degree of secrecy, in an underhand way?

PARA.TAB: Perhaps the most poignant statement I heard at the public meeting at Petersham Town Hall came from a young girl called Amanda. She was quoted on AM of Wednesday, 30 November as saying:

SPEECH.PARA: My name is Amanda, and I come from Sydenham, and us kids at school, we can hardly hear what the teachers are saying from these planes because every two minutes, our teachers have to stop what they're saying, and then when us kids have more ideas in our heads, when one of the planes go, every single idea goes out of their heads.

Time after time, person after person came forward at that meeting making the point of how disastrous the effect had been on their living capacity, on the ability of their children to go to school. Yet we have been told by this government, `Don't worry. We are going to buy thousands of houses. We are going to take over the land. We are going to close it all down. We are going to organise the schools and give them a decent system so they will not get the sound effects.' On behalf of those hundreds of thousands of people, I ask the Minister for Finance (Mr Beazley) who is at the table and Minister Brereton, who is no longer here for this debate, that fundamental question: why did you not sort this mess out before you ruined the lives of these people?

PARA.TAB: That is what they want to know. If you had all the answers—and we are still looking for them; that is why we are having this debate today—why did you not put the insulation into these homes? Why did you not insulate those schools? Why should the children in those suburbs suffer so grievously? Why should the results from their examinations be less than they ought to be? Why should their lives be ruined because of the short-term nature of this government's political decision making process?

I gave out forms at that meeting and asked people to fill them in, to give them the opportunity to see precisely what the situation was. I got some very interesting responses, one from a Mr Antonios Samaras of Newington Street, Marrickville. He sent me two pages. The horrifying thing is that he has planes flying over his house on average about one every four minutes. Just imagine it—one every four minutes! How could you conceivably live under conditions like that? I seek permission of the House to table this material so that people can see what the realities are and what they mean to ordinary people.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Jenkins)—Order! Is the honourable member seeking leave to table the document?

TALK.START.PARA: —I certainly am.
—And he is certainly not going to get it.

PARA.TAB: Leave not granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is typical. That is fine. I will write back to Mr Antonios Samaras and say to him that we have a Minister for Finance (Mr Beazley), who is at the table, and a government which are not only ruining his life but also not prepared to put on the table of this House the facts which he as a free citizen of a so-called democratic society has the right to put forward to a member of parliament and to this chamber. Here, minister—read it yourself.

PARA.TAB: This story goes back to at least 20 October 1976, when Prime Minister Fraser and Premier Wran announced a series of important studies called the MANS study. The object of that study was to examine jointly the implications of the likely growth of air traffic in the Sydney region and to recommend a suitable strategy for major airport development. It is interesting to note that by 14 December 1979 our dear friend Mr Wran and his cohorts had pulled out of the exercise because they did not want to get too close to the heat; it could be a bit embarrassing politically. Nevertheless, in a report which was presented on 14 December 1979 the Commonwealth members recommended that a decision in principle should be taken to develop Kingsford Smith airport by the construction of a close space parallel runway and associated facilities east of the existing north-south runway and that land be reserved in the Sydney region for a second curfew-free major airport.

The honourable member has just said that that would have been disastrous. Let us think this through more carefully. On 7 October 1982 the then Minister for Aviation, Mr Fife, announced the construction of a new runway at KSA. He stressed that `this new runway is not an alternative to a new airport, but a necessary first step if Sydney is to remain as Australia's main aviation gateway'. He added:

SPEECH.PARA: Let me emphasize there will be no new flight paths to the north of the airport.
`No new flight paths to the north of the airport'. He continued:
The only new flight paths will be over Botany Bay and the Kurnell peninsula. No aircraft will approach the new runway from over the city or take-off towards the city on the new runway.
That is the point he made. What has happened is exactly the opposite. The whole issue was the need to try to balance the realities of sound on people—

TALK.START.PARA: —Will they sail in with the tail wind?
—I am sick of listening to the honourable

SPEECH.PARA: member. Will you do me a favour—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Parliamentary Secretary!
—He will never take any chances. You would do anything the government told you.
—Order! The honourable member for Mitchell is not helping.

—The point Mr Fife was making was that a close space runway—not a broad space runway which you finally got—was going to take aircraft above Botany Bay. Instead of that, the runway you constructed has taken aircraft across the city of Sydney, affecting hundreds of thousands if not millions of people who previously had not had a problem with aircraft—or, if it was a problem, it was certainly a manageable one. They are the realities of the situation. Ever since 1983, since the then shadow minister for transport, the honourable member for Shortland (Mr Peter Morris), announced in the election campaign that the Labor government would abandon the plan to build a second runway, there has been nothing but trouble and politics in this whole thing. This whole issue has been fraught with politics. Now the people in these Labor electorates—and in Liberal electorates in places like the north shore of Sydney—are carrying a substantial cost—
—And Cook.

—And in the electorate of Cook. It is because of the way you played politics for 11 years. The fundamental fact is the new airport at Badgerys Creek should have been built earlier, and it has not been. You have been in power for 11 years and you are responsible. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: This is pretty cool. You have the opposition deciding that this is such a serious issue that it will not even put up its second eleven; it has brought out its district cricket team. If ever there was evidence that a district team had been brought out on this one it was the statements we have just heard. I do not know if Wal Fife actually did put out that press release. I would like to believe that Wal Fife did not. I would like to believe that Wal Fife has been misquoted. If he seriously put up an argument, as you just did, that you have a north-south runway and that it will simply operate away from the suburb affected by north-south runways all the time, irrespective of the wind direction, then I suspect that if anybody has been a misleader, a liar or a prevaricator in any way, shape or form in this exercise it has been Wal. I find it impossible to believe that of Wal. I think that Wal was a very decent person. The opposition must be making that up. I am sure that Wal would not ever have said anything as silly as that, given the knowledge that he would have of aviation matters.

PARA.TAB: One of the things that Wal was not able to do at the time was to identify a second airport site in Sydney. That was a privilege which fell to me when I happened to be minister for aviation and we identified the Badgerys Creek site after years of both sides of politics being completely incapable of arriving at a conclusion as to where Sydney's very necessary second airport ought to be. But I can tell you one other thing about the close space parallel runway: it would have made no difference in any of these noise profiles at all. If you sit down there and think your way through logically these propositions, you can see how absurd that proposition is unless you are going to play God and totally change the wind system of Sydney. The one great problem about that close space parallel runway was that it was so close that, unfortunately, you got into the position where you could not increase the usage of the runway at least to the levels of the cross runway carriage. It was a hopeless position to arrive at; nevertheless the opposition of the day managed to arrive at it. What you had out of the solution that the government ultimately arrived at was a workable one.

I am absolutely delighted to be defending Laurie Brereton in this debate. I have been a minister for a very long time now and it has seldom been my privilege to serve with a minister so courageous and so prepared to take the hard decisions and to get stuck into it, to get his hands into the issues of the day and create something from them, create an effective set of outcomes to the problems that he handles—and they are some of the most intractable problems that have confronted governments on both sides of the House over the years. But, in case you want evidence of how meretricious the opposition is in this regard, listen to the hypocrisy of the member for Bradfield (Mr Connolly) clothing himself in the position that he puts forward for his constituents, allegedly, when all the evidence of the problems that we now confront was evidence that was there and thoroughly understood by all of you when the government took this decision.

You talked about a fourfold increase of noise and movement. Where did the estimate of that fourfold increase of traffic movement come from? It was a public document. It was the EIS associated with the original decision taken to build the parallel runway. It was an open public document available to all of you on that side of the House and available to your spokespersons when they made their statements.

Let us have a look at some of these great statements. The Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Tim Fischer) puts forward a wonderful little performance. Let us take a look at what he said on 22 March:

SPEECH.PARA: Environment Minister Ros Kelly has nine days to go before she has to deliver her response to the EIS recommendation that Mascot's third runway be built.
Federal Leader of the National Party Tim Fischer says `D' day is Wednesday 13 November.
"This is the ultimate litmus test for the government to bite the bullet quickly—failure to do so will see Sydney's `gate way' role collapse.
It is two and a half years since the Federal Cabinet approved the third runway . . .
The proposal has withstood the most stringent and critical scrutiny and quite simply it `stacks up'."
This is Timmie boy, the fellow who has been up here asking questions of the transport spokesman in question time when the A team was on, before the B team was put into bat. He went on to say:
ACTU Federal President Martin Ferguson says `one of the reasons the third runway has not gone ahead is because it is a political football'. He is absolutely right.

On 22 March 1989, the Prime Minister Bob Hawke and the then Minister for Transport and Communications, Ralph Willis, in a joint statement said, `The Government has decided to develop a third runway at Kingsford-Smith Airport subject to the satisfactory completion of normal EIS processes . . .
So far the protracted EIS study—
the study that told you how much noise there would be—
has cost over $20 million.
You can't say it was not thorough. The Leader of the National Party continued:
The unassailable evidence before Minister Kelly includes—
all this evidence you have been trotting around as new—
*The fact that fewer people would be affected by aircraft noise. (70% fewer than at present).
*The alternative Badgerys Creek airport would only reach threshold commercial viability after 2005.
*Badgerys Creek would cost $2 billion plus while the third runway would only $273 million.
*The third runway would sustain an additional 36,000 jobs in tourism in NSW and generate an additional $1 billion in GDP.

This is what the opposition said when the decision was taken on the third runway. What canting hypocrites, what a gaggle of pathological exhibits when it comes to this question of whether or not we are to blame.

PARA.TAB: But does it get better? Does the opposition think it knows something about this? I have simply quoted one press release in this wad the Minister for Transport gave me. Let me quote another one—and this is even more classic. The media release is entitled `Near miss at Mascot: there must be no further delay with third runway'. That is the headline. That is from the same source, the National Party leader. It reads:

SPEECH.PARA: Any further delay in deciding on a third runway for Mascot could mean loss of life as well as economic sanity.

Is this the same bunch that is telling us that we ought to operate an east-west runway—against the advice of the CAA on safety grounds—in a full-blown sense across a set of parallel runways? Is this the same outfit that is now arguing that we ought to be doing that sort of thing? If ever you wanted an example of canting hypocrisy, that is one.

PARA.TAB: You have a bit of difficulty with a cross-wind runway operation that produces near misses and out you go, straight to the media, and tell us, `We can't have any more of these near misses. You have to get that parallel runway in place.' What do you think you would be saying about the Minister for Transport now if he had rocked in here a month or two ago, when the third runway was available for use, and said, `Gentleman and ladies of the chamber, I think I might just leave this runway, constructed as it has been, capable of being fully operational, as it is. I shall keep operating this generally conceded rather unsafe cross runway operation until I am absolutely certain that I have got in place all the particular developments at Sydney.'

Do you not think that would now be part of a censure motion against the Minister for Transport? Do you not think now, with all the problems that the CAA has allegedly had and all the investigations under way on safety, that as those opposite move their motion on ANL or whatever—and include it in this censure motion—they would be in this chamber saying, `The CAA puts down a clear-cut position that it is safer to run parallel runway operations, as opposed to running cross-wind runway operations simultaneously, and you haven't opened it, Mr Brereton?' Did you not think that might have been part of the censure motion that might have been moved here today by these canting hypocrites when it comes to dealing with these sorts of issues?

This opposition thinks that everybody in this place has a 24-hour memory. Occasionally those opposite get away with that with the press gallery, but these days information retrieval systems are so much better. These days information retrieval systems allow us to have a cold hard look at what they have had to say over the years and see the canting hypocrisy of their current positions as they produce attacks on the Minister for Transport. Their position on this is a joke. It is a deceit on the people of Sydney.

Let me go to one what of your northern suburban members, the member for Bennelong (Mr Howard), had to say about all this. It is his electorate which is supposed to be affected, next to the honourable member for Bradfield's electorate. What did he have to say about this? Howard condemned the government's attitude—this is when we were not proceeding with the runway. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: It is just a blatant stab in the back and betrayal of Sydney's interests. Sydney is our main tourist attraction and most famous international city. I can't think of anything in terms of our national infrastructure that is more damaging—
that is, not proceeding with that third runway—
It is an awful decision, cheap and parochial.
This is New South Wales ALP right wing cynicism at its worst. The member for Bennelong said:
The coalition had the guts to make the right decision in 1982—
and we have already had a look at one—

when the government stocks were not all that high and the Liberals held Barton and Cook. I have spent quite a lot of time talking to a lot of people and a lot of them understand that by having a third runway, you could, in fact, reduce airport noise.

He said that the people who would get it in the neck if flights in and out of Sydney were rationed would be commuters from the provincial areas such as Tamworth, Dubbo, Orange and Bathurst.That is worth a bit of thought here too, because ignoramuses who were debating this on the opposition side lied to the people of Sydney when they told them—

PARA.TAB: An opposition member interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a censure motion so you can cop it. They told them that they would support opening the east-west runway for a commuter based service, that they would take a bit of a punt that a commuter service on that east-west runway, only using a portion of it, would be able to be capably and safely conducted with a parallel runway in use.

PARA.TAB: There is a better possibility of doing that sort of thing, if that is the road they choose to take. I think that is taking a bit of punt, but it is not impossible. What would be the effect of that? Remember who you are dealing with here. You are dealing with the people who are affected in the northern corridors of the city of Sydney, identified correctly in the EIS, of which you are already aware. The one effect of doing that would be to offer them no relief but to increase heavy jet movements on the two runways. It might be a decision you could take in terms of the efficiency of Sydney airport, but it is not a decision you could take in terms of improving the situation of the people.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I think there ought to be more people to hear this. I draw your attention to the state of the House.
—I will move that the motion be put. (Quorum formed) I move:

PARA.TAB: That the question be now put.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

That the motion (Mr Sharp's) be agreed to.

—Mr Speaker, I wish to make a personal explanation.

—I do.
—Please proceed.

—In the Australian Financial Review of 21 November 1994, on page 67 under the column headed `Rear window', firstly, I was described as the `Liberal member for Gilmore'. This was a grievous insult. Secondly, the article had the audacity to claim that I was `a keen Liberal'—and they do not exist.
—Mr Speaker, I wish to make a personal explanation.

—I am glad to see that the Minister for Finance (Mr Beazley) has walked back into the chamber. TALKER.NAME: Mr PUNCH
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Defence Science and Personnel)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—The world has changed dramatically since the Australian government published its last defence white paper in 1987. We knew then that we were living in a dynamic era, but the nature and the pace of the changes which have since taken place were quite unforeseeable. Of all the changes, the most significant has been the collapse of the Soviet Union. This was a massively important event, which fundamentally changed the global security environment.

PARA.TAB: Almost overnight, the east-west stand-off, which dominated international strategic affairs for 50 years, was no more. No part of the globe was unaffected by this radical change—certainly not Asia and the Pacific. This historic geo-strategic change has been accompanied in the Asia-Pacific region by continued and rapid economic growth. Potentially, this too has enormous long-term consequences for strategic relationships and security in the region.

The government's 1994 defence white paper, Defending Australia, addresses the long-term consequences of these major changes for our defence policy. Defending Australia looks ahead 15 years to provide broad guidance for defence policy making and for the force structure and capability decisions we will have to make. It provides the framework for developing our defence policy through the next decade. Defending Australia is a substantial and complex document. Today I will simply highlight some of the underlying thinking and key themes.

Our starting point is the conviction that Australia must maintain the capability to defend itself against armed attack. Despite all the hopes and aspirations we share for reducing the chances of conflict since the end of the Cold War, military force is still an important element in international affairs, and will remain so. That is a fact of life, regrettably—but a fact nevertheless.

It is also a fact that, while we will do all we can to avoid the use of force ourselves, ultimately, armed force can only be resisted by armed force. We must, therefore, continue to be sure that we can defeat an armed attack on our territory. We have a continent of our own to defend, and a unique set of national interests. We must be self-reliant, with the capabilities to provide for our defence without relying on the combat forces of other countries.

The key judgment in this white paper is that fundamental changes in strategic affairs, both globally and within our region, will make Australia's strategic environment more demanding over the next 15 years. The threat of global war has all but disappeared, but so has the predictable shape which the Cold War imposed on strategic affairs throughout Asia and the Pacific. In its place, a new, more fluid and more complex strategic pattern will emerge.

Security in the region will be shaped by continued high levels of economic growth. The sustained expansion in the economies of most countries is bringing enormous social and economic benefits. It is also increasing the capacity of many countries to modernise and develop their armed forces, and to become more confident and self-reliant in their security. The military capabilities of our regional neighbours are improving, especially through the introduction of higher technology systems. We will also see a growing capacity to sustain and operate these systems.

Australia looks to the future of this region with confidence, and with a strong awareness of the opportunities which Asia offers for our own future. In looking to our long-term security, we will take a positive approach to the region, and to the international defence policies and relationships which support our defence interests. Nevertheless, prudence requires that we maintain the capabilities to ensure our defence self-reliance.

Australia's defence policy, as spelt out in this white paper, recognises our responsibility to help shape our security environment. This requires that we engage closely with our region on strategic issues; that we maintain our alliances with the United States and New Zealand; and that we contribute effectively to multinational security efforts.

Just as Australia's prosperity is strengthened by our economic integration with Asia, so our security will be enhanced by closer strategic engagement. Australia has an active role to play in the evolution of a secure regional environment which reflects our needs and interests, and makes armed attack on this country less likely.

The way we seek to influence this environment will need to evolve as strategic circumstances change. The task will become more challenging as our security environment becomes more complex and more demanding.

We will strengthen our bilateral defence relationships, and actively pursue multilateral approaches to security in the region. In particular, we will foster an accurate understanding of Australia's strategic interests and security concerns. In turn, we will ensure that we understand the perceptions, concerns and capabilities of our neighbours.

At the same time, our alliance with the United States will continue to be a key element of our defence policy. We will work with the United States to ensure that the alliance continues to meet the needs of both parties—both in a strategic sense and in the practical benefits it delivers. We will continue to give strong support to the United Nations and other multinational endeavours which promote global security.

An effective United Nations can help to make war less likely throughout the world by mobilising international action against aggression. Our support for the United Nations therefore makes a direct contribution to our security. It is also through the United Nations machinery that the government is able to respond effectively to humanitarian crises, such as those in Rwanda and Somalia.

Important as these commitments are, we do not structure the Australian Defence Force for them. The ADF has clearly demonstrated that its force structure and readiness levels are sufficient to undertake United Nations tasks, provided the defence budget is supplemented for major contributions.

We will continue to examine each multinational operation on its merits, and evaluate each contribution in terms of our national objectives. Effective arms control measures also contribute directly to Australia's security. Therefore, defence will continue to support the government's policy objectives in relation to global regimes for arms control.

We are also strongly committed to transparency in defence planning in order to build trust and reduce suspicion, especially within our own region. The publication of this white paper is in itself an important trust building measure.

While the government will continue its active pursuit of Australia's international defence interests in these ways, the key message of Defending Australia is that our highest defence priority will continue to be to build, maintain and support forces which ensure we can defeat any armed attack against Australia. We do not believe that any country has an intention to use force against Australia. We have no disputes with other countries which might be expected to give rise to the use of force, and there is also no reason to expect one to develop.

However, disputes can arise and intentions can change relatively quickly. Because military capabilities take many years to develop, it follows that we plan on the basis of capabilities and not threats. Let me repeat that: we plan on the basis of capabilities, not threats.

No country has the capability to seize and hold major territory on our continent. Significantly, we believe that no country plans to develop such forces. To do so would require a very large effort, and we would expect to have substantial warning of any such development. However, the capabilities available to mount lesser levels of attack on Australia will grow over the next 15 years. Such attacks could be very damaging to Australia, and could arise with relatively little warning. The key challenge for defence capability planning will be to adapt to the greater demands posed by increasing military capabilities in such short-warning conflict.

We will continue to use the most cost-effective means to ensure our security. Our planning will exploit Australia's geographic advantages, technological capabilities and wider national resources to ensure we can defend this country. This means giving clear priority to the naval and air capabilities needed to deny our approaches to an adversary.

We must recognise, however, that the development of military technology poses new challenges. Over the longer term, we will need to be more selective about those military capabilities in which we must maintain our technological advantage. We will also use our defence capabilities more efficiently. All elements of the Australian Defence Force will work closely together as an integrated force and make the best possible use of their equipment and facilities. Our ability to draw on wider national resources will grow in importance.

We will seek to integrate a range of civil assets and expertise into our defence effort in order to sustain our capabilities more efficiently. This will provide a wider base for developing and supporting high-technology systems. The effective use of our geographical and technological advantages, backed by the diverse strengths of our national support base, will give Australia a defence posture of greater depth and resilience.

From this key objective flow the main defence priorities set out in Defending Australia. I want to highlight three today. Firstly, high priority will be given to the skilled people we need in the ADF. The Australian Defence Force's tradition of excellence is based on the professionalism of its people.

Our deployments to the Gulf War, Namibia, Cambodia, Somalia, Rwanda and elsewhere have demonstrated this beyond question. We should also acknowledge the great body of unsung work which our forces do every day to ensure they retain the necessary levels of proficiency and preparedness.

The ADF will remain fundamentally dependent on the quality of its people. It is easy to overlook some of the special demands military life places on our people and their families. We must therefore ensure that they receive adequate recognition. While personnel numbers will not increase over the next 15 years, the demands placed on our people by new technology will.

Recruiting and retaining high-calibre people in the Defence Force presents long-term challenges. Over time, we will increase community understanding of defence and encourage greater recognition of the career opportunities that military service provides. In addition, a wide ranging defence review of the principles which underpin ADF personnel policies and procedures has begun and will be completed next year.

Reserves too have a long and proud tradition of service in peace and war. The white paper makes clear that reserves now have specific roles in our operational elements. They form a fundamental part of our total force and provide important links between the Defence Force and the wider community.

Changes in reserve training are being implemented, and a detailed structural review of the army reserve will be carried out next year. This will ensure that our reserves are better equipped, and that their training standards are more closely aligned to those of regular members.

Secondly, the government will emphasise investment in high-technology capabilities which increase our security. We are moving ahead with plans to procure airborne early warning and control aircraft, and we will replace the Macchi lead-in fighters and our ageing transport aircraft.

We will also proceed with new command, control, communications and intelligence networks, new helicopters for our Anzac frigates, new minehunters and new vehicles for the land force. Our six new Collins class submarines, due to come on line in the next few years, will be the most capable, conventional submarines in the world. They are sufficient to meet our forecast needs. We will, however, review the need for additional submarines in the context of the first five-year defence budget in 1996-97. Our existing Leopard tank fleet will meet our needs until at least 2010. Therefore, we will not take up the recent offer to purchase newer Leopards because this would not be cost-effective.

Defence capability development is not just based on acquiring new equipment. In a number of cases, we have the opportunity to enhance our capabilities by upgrading existing equipment and systems. For instance, we will ensure our FA18 Hornet fighter aircraft remain highly effective well into the next century by upgrading their sensors, electronic countermeasures and weapons. We will also undertake major upgrades of Australia's FFG frigates, M113 tracked armoured vehicles, and P3C maritime patrol aircraft.

In our land force, the scope of efficiencies programmed by army will free up the personnel and resources necessary to raise a fifth infantry battalion. This battalion will be formed over the next three to four years.

Thirdly, the government will continue to pursue a more effective partnership between Defence and Australian industry. This is essential to strengthen defence self-reliance over the long term. We look to internationally competitive industries in Australia and New Zealand to supply, maintain and adapt our high-technology defence equipment. We also look to industry to design and manufacture equipment suited to our unique needs.

To encourage and assist our industries to develop the capabilities Defence needs, we have identified a number of changes to the way Defence works with industry. Defence will rely more on the strengths of the commercial sector. We will identify further opportunities for the commercial support program and help industry to acquire more defence related intellectual property.

In addition, we will encourage greater local industrial research and development and, within carefully enforced guidelines, encourage increased international materiel cooperation and defence exports. Our emphasis on a strong partnership with industry will be complemented by the efficient use of Australian defence science and technology to help develop and support our most important defence capabilities.

More broadly, successful national defence requires the closest possible links between Defence and the wider Australian community. This partnership ensures that vital support is available for our defence in peace and in conflict. It also provides major benefits to the Australian community through the ADF's activities in areas such as disaster relief, bushfire fighting, search and rescue, and counter-terrorist support.

Finally, I want to address the issue of resources. National defence can never be done `on the cheap'. More complex and demanding strategic circumstances will place even greater pressure on our defence budget. We cannot escape that.

It is often assumed that by reducing uniformed personnel numbers we reduce our defence capabilities. This is not the case. Defence has recently achieved major reforms which have reduced personnel numbers and costs significantly without reducing capabilities. Personnel costs have dropped from 60 per cent of the defence budget 20 years ago to under 40 per cent today. The government will continue to seek defence reforms and efficiencies.

Nonetheless, we recognise that these savings cannot accommodate all the additional pressures on the defence budget over coming years. Those pressures will arise from the need to meet higher labour costs as ADF skill requirements rise and to sustain the operations needed to keep our capabilities highly effective. At the same time, we must invest in major new equipment and facilities because continual development is essential to maintain our relative level of capability.

The government is determined to sustain defence funding. A long-term commitment is fundamental when capabilities take decades to develop and introduce. We will provide the stability and predictability which is so important to the development and management of long-term projects and activities.

For the next few years defence expenditure at current programmed levels will enable the plans and projects outlined in Defending Australia to proceed. Beyond that, modest real increases will be needed to meet the demands of an increasingly complex defence environment.

The government has considered these issues carefully and responsibly, and is committed to sustaining defence spending at approximately two per cent of GDP. The government has also decided that, from 1996-97, it will provide defence with a five-year budget commitment. This is a historic commitment. It is a decision which will provide an assured basis for long-term planning. This will allow more efficient development of defence capabilities, more effective procurement from industry and better personnel planning and management.

Many areas in Australia contribute to our defence objectives. Defence, in turn, contributes to other national interests. This includes Australia's international security interests, which require very close integration of government policies and approaches.

The relationship between the Departments of Defence, Prime Minister and Cabinet and Foreign Affairs in these areas is especially strong and contrasts markedly with the approach of some 10 years ago. Our commitment to this integrated approach was reflected in the close consultation which occurred during preparation of this white paper.

The decisions we make on crucial resource and other issues over the next few years will shape Australia's defences well into the next century. The government is determined that, in the coming decades, our adaptable, versatile and self-reliant defence effort will effectively safeguard our country. I present the following papers:

TAB.EMPHASIS: Defending Australia: Defence White Paper 1994—Ministerial Statement and Paper, 7 December 1994.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reith Mr P.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I welcome the opportunity to respond to the government's 1994 defence white paper. I do so in my capacity as the opposition defence spokesman representative in the lower house. I endorse the excellent contribution to the debate about Australia's defence policy made by my colleague the shadow minister for defence, Senator Jocelyn Newman, in the Senate this week. I also commend to those interested in the debate the remarks of my coalition colleagues in the Senate, particularly those of Senator MacGibbon.

PARA.TAB: I am pleased to have the opportunity to make a few remarks. I held the defence portfolio on behalf of the coalition for some time, which sharpened my interest in defence policy matters. There is also clearly a link between the portfolio of foreign affairs and defence policy issues. As the coalition's current spokesman on foreign affairs, I believe that it is important to be abreast of the issues and to comment on them.

It is also important to continually monitor and assess developments on major defence issues confronting the country. The end of the Cold War has meant the end of direct and de facto superpower confrontation and the lifting of the pall which the threat of global or large-scale regional war had previously brought to world affairs.

The end of the Cold War has brought with it new but sometimes uneasy balances. It has seen the coincident breakdown of order in the Balkans and in central Asia, just to mention two. There have been some increasing tensions over proliferation of weapons of mass destruction in north Asia, for example, which is in our own region. Also, in our own region, the spectacular economic success of some of Australia's neighbours has underpinned a steady improvement in regional defence capabilities and signals an inevitable end to our claims to continued technological superiority in defence capabilities.

At the same time, there have been stresses and fractures in long established alliances and there have been renewed pressures on the will and the resources of multinational fora, such as the United Nations. These and other developments have raised new uncertainties and new challenges for defence policy makers. Australia is not immune from direct developments in our own region or from the flow-on effects from events further afield. I quote with approval paragraph 1.6 of the white paper, which I think puts it quite well:

SPEECH.PARA: The next fifteen years will see great change in our strategic environment. With the end of the Cold War, important new uncertainties have emerged about the future strategic situation in Asia. Economic growth will increase the power of nations in our region, and political change may make their policies less predictable. Because of these uncertainties, we acknowledge the possibility that our security environment could deteriorate, perhaps quite seriously in the future. We recognise that at some time in the future armed force could be used against us and that we need to be prepared to meet it.

That is a useful summary contained in the early pages of this defence white paper. This is not to say—I do not say—or suggest that Australia suddenly finds itself in a new and threatening environment. But it does mean that the certainties of the Cold War are over and that Australia will have to work hard to promote and secure its own interests in a more fluid and potentially more volatile region. In that context, the coalition does welcome the government's interest in defence and the release of this paper.

PARA.TAB: In February, the government released its long overdue Strategic review 1993. We also welcomed that but made the point that it was rather tardy in coming. In fact, it had merely followed the coalition's earlier policy initiative released in 1992, particularly as it relates to cooperative regional defence. This white paper has been too long in coming, but it is welcome despite that. However, having read it, I am just not sure whether it was worth the wait after all.

It is sometimes stated by defence commentators in Australia that, leaving the Democrats and the Greens aside—you can safely discard them when it comes to sensible debate on these issues—there is a fair degree of common ground between the major parties on defence issues and that differences centre more on the scope and scale of defence preparedness and on issues of portfolio management than on the broad thrust of defence policy.

There is some truth in this argument, but I stress that whilst there is some common ground between the government and the opposition this should not be seen as a guarantee of bipartisanship on defence policy issues. Far from it. There are substantial differences between the government and the coalition. When we read this white paper we find that it highlights our concerns and the differences between ourselves and the government.

For some time now we have held grave concerns about the way capabilities, operational readiness and personnel levels are being whittled down under Labor stewardship. We are concerned about mismanagement and about the size of the defence bureaucracy. We see nothing in this white paper which will sensibly address these issues.

Under Labor, our defence capability has been cut. Under the 1991 force structure review we lost two out of our six regular infantry battalions. The white paper proposes that the army can re-raise one of these battalions, but only by stripping manpower from somewhere else in an already depleted Australian Defence Force. It is a case of robbing Peter to pay Paul when you have already impoverished Paul.
Mr Somlyay interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I can assure the honourable member that I am not referring to the Prime Minister (Mr Keating). The Prime Minister has not been impoverished by his years in office, as his latest purchase of a mansion in Sydney shows. Under Labor our fighter force has been pared from four to three squadrons and we have fewer surface combatants and fewer submarines available for operational service. That is a fact.

PARA.TAB: During Labor's term in office our personnel numbers have dropped by almost 20 per cent. I recognise that some of that has been due to the introduction of the commercial support program. The opposition supports the CSP. I understand that there have been a lot of difficulties with the introduction and implementation of the CSP, but I think the government can go further with the CSP. I say that because I think people join our defence forces to be active in the principal roles of the defence forces and not to be doing those functions which could be contracted out. The opposition is concerned by the fall off in uniformed personnel, especially in combat elements.

Sustainability levels have been shattered as the government trades off stockholding to meet underfunded recurrent expenditure bills. The much touted force structure review initiatives, such as the ready reserve scheme and the commercial support program to some extent, have simply failed to deliver the sorts of efficiencies and savings expected of them. The list goes on and on. There have been delays in the Collins project, mismanagement and debates about the Anzac contract and we have had the ill-conceived ready reserve scheme which I think the government, in its heart of hearts, knows was ill-conceived from the word go. Virtually anybody who has looked at the scheme would come to that conclusion. The opposition has also been worried about the flea market approach to defence purchasing and the insidious erosion of conditions of service.

At the heart of all this is the question of defence funding. In this context, the Minister for Defence (Senator Robert Ray) is not keen to promote debate about defence in this country. I went to a seminar recently where the minister was supposed to speak, but apparently he declined the invitation because he did not want to promote defence policy debate in this country which I think is a great shame. The minister is on the public record back in November 1992 talking about his role as Minister for Defence. When asked a question about defence funding, the minister told the Australian:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . that's how I'm judged (by the Chiefs of Staff)—can I deliver a politically reasonable base funding . . .

Yet in the 1994-95 budget allocations, spending on defence will drop to the lowest level as a percentage of government outlays since the last year of the Whitlam government. By the end of the current Labor term it will fall to the lowest per cent of GDP since before the Second World War. The minister says, `Judge me by whether or not I have the political clout to keep the dollars going into defence,' but on his own criteria he fails miserably. This defence white paper is yet another confirmation of that sorry fact.

PARA.TAB: The failure of the Minister for Defence to meet his own criteria for success as a minister has been recognised by the Labor Left. The incredible thing about Australian politics is that even the Left admits that cuts in personnel and operating costs have been to the detriment of readiness and morale. It put out a paper entitled `The price of peace in an age of uncertainty' which acknowledges:

SPEECH.PARA: Further defence cuts would raise concerns about Australia's capacity to fulfil its national goals in the area of defence self reliance, Foreign Affairs and the promotion of peace.
That is exactly the direction in which this defence white paper and the government's policy is taking us.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Two Per Cent.

—Mr Two Per Cent. Why would anybody believe that the two per cent is going to be maintained anyway? In the last white paper the government told us that it would keep defence spending between 2.6 and three per cent, which is what was necessary to keep the show on the road. Of course, that has been eroded. I have no doubt that the government will erode it further.

PARA.TAB: Commonsense tells me that spending on defence is like writing out a cheque for home insurance. Honourable members know that, every year when they write out a cheque for insurance, they would have second thoughts and say, `I will work on the basis that there will not be a fire this year because there has never been a fire'—I am lucky I have never had a fire burn down any of my homes—but commonsense tells you to keep paying the premium. I believe that when it comes to Australia's defence forces we have to keep on paying the premium. Year in and year out, sadly, this government is whittling away Australia's defence efforts.

At $9.87 billion in 1994-95, defence allocations will fall to 2.1 per cent of GDP. This is $2 1/2 billion dollars lower than if spending were pegged at the 1987 expectations raised by the government of a benchmark figure of three per cent. Clearly, the spending projections in the 1987 white paper have proved to be unrealistic and unsustainable. With the latest white paper imposing a cap of two per cent of GDP, the problem can only be exacerbated.

I will put it in the most simple terms: when the government brought down its defence paper in 1987 it said, `This is what we think we ought to do to defend Australia. This is the personnel and equipment that is necessary.' To achieve that the government would need to spend between 2.6 and three per cent of GDP. That was the way it was going to proceed. It did proceed and proceeded particularly on the capital equipment side. The opposition has supported the government in its commitments to buy new ships, submarines and other sorts of equipment. But the fact is that after it made the commitments it then started to cut back on defence spending. It was committed to various contracts and the like on the equipment side so, when it was short of a dollar, what did it do? It cut into readiness and personnel resources.

We have great people in the Australian Defence Force and I pay tribute to the people who are prepared to serve our country in the defence forces. They have to put up with a hell of a lot. Within the last 12 months I spent a day out on HMAS Adelaide. I was most impressed by the work the captain and entire crew do. I have been to the RAAF base Pearce. You could not meet Australians more dedicated to the future of this country than those in either of those two situations and the Defence Force in general. We are very lucky to have those people.

That imposes an obligation on us to look after those who are prepared to serve their country. Let us look at the pay rates for some of our defence people. We pay some of our defence people so little by way of remuneration, take home pay, that they qualify to go around to Social Security for a welfare payment. That is a disgrace. Unfortunately, that is the reality of defence spending under Labor.

I have said in earlier speeches that it would be tragic for Australia's defence if the white paper simply sets about justifying existing structures and capabilities. It is the old trap of situating the appreciation rather than providing a disciplined analysis upon which defence policy and force structure planning can be solidly founded. Unfortunately, this has proved to be true. This white paper simply recycles the 1987 white paper, the 1991 force structure review and the 1993 strategic review. It offers very little that is new to the debate. It is less a policy review than an apology for the government's failure to fund its last white paper proposals.

I conclude my response, which is a bit limited by nature of the schedule today, with three issues. The first goes to Labor's approach to regional defence cooperation. This government, which prides itself on its understanding of Asia, has not managed to strike the right balance in its proposals for closer regional defence cooperation. The 1994 defence white paper fails to recognise that the development of a sense of strategic community, which is so vital to continued regional stability, rests on a balanced effort to strengthen regional relationships as well as on direct bilateral ties.

In our defence policy document A Strong Australia, released in 1992, the coalition unambiguously supported the strengthening of defence ties in the region under the aegis of cooperative regional defence. Our policy places particular emphasis on the development of defence cooperative arrangements, particularly where these serve to improve stability through transparency and mutual understanding. We were heartened to see that this concept was picked up by the government in the 1993 Strategic Review and were pleased to see its similar acknowledgment in this latest white paper.

The extension of Labor's strategic horizons beyond South-East Asia to North Asia, to include Japan, the Koreas, China and Taiwan, and the Indian subcontinent is also welcome. But, on Labor's record, we doubt whether it will be able to translate its expressions of good intention into effective action. Labor has too often displayed an inconsistency in its dealings with the region and this has, at times, caused some friction. Our relations with Indonesia, Malaysia and Thailand have all been bedevilled by Labor's lack of balance and even-handedness. Sadly, I do not see any relief from this in the latest white paper.

Indonesia, for example, is now touted by the defence minister as our most important relationship. I hope that this does not send confusing signals to our longstanding defence partners in the region—particularly New Zealand, Papua New Guinea, Singapore and Malaysia—who are partners in formal defence arrangements.

Indonesia is important, but other regional players deserve appropriate regard. Relative size and proximity should not be the only determinants of the importance of bilateral relations. The coalition acknowledges the significant role which smaller and less proximate nations also play in promoting regional stability. It views the scope of relationships between regional nations to be no less important than the strength of discrete bilateral relations.

While the government is right to focus on the development of bilateral relationships, it must not lose sight of the need to promote regional, and not just bilateral, cooperation. And it should not overlook the fact that our bilateral cooperative programs also offer opportunities for promoting interaction between regional counterparts. In particular, concurrent attendance by officers from regional nations at courses at our military and academic institutions offers far greater scope for effective and cooperative interaction than a purely bilateral course.

Similarly, we should seek to promote seminars and discussions at the senior policy and strategic levels on a broader than bilateral basis. The bottom line is that we must ensure that our finite defence cooperative resources are put to the most efficient and mutually beneficial use. By mutually beneficial, I mean regional and not just bilateral benefit.

The second matter I raise is a rather specific one, but it is on my mind because I have been reading the papers this morning about the Prime Minister and his interest in foreign affairs matters. It reminds me that the skills you learn as a wheeler and dealer in the New South Wales Right are not always appropriately transferred and applied in the matter of sensitive international relations. I refer particularly to two paragraphs in the defence white paper. The first is paragraph 2.17, which refers to Taiwan. It states in part:

SPEECH.PARA: The relationship between China and Taiwan is likely to evolve in response to political change in both, but in a direction that is not easy to foretell.
I also quote an interesting statement from paragraph 8.29. It states:
In time, opportunities also may arise for constructive contact with Taiwan on defence and security issues.

My attention was drawn to this, not just because of the newspaper reports this morning but also because of the fact that in the last two or three months I have been in both China and Taiwan and there are some very interesting issues which Australian policymakers should be addressing.

PARA.TAB: There has been a continuation of the political liberalisation in Taiwan. When I was there, I was able to see for myself the vibrant democracy at work as elections were being held for the mayoral positions in both Taipei and Kaohsiung in the south, and there was also an election for the position of Governor of Taiwan Province. It is interesting that, in the outcome, the DPP was successful in wresting the mayoral position in Taipei from the ruling party. The interest in that is that this is yet another signal of the development of a multi-party political system in Taiwan.

Taiwan has an interesting history. When I was there, the KMT was enjoying its 100th anniversary. The KMT has had a chequered past—I think that is a fair comment to make—but it is very interesting to see in Taiwan the unilateral handing over of political power by a monopolist political party to establish a multi-party, democratic system. It is a matter of great tribute to the leaders of the society in Taiwan that those who have held power have been prepared to share power and to establish a democratic system.

TALK.START.PARA: —It has taken a long time.

—It may well have, but there are others in the region for whom it is taking longer. Let us give credit where credit is due. This political development is reflected in that earlier quote from the defence white paper.

PARA.TAB: The second development there is the economic development, which is also picked up in various reflections in the defence white paper. You have to hand it to Taiwan. The fact is that 35 years ago it was an aid recipient with per capita incomes of $200 or $300. Now it has a per capita income of $7,000, and it is still growing at a very considerable rate. You come back from a place like Taiwan and you say, `It's great to be home.' But the second reaction is: `What a comparison.' Taiwan has foreign reserves of $US90 billion compared with our foreign debt of $160 billion. It has high rates of growth, and it is not talking about jacking up taxes because of the current account constraint—the same old boom-bust recession problem that we have in Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —This doesn't have anything to do with defence.

—It has a lot to do with defence. Minister, perhaps you have not been following the issues for very long, but the fact is that our defence policy is interdependent with both our foreign affairs policy and our economic policy.
—He hasn't even read his own paper.

—Exactly. I thank the member for Groom for his interjection. Ultimately, as this defence paper makes very clear, if Australia cannot maintain its economic base, our position in the region is relatively disadvantaged. I pay tribute again to the economic success of Taiwan.

PARA.TAB: The third point I make is that I am very pleased that the government has picked up many of the proposals made by the coalition to improve the relationship between Australia and Taiwan. This has occurred within the existing political framework, which is quite appropriate. Those improvements have been made and that has been very positive and beneficial for both sides of the relationship.
Lastly, I commend the work of Colin Heseltine and those others who provided me with assistance when I was in Taipei. I conclude by quoting paragraph 2.8 of the defence white paper. In part it states:

SPEECH.PARA: The successful initiation of APEC and the ASEAN Regional Forum shows that the region can agree on broad goals. These developments give grounds for optimism. However, ethnic and national tensions, economic rivalry, disappointed aspirations for prosperity, religious or racial conflict, or other problems could produce an unstable and potentially dangerous strategic situation in Asia and the Pacific over the next fifteen years.

That is the rhetoric of the government. I think the sad thing about the defence white paper is that, having painted a not unrealistic scenario for the future, the government has not backed that up with the resources necessary for the ADF to ensure that we can meet the situation which the government believes we will face.

PARA.TAB: I conclude by saying that we welcome the release of the defence white paper. We are disappointed in its substance and hope that the government takes these concerns more fully into account in the future.
