TALKER.NAME: Mr BRERETON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister for Transport)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That this House:

SPEECH.PARA: (1)congratulates the International Labour Organisation (ILO) on the 75th anniversary of its foundation and on the 50th anniversary of the adoption of the Declaration of Philadelphia;
(2)notes that Australia was a founding member of the International Labour Organisation when it was formed in 1919 with 45 member states;
(3)notes that on this anniversary, as a result of the ongoing international support for the Organisation, there are now 171 member states;

(4)recognises and appreciates the uniqueness of the Organisation within the framework of UN specialised agencies by way of its tripartite structure, which enables governments, employers and workers to participate directly in its activities;

(5)reaffirms its support for the important role played by the ILO as an international forum dedicated to the objectives of promoting and raising labour and social standards with a view to advancing social justice and ensuring world peace; and

(6)wishes the ILO continued success in building links of friendship and understanding through the improvement of working conditions, general welfare and the human rights of working people and their families throughout the world.

Australia was a founding member of the ILO in 1919 and has been an active participant in the ILO throughout its 75-year history. I am pleased to say that the ILO has always enjoyed bipartisan support in this country. Throughout the world governments of all political persuasions have recognised the importance of the ILO and supported its work.

PARA.TAB: Since 1919, the membership has grown from 45 countries to virtual universal membership by 171 countries today. I am particularly pleased to note that South Africa is the newest member. South Africa rejoined the ILO this year after a 30-year absence following the election in April of President Nelson Mandela's government of national unity.

The ILO can count among its many achievements the vitally important contribution it has made to overcoming the abhorrent regime of apartheid in South Africa. The ILO was founded on the belief of social justice and to provide basic human rights for working people. The ILO's mandate, reflected in its constitution and in the 1944 Declaration of Philadelphia, continues to be as relevant today as it was at the time of its adoption. It includes respect for human rights, decent living standards, humane working conditions, employment opportunities and economic security.

The ILO can boast a commendable record in fulfilling its mandate. It can truly reflect on its 75 years and say that it has been a most effective international organisation. That is an assessment not just of this government but of many leading world figures. On the occasion of the award of the Nobel Peace Prize to the ILO in 1969, the Chairman of the Nobel Committee said:

SPEECH.PARA: There are few organisations that have succeeded, to the extent that the ILO has succeeded, in translating into action the fundamental moral idea on which it is based . . . Working earnestly and untiringly, the ILO has succeeded in introducing reforms that have removed the most flagrant injustices in a great many countries . . .

His Holiness, Pope John Paul II, when he gave an audience to the chairman of the ILO governing body in 1992, congratulated the ILO for putting social dialogue and tripartite cooperation at the forefront of its considerations.

PARA.TAB: President Nelson Mandela, in contributing to the volume of essays entitled Visions of the Future of Social Justice on the occasion of the ILO's 75th anniversary, wrote:

SPEECH.PARA: The present situation in South Africa, where a majority of the population is trying to rectify the experience of generations of systematic exclusion from the most basic rights and benefits, highlights the ongoing relevance of the ILO mandate. Many South Africans are only now recognising that lasting peace can be established only on the basis of social justice, 75 years after it was expounded as the founding principle of the ILO.
Through the adoption, ratification and application of international labour standards by member states, the ILO's relevant is continually reinforced.

PARA.TAB: Australia has ratified 54 of the ILO's 175 conventions, including the fundamental standards concerning freedom of association, abolition of forced labour, discrimination of employment, equality of opportunity and tripartite consultation. These standards have played a very significant role in improving employment conditions for all of Australia's working men and women.

Our landmark Industrial Relations Reform Act has, for the first time, given all Australian workers access to key minimum standards based on ILO conventions. It opens the way for Australian workplaces to become more productive and more internationally competitive. It does so within a secure framework of comprehensive minimum standards underpinned by the award system and complementary entitlements based on relevant international standards.

Ratification of ILO conventions has advanced the rights of workers throughout the world across a very broad spectrum. The fundamental conventions on freedom of association, forced labour and quality of opportunity, have now been ratified by well over 100 countries. Together they constitute a vital safety net of industrial protection. The fact that ratified ILO conventions are binding has also helped in countries where there has been a chance of their slipping backwards and adopting regressive legislation. However ILO conventions are by no means rigid, inflexible or overly prescriptive documents. The ILO assesses the need to revise its conventions on an ongoing basis. This ensures that they remain compatible with the realities of modern labour markets. Through its conferences, meetings and technical cooperation activities, the ILO is constantly exposed to the reality of the changing labour market conditions in each and every one of its 171 member states.

This experience is invaluable in assisting those member states in their implementation of conventions, in the development of new standards, and in the revision of existing standards. The full and independent participation of employer and worker organisations in the work of ILO also ensures that standards are kept up to date. More broadly, the ILO is uniquely placed to play a major part in improving social and labour conditions, as it is the only tripartite institution at an international level.

The government is presently evaluating several ILO conventions concerning basic human rights, occupational health and safety, and a range of other issues. A number of these conventions are included in Australia's national action plan on human rights, released earlier this year. Our target is to ratify the conventions progressively over the next five years. We will pursue this objective in full consultation with the states and territories, with employers and with the trade union movement.

The government is also consulting with the states and territories concerning the possible ratification of ILO convention 169 on indigenous and tribal peoples. This international agreement is the only international convention which exclusively deals with the rights of indigenous peoples. Consultation with Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander organisations is also a fundamental precondition to the ratification of this important international convention.

There has sometimes been ill-informed comment about how Australia's sovereignty is affected by our international obligations and about the effect of conventions on states rights. The ratification of ILO conventions is a decision that each member of the ILO takes in the free exercise of its own sovereignty. In determining whether to become a party to a convention, successive Australian governments have considered whether the relevant convention is consistent with our national interests.

Ratification creates binding international obligations on Australia to recognise and to apply in law and in practice the provisions of the ratified convention. The ILO has a well developed system of monitoring a country's practical application of the provisions of a ratified convention. ILO conventions have normally been ratified by Australia where our law and practice satisfy the convention. Ratification invariably follows extensive consultation with state and territory governments and the peak employer and union bodies through the National Labour Consultative Council.

With the increasing globalisation of the world of work, the ILO's basic principles and standards of freedom of association are more relevant today than they ever have been. This is particularly true in the Asia-Pacific region, where many countries are looking to work in partnership with the ILO to establish plans for technical cooperation in labour law, labour relations, employment promotion and training.

There is a growing awareness in Australia of the need for a closer, more cooperative relationship between Australia and the countries of our region. We are strongly committed to playing an active role in promoting economic and social development of the region in many fields, and that includes employment and labour issues.

A joint Australian-ILO project is assisting the governments of eight South Pacific island countries to improve the standards of their own policy and administration and, in the process, to significantly lift the productivity of their work forces. This project commenced in 1990 and has been highly successful, achieving higher levels of workplace safety and health and more cooperative industrial relations. It has been widely acclaimed by all parties and has been independently evaluated by Coopers and Lybrand, which described it as `an excellent example of effective development assistance in the South Pacific'.

A second project with the ILO commenced in February 1993. It is a tripartite project involving Australian advisory and training services to provide assistance to labour ministries, trade unions and employer organisations in Indonesia, China, Vietnam, Thailand and Malaysia. Although only in operation for some 18 months now, it is a program that is already having a substantial and positive effect. Most importantly, it has established an internationally acceptable model by which Australia can play a constructive role in the very sensitive area of labour rights and standards. To build on these efforts, we have established an Asia Desk in the Department of Industrial Relations. It is aimed at strengthening our focus on assisting the development of sound industrial relations throughout the Asia-Pacific region.

The government has provided funds in this year's budget to support our industrial relations initiatives in Asia and particularly our role in implementing our memorandum of understanding on industrial relations cooperation with Indonesia, a memorandum that we signed in November last year. I am also pleased that we will be working with the ILO to assist its programs in our region on combating the exploitation of children at work.

Let me conclude by saying that I believe the ILO needs to continue to play a key role in guiding and influencing international social policy development. It is uniquely well placed for this, given the universality of its membership, its tripartite structure, its machinery for development and supervising standards, its principles, its values and its 75 years of operational experience. International organisations are strong and effective only if they are supported by their constituents. In Australia, the political parties and the social partners have firmly supported the ILO's principles and its work throughout its 75-year history.

The ILO conference this year unanimously adopted a resolution which called on all member states and employers' and workers' organisations to reaffirm the principles and fundamental values upon which the ILO was founded. I trust that the House, in adopting this motion, will join with the international community in reaffirming our support for the vital work of the ILO in advancing social justice and human rights of working people and their families throughout the whole world.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Charles Mr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The opposition joins with the Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister for Transport (Mr Brereton) in congratulating the International Labour Organisation, the ILO, on the 75th anniversary of its founding. There is no doubt that the ILO has performed a very valuable service and is a very respected organisation in world social and equity terms.

PARA.TAB: The International Labour Organisation was founded in 1919 under the Treaty of Versailles. After World War I, representatives of countries present at the peace conference framed a Constitution and an Enumeration of Principles for the International Labour Organisation. These texts would become Part XIII of the Treaty of Versailles. The organisation was formed to improve labour and social conditions. For example, the preamble states:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . universal justice and lasting peace can be established only if it is based upon social justice . . .
Right from its inception, the ILO has encouraged all nations to join its organisation. According to the preamble:
The failure of any nation to adopt humane conditions of labour is an obstacle in the way of other nations which desire to improve the conditions in their own countries . . .

The 42 members of the League of Nations, including Australia, were the founding members of the ILO. Germany was admitted to the organisation in 1926 and the United States in 1934. It could well be said that the operations of the ILO—certainly through the early years—were dominated by European nations and by the developing culture in Europe of a social partnership between labour and capital. The idea emerged and then became the foundation of bureaucratic institutions—including the ILO—in such countries as Austria and Germany, where social compacts led to very heavily bureaucratised industrial relations systems. In such cases legislation is often not needed because all work practices are frequently sorted out before such issues ever even reach government. They are sorted out through total bureaucratic mechanisms.

PARA.TAB: It has been said recently that highly centralised industrial relations systems, such as those throughout much of Europe, are reasonably efficient. It is also said that highly deregulated industrial relations systems, such as the one found in the United States, are relatively efficient. But Australia, caught in this time warp in the middle of deciding whether or not we will be highly regulated and centralised or whether we will be deregulated and open, is caught in a problem with makes us less efficient than either one of the others.

While we have always supported the ILO and continue to do so, it causes some difficulty. One difficulty we have is the way this Labor government selectively uses ILO conventions through the external affairs power of the constitution to back legislation which otherwise would offend the constitutional powers of the various states. The Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Brereton) in his speech to the House a few moments ago talked about sovereignty. He talked about maintaining the sovereignty of Australia through the links of our international treaties. What the minister forgets is that we are giving away a portion of our sovereignty, we have reduced our sovereignty, by allowing international bureaucratic organisations to an extent to make laws which under other circumstances we might not have made.

I was pleased to hear the minister say that when he considers Australia signing and ratifying a number of conventions for the government he will consult widely with the states, with employers and with union bodies. I trust that he will live up to that statement, that he will consult well and that he will seek the agreement of the states before he signs such instruments on behalf of all the Australian people.

Two examples come to mind of where this government has used conventions, I believe quite improperly, to override the powers of the states. The first recent example was when the Minister for Industrial Relations used ILO convention 137, signed and ratified in 1974, 20 years ago, a convention that we have had no need to use for some considerable time because it dealt with the issue of containerisation in the ports. The minister attempted to use that convention to allow the waterfront union movement through the finance committee to reintroduce employer levies and pooling of employees to create once again a register which the Waterfront Industry Reform Authority had attempted to do away with.

The second instance is the Industrial Relations Reform Act, which came into being on 30 March this year as an amendment to the Industrial Relations Act. The minister spoke of that briefly, talking about using the ILO convention to give every Australian worker minimum rights of protection guaranteed. But he has used the ILO convention to override what are state rights. They are written into the constitution as the rights of the states to make laws with respect to industrial matters except where a dispute occurs crossing the borders of two states, in which case the Commonwealth has jurisdiction. So the minister has improperly, in my view, used ILO conventions to legislate to enable his legislation to override state legislation because there was no other way under the constitution that he could do it.
One area of concern where we differ with the ILO is the issue of freedom of association. The Universal Declaration of Human Rights, article 20(2) states:

SPEECH.PARA: No one shall be compelled to belong to an associa tion.

I believe very strongly in freedom of association. People in our country—hopefully everyone in the world—should have the right to belong or not to belong to any organisation that they choose: a union, a management organisation, a community organisation, any kind of organisation. One of our basic rights should be freedom of association. Article 22 of the International Covenant of Civil and Political Rights states:
Every person has the right to freedom of association with others, including the right to form and join trade unions for the protection of that person's interests.
But ILO convention No. 87, article 2, says simply:

Workers and employers, without distinction whatsoever, shall have the right to establish and, subject only to the rules of the organisation concerned, to join organisations of their own choosing without previous authorisation.
Convention No. 98, article 1, in part says:
Workers shall enjoy adequate protection against acts of anti-union discrimination in respect of their employment.

I agree with the sentiments expressed in those articles absolutely. But the ILO does not go on in any of its articles, in any of its conventions, to define the right that a worker or an individual shall also have, an equal right, not to belong to a union of trades—`shall have the right not to belong'. That is a very important difference in principle which we on this side of the House hold dear and which those on the other side of the House, with a Labor government that is indebted to the trade union movement and to the trade union organisations, will not endorse in any way.

PARA.TAB: The minister talks about the tripartite nature of the ILO. I wish to bring to the attention of the House that in Australia, as in the majority of industrialised nations in the Western world, the rate of union membership is once again falling. A recent article defined, and the Australian Bureau of Statistics has confirmed, that in August 1993 union membership was down to 37.6 per cent of the work force compared with 39.6 per cent in August 1992. The unionisation rate at that time in the private sector was 27.5 per cent compared with 29.4 per cent in August 1992. The rate of decline in the public sector was higher, with the proportion of public sector employees who were union members down from 67.1 per cent in 1992 to 64.4 per cent last year.

So all categories of union membership are showing falls. That is because of two factors. One is that unions are finding that they are less and less relevant to the needs of employees in workplaces, who today feel much more inclined to negotiate their industrial issues, their pay structures and their working conditions directly with their employer. So the two of them can work together to achieve a highly productive and high quality outcome for their firm.

According to the AAP this morning, the New South Wales Labor Council Secretary Peter Sams has warned that the union movement is in danger of losing its power to lobby government. The ACTU executive meeting in Melbourne this week was told that union membership affiliated with the ACTU had fallen over the last year by 400,000 to 2.4 million. Mr Sams evidently told guests at a breakfast meeting in Sydney this morning that the correct number was more likely to be closer to two million. That is a fall of 800,000 in a very short period. Mr Sams said it was vital that a new membership drive succeed. He stated:

SPEECH.PARA: `If we can't do it now in 1995 with an improving economy and good employment growth then we are never going to do it and we will end up as a rump, as an unrepresentative group of people that meet from time to time and create a bit of ruckus', Mr Sams said. `But we won't actually have a major representation or a major representative organisation in which we can lobby government for the things we believe in. I think unless we address that issue and address it wholeheartedly in 1995, then we will be in for a very long period in which our influence will be marginalised.

The tripartite nature of the ILO, about which the minister spoke so eloquently, is in danger in Australia from the union movement destroying itself because of its lack of relevance to a modern work force dedicated to improving productivity, improving wage rates and improving the lives of those who work for Australia's industry.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.

PARA.TAB: That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, the following proposed works be referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works for consideration and report: Construction of a new building complex for the Australian Geological Survey Organisation at Symonston, ACT.

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian Geological Survey Organisation, AGSO, currently occupies a number of buildings, the largest of which is the Anzac Park East offices on Constitution Avenue, where it has been since 1965. Most, if not all, accommodation is unsuited to the functional and operational requirements of AGSO and a new special purpose designed and built complex will provide for the consolidation of AGSO's functions. The need to vacate Anzac Park East is a result of advice from regulatory authorities that AGSO laboratory operations should not continue in the building because existing facilities contravene fire regulations, do not comply with laboratory construction codes and contain serious OH&S deficiencies.

PARA.TAB: The project involves construction of a three-storey building comprising laboratories and related areas, offices and administrative support areas, storage areas, staff amenities, engineering workshops, roads, car parking, civil works and landscaping. The proposed building is to be located on a green field site of approximately 20 hectares in Jerrabomberra Avenue, Symonston, ACT, adjacent to the Therapeutic Goods Administration complex in Narrabundah Lane. It is anticipated that construction will commence in early 1996 with completion in 1998. The limit of cost for the project is $114 million at December 1994 prices. I table supporting drawings and commend the motion to the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —I simply ask the minister: is that money already appropriated and, if so, from where?

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, the following proposed works be referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works for consideration and report: Construction of a multi-level car park for the Federal Airports Corporation at Melbourne Airport.

SPEECH.PARA: Melbourne airport is the second busiest in Australia. It is subject to continuing growth in passenger movements and, as a consequence, the present short-term car park is suffering severe congestion and frequent closure. As this growth in passenger numbers is forecast to continue for the foreseeable future, it is necessary for the corporation, in order to provide an appropriate level of service to its customers, to increase the capacity of the short-term car park. As it is desirable that short-term car parking spaces be provided as close as possible to the terminal, it is preferable that the increased capacity be provided in a multi-level structure adjacent to the passenger terminal, rather than through further ground level parking.

PARA.TAB: The proposed work involves the construction of a four-level, open-sided concrete car park, consisting of a covered ground level of 20,869 square metres, three suspended decks, including the open roof level, totalling 58,665 square metres, and a ground floor open car park of 23,500 square metres. It also includes: associated facilities, such as office facilities for car rental companies and police; accommodation for some high vehicles, including small buses; lifts and stairs; pedestrian bridges; goods loading dock; and landscaping and plantings. The project is planned to be completed in two stages. The first stage is expected to be in operation within eight months of the commencement of construction with the second stage following about 15 months later. I table the attached drawings. I suggest that if the honourable member for Mackellar (Mrs Bishop) is interested, this being a Federal Airports Corporation project, the appropriation is probably within that portfolio. I commend the motion to the House.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walker The Hon F.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, the following proposed work be referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works for consideration and report: Maralinga rehabilitation project, SA.

SPEECH.PARA: This project is being conducted by my department. The Maralinga and Emu sites are located in South Australia in the region north of the Nullarbor Plain. Maralinga is 270 kilometres north-west of Ceduna. Emu is 190 kilometres north-east of Maralinga. Between 1953 and 1963, Great Britain conducted several programs of nuclear warhead development trials at Maralinga and Emu. These included detonations of nine nuclear weapons and hundreds of so-called `minor trials' that dispersed radioactive materials. The former test site areas are contaminated to various levels with plutonium and other artificially produced radioisotopes that present an unacceptable risk to future users of the sites.

PARA.TAB: In 1969 Britain undertook a program of clean-up works called Operation Brumby. The 1985 royal commission into British nuclear tests in Australia concluded that Operation Brumby was inadequate, based on wrong assumptions and left the area in a more difficult state for any further clean-up. The royal commission concluded, inter alia, that action should begin immediately to effect a clean-up of Maralinga and Emu to a level where they are suitable for unrestricted habitation by the traditional Aboriginal owners.

A technical assessment group, TAG, was formed in February 1986 to address technical matters stemming from the royal commission. A three-year program of scientific and engineering studies by TAG developed a range of rehabilitation options and comparative costs. TAG's report was tabled in parliament in 1990.

During 1990, the Commonwealth government agreed on a preferred rehabilitation option for the Maralinga test sites as a basis on which to seek a substantial contribution to rehabilitation works from the British government. This clean-up option is the lowest cost option developed by TAG that would enable Aborigines to resume access to the former test site areas. It is intended that upon completion of the project the test site area will be returned to South Australian control for addition to the Maralinga Tjarutja freehold lands.

In December 1993, the Australian and British governments concluded an agreement under which Britain will pay #20 million in an ex gratia settlement of Australia's claims concerning the British nuclear test program in Australia. This amount will be paid in six annual instalments. The first instalment of #5 million was paid in December 1993. The proposed clean-up will reduce the radiological hazards at the test sites to enable Aboriginal use of and transit through the test site area, reduce and possibly eliminate the need for control and surveillance of the sites and remove potential Commonwealth liabilities arising from site contamination.

The majority of the works will be undertaken at Maralinga, including: installation of a construction camp at Maralinga village; upgrading of general site infrastructure; construction of burial trenches; collection of contaminated soil and placement in burial trenches; stabilisation of material in selected debris pits and removal of contents from other debris pits to burial trenches; and general clean-up and surface restoration and revegetation of disturbed areas.

Work at Emu will involve the ripping up of roads to discourage access to the site. All work in the contaminated areas of the site will be undertaken under strict controls. It is anticipated that work will commence in mid-1995 for completion in late 1999 at an estimated cost of $104.4 million at November 1994 prices. I would not recommend the committee attend this particular site until after the restoration is complete. I commend the motion to the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wonder whether I missed all the costings for those three other proposals, Nos 8, 9 and 10. Through you, Mr Deputy Speaker, I would make a comment: I think it would be helpful to the parliament to know the cost of all the proposals that are going off to the Public Works Committee, just as it would be useful to know the costings for all the proposals that will be dealt with soon, having been approved by the Public Works Committee.

SPEECH.PARA: This proposal relates to the Defence Force structure review, which was announced by the Minister for Defence (Senator Robert Ray) on 30 May 1991. PARA.TAB: APIN stage 1 was considered by the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works on 26 August 1992, and approved by parliament in November 1992. PARA.TAB: That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, it is expedient to carry out the following proposed work which was referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works and on which the committee has duly reported to Parliament: Development of 2nd Field Hospital at Enoggera, Qld.

SPEECH.PARA: The 2nd Field Hospital is a new army unit formed by the amalgamation of the existing 1st Military Hospital at Yeronga and 2nd Field Hospital at Kelvin Grove. This proposal, which was referred to the Public Works Committee on 29 June 1994, is to provide new facilities for the 2nd Field Hospital at Enoggera to replace the inadequate facilities at Kelvin Grove and Yeronga.

PARA.TAB: The Public Works Committee, in its report tabled on 15 November 1994, concluded that there is a need for the project and commended `the dedication of the staff of the 1st Military Hospital, Yeronga and 2nd Field Hospital, Kelvin Grove who are presently working in old timber, metal and asbestos clad buildings which provide inadequate working conditions and lead to operational inefficiencies'. While recommending that the project proceed, the committee also recommended that `the Department of Defence continue discussions with ACROD access and mobility committee concerning access provisions at the 2nd Field Hospital'. The Department of Defence agrees and will comply with this recommendation.

The project involves construction of a modern hospital to include facilities for the field hospital equipment and static health care services. It is anticipated that work will commence in January 1995 for completion by December 1996, at an outturn cost of $29.2 million. I would like to thank the committee for its support. TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

TAB.TAB: That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, it is expedient to carry out the following proposed work which was referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works and on which the committee has duly reported to Parliament: Upgrading of accommodation at HMAS Watson, NSW.

SPEECH.PARA: The existing facilities at HMAS Watson date from 1870, but most buildings currently used were constructed in the mid-1950s and need to be upgraded or expanded to meet current accommodation standards. The proposal, which was referred to the Public Works Committee on 29 June 1994, involves the provision of new or upgraded living-in accommodation for 346 service personnel, additional office space and classrooms, improved recreational facilities and additional parking space.

PARA.TAB: The Public Works Committee, which tabled its report on 17 November 1994, has concluded that there is a need for the project and has recommended that the project proceed. However the committee has made a number of recommendations regarding restoration of bushland in areas near the Sydney Harbour National Park boundary, investigation of an alternative route for the bicentennial coastal walkway, and to address the concerns of local residents about master planning and management of the base and possible visual intrusiveness of a number of buildings.

The Department of Defence agrees with the committee's recommendations and all will be implemented. Construction is expected to commence early in 1995 for completion by December 1996, at an estimated outturn cost of $18.81 million. I would like to thank the committee for its support. I commend the motion to the House.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walker The Hon F.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, it is expedient to carry out the following proposed work which was referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works and on which the committee has duly reported to Parliament: Housing development at Bligh Park, NSW.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bligh Park estate is located about seven kilometres from the Richmond RAAF base. The residential development is being carried out by a joint venture involving Hawkesbury Council and Landcom, which is the residential property development section of the Property Services Group of the New South Wales state government. The proposal, which was referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works on 29 June 1994, is to provide suitable accommodation for defence personnel who are at present living in substandard accommodation at Hobartville.

PARA.TAB: The Public Works Committee tabled its report on 16 November 1994 in which it concluded that there is a need for the project and recommended that the project proceed. The committee also recommended that `the Defence Housing Authority continues to encourage the planting of native trees and shrubs on its housing developments'. The Defence Housing Authority agrees and undertakes to comply with the recommendations of the committee.

The proposed work involves the purchase of 50 residential allotments and the construction of 50 houses thereon at an estimated cost of $8.5 million. It is anticipated that construction will commence in February 1995 for completion in September 1995. I would like to thank the committee for its support, and I commend the motion to the House.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walker The Hon F.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, it is expedient to carry out the following proposed work which was referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works and on which the committee has duly reported to Parliament: Midlife upgrade of Blamey Barracks, Kapooka, NSW.

SPEECH.PARA: The objective of this proposal is to upgrade facilities at Kapooka to extend the life of the barracks for a further 25 years. In its report, the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works endorsed the need for the upgrade and noted that the present working and living conditions are below standard and that some facilities do not meet building codes or occupational health and safety requirements.

PARA.TAB: The works involve the renovation of a number of buildings including eight recruit accommodation buildings, two staff accommodation buildings and the recruits' mess and canteen. Other buildings to be incorporated in the refurbishment are the military instruction building, cinema and office space for training staff. Two small residential accommodation buildings will also be constructed as part of the project.

While recommending that the project proceed, and commending the Department of Defence on its willingness to liaise with members of the building industry concerning the proposed works at Kapooka, the committee also recommended that `the Department of Defence continues discussions with the building industry in Wagga and proceeds with its intention of conducting a seminar for the building industry to discuss forms of contract and tendering processes'. The Department of Defence is complying with this recommendation.

The committee also complimented the Department of Defence on its reuse of waste water at Kapooka. It recommended that it `continues to investigate the possibility of installing water saving devices where appropriate at Blamey Barracks, Kapooka'. This has been noted by Defence, and water saving devices will be considered for each element of the project during the detailed design phase.

It is proposed to commence the works in January 1995 for completion by the end of 1996 at an estimated outturn cost of $21.5 million. The recruit training battalion will continue to be fully functional throughout the refurbishment. I would like to thank the committee for its support, and I commend the motion to the House.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walker The Hon F.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, it is expedient to carry out the following proposed work which was referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works and on which the committee has duly reported to Parliament: Upgrade of transonic wind tunnel at DSTO Fishermens Bend, Victoria.

SPEECH.PARA: The Defence Science and Technology Organisation's Aeronautical and Maritime Research Laboratory, AMRL, is headquartered at Fishermens Bend, which is located about seven kilometres west of the central business district of Melbourne in Victoria. This site accommodates most of the laboratory which has as its primary mission the development, maintenance and exploitation of scientific and technological skills in areas central to military aircraft and other air vehicles for the benefit of Australian defence.

PARA.TAB: The proposal, which was referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works on 29 June 1994, is for the replacement or upgrading of a range of components including the compressor system, compressor drive and tunnel test section, and the installation of a new cooling system, a new plenum evacuation system and a new model support system. It is anticipated that construction will commence in May 1995 for completion by February 1997. The Public Works Committee tabled its report on 8 November 1994 recommending that the work proceed at a limit of cost estimate of $12.7 million at December 1993 prices. This equates to an outturn cost of $13.5 million.

While recommending that the project proceed, the report also recommended that an independent study of the desirability of deactivating a second DSTO transonic wind tunnel at Salisbury be carried out under the auspices of the Australian Science and Technology Council. DSTO is addressing this issue and will undertake the recommended action with consultation as appropriate with the PWC. I would like to thank the committee for its support, and I commend the motion to the House.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walker The Hon F.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, it is expedient to carry out the following proposed work which was referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works and on which the committee has duly reported to Parliament: Stage 2 Redevelopment of Royal Military College, Duntroon, ACT.

SPEECH.PARA: This proposal, which was referred to the Public Works Committee on 29 June 1994, will include a new logistics complex and headquarters building along with extensions to the gymnasium, officers' mess, military instruction block and medical centre. The playing fields and ovals will be upgraded along with adjustments to the existing road network to provide safer and more efficient traffic circulation.

PARA.TAB: The Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works tabled its report on 10 November 1994, recommending that the project proceed. The committee also made two further recommendations to which the Department of Defence has responded as follows: `The Department of Defence and the ACT Government should discuss coordination of road construction with a view to the work being undertaken concurrently as soon as possible'.

The Department of Defence has commenced detailed discussions with ACT Capital Works on the staging of the Morshead Drive roadworks and the new entrance road to RMC. Several options are being considered to allow concurrent activity to occur on these two similar projects.

The pilot study of the use of grey water for watering should be monitored carefully and, if no salinity problems emerge, should be extended to encompass all playing fields at RMC and ADFA as well as other defence establishments where practical. An initial assessment of the results from the monitoring program is currently being undertaken. A decision on increasing the use of grey water at RMC will depend upon the results of this assessment process.

It is anticipated that construction will commence in January 1995 and be completed by December 1997 at an estimated outturn cost of $28.7 million. I would like to thank the committee for its support, and I commend the motion to the House.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walker The Hon F.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, it is expedient to carry out the following proposed work which was referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works and on which the committee has duly reported to Parliament: New laboratory complex for DSTO at Salisbury, SA.

SPEECH.PARA: DSTO is the research and development arm of the Department of Defence. Its role is to provide professional and informed advice on the application of science and technology to meet the needs of Australia's defence and security. This proposal, which was referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works on 29 June 1994, is to provide a modern energy efficient research complex to replace the inadequate and greatly dispersed World War II former munitions manufacturing buildings currently in use.

PARA.TAB: It involves the construction of a new building which will accommodate 590 research and support staff and will include new laboratories and associated support spaces, office areas, administrative support facilities, staff amenities, engineering services, car parking, roadworks and landscaping. The public works committee, in its report tabled on 5 December 1994, concluded that there is a need for the project and recommended that it proceed subject to the following recommendations.

Firstly, the Department of Defence should continue the process of consultation with the South Australian government, local councils and relevant authorities concerning planning matters arising from the northern Adelaide defence land use study. Secondly, the Department of Defence should consult with staff associations regarding the revised design and report to the committee about these consultations.

Thirdly, the Department of Defence should review procedures for the testing of systematic designs against user requirements to minimise changes. Fourthly, concurrent with the further development of the proposal, the Department of Defence should undertake, or commission, a study of the impact on staff efficiency and productivity of open planning and other forms of office accommodation.

Fifthly, costs associated with contingencies and escalation should be reduced. Sixthly, a formal framework for consultation between Commonwealth, state and public organisations involved in heritage matters should be established which would enable heritage implications of the proposed development and the wider site to be addressed in a timely manner.

Seventhly, any requirements designed to ensure the heritage integrity of the site should recognise the need for the Department of Defence to operate in an efficient and effective manner as required by the government. Eighthly, when remediation of soil contamination proceeds, the Department of Defence should provide the committee with regular reports about the extent of the remediation work and the costs associated with it.

The Department of Defence agrees to all the above recommendations and will institute measures to conform and, where appropriate, report back to the PWC. Whilst recommending that the Department of Defence undertake a broader study on the effects of open-plan offices on productivity, the committee believes the project should not be held up pending the outcome of the study and therefore recommends that the proposed construction of a new laboratory complex should proceed at an estimated outturn cost of $50.714 million. As can be seen, a great deal of money is being put into the Australian economy which should provide many jobs for Australians.

It is estimated that construction will commence in February 1995 and be completed by mid-1997. I would like to thank the committee for its support and the very special work it did on this particular matter. l commend the motion to the House.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being just past 7.30 p.m., I propose the question:

PARA.TAB: That the House do now adjourn.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to raise the issue of there being a real world outside Canberra. It is time that members of the Keating cabinet came to realise this, got out of their ivory towers in Canberra and had a look at the rest of Australia. I have been prompted to say this because figures just released by the Australian Bureau of Statistics reveal that a Victorian earns an average of $616.60 per week before tax, while a Canberra resident earns $715.40—almost $100 more per week in net disposable income.

PARA.TAB: The latest census data available for Bendigo shows that 49 per cent of the city's earning population receive no more than $230 per week. We can compare that with Canberra residents earning $715.40 and Victorian residents earning an average of $616.60. It is quite obvious that people in the Keating cabinet have not been going out into broader Australia to find out exactly what is happening.

I have here a table of average weekly earnings. The ACT comes right at the top of the list with $715.40, and right down the bottom—although housing is much cheaper there—is Queensland. I have visited the electorate of the honourable member for Fairfax (Mr Somlyay) and I have noted that housing is cheaper there. Victoria is languishing in the middle with $616.60—

TALK.START.PARA: —Where's South Australia?
—South Australia does not fare too well, either. South Australia is at $604.30. So you are $115 behind Canberra. I know that most ministers in the cabinet spend most of their time in Canberra—
—Overseas.

—And overseas. But it is time they got away from Canberra and found out just how the rest of Australia is battling on. What has happened is that high unemployment levels have savaged country areas of Australia. We have had `the recession we had to have'. We have had drought. We have had low commodity prices for rural product. All of these things are reflected in the levels of average income per week. I draw that to the attention of the House. It is time that Mr Keating and his cabinet got out to rural Australia and found out exactly what is happening in the rest of Australia.

—There is nothing worse in public life than a politician willing to scaremonger to win votes, especially when that politician knows his or her scare campaign is based on a lie. Anne Cohen, the Liberal state MP for Badgerys Creek, is now engaged in a malicious and plainly dishonest campaign to scare people in her electorate with respect to the impending development of Sydney's second airport at Badgerys Creek. I wish to place a few facts on the record. Mrs Cohen has issued statements to local papers in my electorate claiming that—
—Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order, in view of the unparliamentary language used by the member for Werriwa, who referred to a campaign of lies.

—I again remind honourable members in this place about language which is appropriate. As Speakers, including me, have ruled about the use of that terminology as directed against a specific member of this place, I again remind members to be careful of their language.
—I mentioned that in the context of a general statement.
—Correct, and that is why you have not been required to withdraw.

—I then went on to talk about Mrs Cohen and her campaign. The fact is that the suburbs of Raby and St Andrews in my electorate are as close to Badgerys Creek and its flight paths as Regents Park is to Mascot. Further, no urban area in western or south-western Sydney is within seven kilometres of the 20 ANEF contour, below which there should be no noise difficulty.

PARA.TAB: There will be no problem at Badgerys Creek, despite the scaremongering of Mrs Cohen and the newly-endorsed Liberal candidate for Macarthur, Charlie Lynn, unless a government decides to build homes next to the airport site. Who was it two years ago in a very consistent campaign that wanted to build 100,000 residential lots through the South Creek Valley sector surrounding the Badgerys Creek airport site? It was Mrs Cohen and the Greiner and Fahey governments. They had on the planning map of New South Wales a 100,000-lot release surrounding the airport site. Now, spurred on by the impending New South Wales election, they have discovered noise as an issue, having advocated 100,000 homes around that airport site.

The master plan and concept for Badgerys Creek has always involved a successful, competitive and well-designed airport serviced by the transport links to and from the airport site and surrounded, most importantly, by industrial land, commercial land, tourist activities and airport related economic use; that is, to have an airport that is efficient, state-of-the-art with a best practice design surrounded by economic land uses. For that reason, the state government should be supporting the accelerated development of Badgerys Creek. It should be supporting—not holding up—the planning of the road and rail access to and from the airport site.

Shamefully, in the middle of 1992, Mrs Cohen had the planning minister, Robert Webster, come out to her electorate and abandon all the planning for the rail link between Glenfield and the Badgerys Creek airport site. That decision, shamefully, has set back the planning for Badgerys Creek by two or three years. As a result, anyone who has a legitimate concern about noise in the inner city will not find the necessary relief because of the New South Wales government.

Further, in September 1992, the state government agreed to meet infrastructure costs of $1.3 billion associated with the development of the third runway at Mascot. When asked by the Minister for Transport (Mr Brereton) for its commitment to the essential road and rail access to and from the Badgerys Creek airport site, the Fahey government said that it would not be spending a cent. It exposed its priorities of a third runway, no curfew in east Sydney and expenditure of $1.3 billion. The first instalment has gone down—$500 million for a Sydney to Mascot rail link. That was its priority for east Sydney.

In western and south-western Sydney, when there is the opportunity for tens of thousands of jobs at a well-planned airport in our region, the state government came up with a commitment of absolutely nothing. There was no financial expenditure on those important transport links. The only policy it has had in the last couple of years was to build 100,000 residential lots surrounding the Badgerys Creek airport site. It has the hide to then come out, with an election pending, to try to scare people.

The Liberal Party has contributed nothing to the development of that airport other than trying to scare people about noise. Shamefully, the newly endorsed candidate for Macarthur has jumped on the bandwagon as part of a low level, shameful tactic by the federal Liberal Party to scare people, knowing it is an absolutely dishonest and total distortion of the truth.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today I was waiting for the censure motion against the Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister for Transport (Mr Brereton) and I could not believe what I heard. To think that the member for Hume (Mr Sharp) and the member for Mitchell (Mr Cadman) would run down to the dispatch box and condemn the Minister for Transport over the third runway when every member of this parliament supported the third runway proposal absolutely astounds me. The hypocrisy of this place is unbelievable. Are some opposition members going to jump up now and say that the opposition has been misrepresented? I am sorry: some opposition members actually were not in the party at the time. But the Liberal Party is as committed to the third runway as anyone else.

PARA.TAB: The third runway is a form of urban vandalism—the opposition is dead right. In Melbourne, the opposition's mate Jeff Kennett is proposing to build an eight-lane freeway through the suburbs of Brunswick and Coburg. He does not give a stuff about the people of the northern suburbs.

TALK.START.PARA: —The member for Wills might watch his language.

—I am sorry. He cares little for the working class people of Coburg and Brunswick. I think he does not even care much for his bourgeois friends out in Essendon because he wants to drive the freeway through their territory as well. What I ask the Liberals to do is stand up and condemn the Kennett government for its act of urban vandalism in the northern suburbs of Melbourne. I know what the Liberals will do. They will not say a word.

PARA.TAB: How do we feel about the Grand Prix and Kennett's actions in building a Grand Prix track? He is riding roughshod over the interests and rights of people in Melbourne. What does the opposition say? Absolutely nothing. Opposition members saw that a political point could be scored in relation to the third runway, so they sanctimoniously jumped to their feet and condemned the Minister for Transport.

What the opposition should be doing is condemning the Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister for Transport for his terrible handling of the Transport Workers Union and his abuse of workers. If the opposition did that the fools might score a few votes from the former Labor voting people. The opposition has been pushed so far to the right that it has not got a clue.

The building of freeways is actually funded and receives tax relief under the Taxation Laws Amendment (Infrastructure Borrowings) Bill 1994. The bill states that eligible infrastructure facilities at present are road transport facilities in Australia that are used for transport of the public or their goods at a charge to them. That is federal Labor policy. Did the opposition ever think that it might score a point by standing up and saying that the federal Labor Party actually agrees with tollways? It should try it some time instead of thinking that what it needs to do is push further to the right. If the opposition leapfrogged the Labor Party it might do a bit better.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Smith Mr Stephen

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a fundamental tenet of democracy that all people are regarded as equal. The fundamental principle of one vote one value is reflected in the Commonwealth Electoral Act and our electoral system. That reflects the tenet of people being equal and their votes being equal. Unfortunately, this is not reflected by the parliament, the electoral act or the electoral system in my own state of Western Australia. Members should be aware that no legislation has ever been enacted in Western Australia without the support of the state colleagues of those opposite. The conservatives have always dominated the Legislative Council in Western Australia, so the electoral system in Western Australia is determined by them.

PARA.TAB: I draw the attention of the House to the recent redistribution of the state parliament effected by the Western Australian government Gazette of Monday, 28 November. The electoral system required by the conservative controlled Legislative Council of Western Australia has the effect of dividing the state into a metropolitan area and a country area. It is interesting to note that of the 1,034,000 enrolled voters at the time the redistribution was effected, over 760,000 of those were in the metropolitan area and over 270,000 were in the country area. There are 34 Legislative Assembly seats allocated in the metropolitan area, so that is 34 for 760,000—an average enrolment of 22,370—and 23 seats in the country area for just over 270,000—an average enrolment of 11,887. Members can see that the vote weighting is two to one.

When you look at the electoral statistics released by the Electoral Commission at the time of the redistribution and then look at the current boundaries on the same electoral system determined by the conservative controlled Legislative Council, you find that the greatest number of enrolled voters in the metropolitan area is in the seat of Wanneroo, which is in the electorate held by the honourable member for Moore (Mr Filing). The current enrolment in that seat is 30,885. The country seat with the lowest number of enrolled voters is Ashburton. That seat has 8,610 voters. So we have nearly a four to one weighting there.

On the new boundaries, the greatest number of enrolled voters in the metropolitan area are in the seat of Belmont. Those 23,511 voters can be compared with the 10,363 voters in the seat of Pilbara. That is before the quotient variant of 15 per cent comes into play. So we can see what those opposite and their state colleagues stand for when it comes to treating people equally.

In the West Australian of Thursday, 1 December, I was very interested to see reference made to the President of the Liberal Party of Western Australia. The article entitled `Honey on a Return Ticket' states:

SPEECH.PARA: Liberal Party State president David Honey went on a strange journey to one-vote one-value and back yesterday.

PARA.TAB: Perhaps the heat got to him, but Dr Honey first declared himself in favour of ending vote-weighting in elections to the Legislative Assembly and then did a back-flip after a chat with Premier Richard Court.

SPEECH.PARA: The article goes on to say:
. . . soon after, Mr Court appeared in the office of The West Australian at Parliament House and said Dr Honey would be calling because he had got it wrong.

PARA.TAB: Dr Honey called within five minutes and said the party supported vote-weighting. He had called back after speaking to Mr Court because he had misstated party policy.

SPEECH.PARA: So that reflects the commitment of the state colleagues of those opposite to vote weighting and electoral system rorting. I must say that I was dismayed to see a few days later in the West Australian of Monday, 5 December that same David Honey, who one minute before he spoke to Premier Court was in favour of a review of the Electoral Act to take away vote-weighting, had this to say under an article entitled `Boundary changes draw Liberal fire':
Liberal Party state president David Honey has attacked the new WA electoral boundaries, saying they are diabolical . . . Dr Honey said the electoral Act needed to be reviewed.
It goes on to report:

Dr Honey said the Government should consider amending the Electoral Act so that the commission could redraw the boundary of the Upper House's Mining and Pastoral Region to take in some of the area covered by the Agricultural Region.

So they want rorts within rorts in Western Australia. They are not committed to people casting equal votes; they are not committed to the basic notion of equality; and they are quite prepared to see a gross malapportionment occur in Western Australia.

PARA.TAB: Mainstream elements of the Western Australian Liberal Party do not believe that people's votes ought to be equal. In fact, half of them do not believe that some people should be entitled to have a vote. An article in the West Australian in August 1992, after the Liberal Party's state annual conference of that year, headed `Plan to end forced voting' states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Liberal Party's annual state conference yesterday backed a call to end compulsory voting in state and federal elections . . . The president of the Canning division, Mrs Ricky Johnston—
who has been a candidate for the seat of Canning on a number of occasions—
. . . said it was not compulsory to actually vote.
She goes on to say:
A compulsory system meant "dregs of society" got a say whereas with voluntary voting only those who were interested actually cast a vote.

So those on the other side of the chamber do not believe that votes ought to be equal. They also believe that people who actually have a vote are the `dregs of society'. No doubt this attitude is adopted largely because their so-called `dregs of society' do not vote for them.

TALK.START.PARA: —It would come as no surprise to members of the House that I am going to talk yet again on the third runway and its effect on my suburb of Kurnell. I must say that as I heard the Minister for Transport (Mr Brereton) speak today my regard for him increased, because he has the influence to say—
—From a very low base, though.

—Of course. I do not deny that at all. I was very impressed today to find that he was able to say that cabinet will be tackling a range of measures in the next day or so—it was all happening tomorrow. So he can move mountains as far as cabinet meetings are concerned.

PARA.TAB: I hope he can move mountains as far as noise over Sydney is concerned. I have some doubt about that. But I would put to him tonight, in view of the fact that cabinet is meeting tomorrow, that the solution to the problem in the area to the south of the north-south runway is simple. We do not have to have planes directed to the north, to the west, to the east—wherever. All we need to have is the flight paths that have existed for 22 years, which were changed on 4 November when the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) opened the new runway. We want those flight paths returned to what they were two months ago.

If that happens, planes will no longer be flying at 800 feet above the suburb of Kurnell, which they have never flown over before, nor will they be flying over the Kurnell oil refinery at 1,000 feet. No airport in the world allows planes to fly over areas at 1,000 feet. Rather than find fault with the Minister for Transport, I say to him, if he should read this paper before the cabinet meeting tomorrow—

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you think he will?

—I would hope he does, because he is reading an awful lot of stuff that comes from this side of the House at the moment. As one of the longest serving members of this House, I must say that I am so impressed—unbelievably impressed—that this Labor government is so influenced by the words and statements of the members of Liberal-National state governments and of the members who sit on the coalition side of this House that it changes not mountains but airports. We are being blamed for the two-year delay on Badgerys Creek, which the member for Werriwa (Mr Latham) cleverly put forward today. I say to him in the kindest and the most friendly of manners: if you think that is going to happen in your term here in this parliament, forget it.

PARA.TAB: As far as the airport in Sydney is concerned, the east and the west of the airport have massive problems. I am not addressing those this week, but I am addressing the problems that are facing the people of Kurnell—an isolated part of my electorate which the member for Kingsford-Smith looks out upon. I tremble to admit to the House that he and I are in fact political neighbours. We meet occasionally in surf club situations—not in football clubs, Mr Speaker, as you and I meet in the area.

I am impressed that, with only 1,800 people there, people have gone to live there with their small families. Why? Because it is isolated from the normal suburbs of Sydney and because they have the advantage of having their own beach. It is a delightful spot which has been totally and utterly ruined by the acts of the last four weeks.

Though I rose and praised the Minister for Transport for moving the cabinet, I sincerely put to him that he can solve one problem very simply in the cabinet meeting tomorrow by returning the flight paths over to the northern part of Sutherland shire to what they were before his leader opened the third runway on 4 November. I will be speaking again this week on this same subject.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Swan Mr W.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —In today's Bulletin, the Queensland National Party made it brutally clear that the Joh campaign rides again. Today in the Bulletin, Joh's offsider and mouthpiece, Mr Ken Crooke—you might recall that Mr Crooke was Joh's press secretary for many years and is the current Director of the National Party in Queensland—described the federal coalition as `wishy-washy'. He described the Leader of the Opposition, the member for Mayo (Mr Downer), as an appeaser. These are fighting words. They are deliberately designed to wound, mock and ridicule the Leader of the Opposition.

PARA.TAB: It is pretty clear that the Queensland Nationals are hell-bent on smashing the coalition at both the federal and state levels. The first shot in this war, in this new Joh campaign, was fired on 15 November when Don McDonald, the President of the Queensland National Party, issued an ultimatum to the Queensland Liberal Party to agree to a joint Senate ticket in that state or face the repercussions. The repercussions of failure to agree to a joint Senate ticket would be three-cornered contests—three-cornered contests in seats like Fisher, Longman and Groom. That ultimatum, which was delivered by the Queensland Nationals to the Liberals, has passed. Today we have what I think is the second shot in that campaign. Today's Bulletin states:
Crooke believes conservative supporters are dismayed by Downer's equivocal stance on the sexual privacy and racial hatred issues.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Crooke says:

If you are going to succeed, people want to know where you stand . . . People are sick to death of this wishy-washy waffle. The coalition needs to define itself clearly on matters of principle—if you straddle the barbed-wire fence, you get hurt in all the wrong places.
Mr Crooke was joined in that campaign by the member for Kennedy (Mr Katter), who had this to say:

A lot of Liberals have been very appreciative of the stand I've taken. Downer is trying to appease small-`l' people in the Liberal Party, but that has antagonised and disillusioned people in the coalition . . . You have got to be a mug to go along with the Labor Party—
like the Liberals. It continues:
If I was in the Liberal party I would be clearly worried about the polls.

The Liberal Party is clearly very worried by the polls. Thinking about those statements, they may not have come from the member for Kennedy; they could well have come from Joh Bjelke-Petersen, and that is the point.

PARA.TAB: The point about these attacks by the member for Kennedy is that they all occurred before. They all occurred in 1987 when the Nationals humiliated their leader at the time, the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair), and pushed him out of the coalition. When is the member for Kennedy going to do that with the current Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Tim Fischer)? When is the push going to come from inside the National Party caucus to really put the pressure on the Leader of the National Party? It is crunch time for the Leader of the National Party as much as it is crunch time for the Leader of the Opposition.

I know what the answer would be to these questions if we asked the member for Fisher (Mr Slipper) or the member for Groom (Mr Taylor). They would say, `Take them on. We can't take any more of these divisive tactics from the National Party. We don't want a repeat of the Joh for PM campaign of 1987. We will stand up to the Nationals.' Because who will be the candidate for the National Party in the federal seat of Fisher at the next election? It will be none other than the son of Joh Bjelke-Petersen—John Bjelke-Petersen. The lad is looking for something useful to do. He needs a job, so he is now intending to make his bid on the back of this new campaign from the Queensland Nationals to split the coalition. The Bjelke-Petersen forces strike back.

In 1987 we had the jack-in-the-box, the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard), who dreamed of being PM, and the Queensland Nationals took it all away from him. Where is the honourable member for Bennelong tonight? Is he up there with the Leader of the Opposition, talking about these divisive tactics from the National Party? Is he out there condemning the National Party? Can we expect him to say something to the press about the Liberal Party and the National Party at another one of those famous doorstops where he does not really talk about anything, does not talk about a leadership challenge? Is he going to come in, stand shoulder to shoulder with the Leader of the Opposition, and repudiate the tactics from the Queensland National Party? If he is not, we all know what he is really up to: that is, he will make his bid in the new year. If we expect him to do that, I would think pigs might fly.

TALK.START.PARA: —I remind the House that the honourable leader to whom Mr Swan referred, Mr Bjelke-Petersen, won in his last election in Queensland with nearly 60 per cent of the vote. If he were still there, he would still be giving that mob a terrible hiding.

PARA.TAB: The farmers of Australia got $164 million off the federal government. Very regretfully, I think a lot of the farming organisations which laid on their backs and had their tummies scratched by the federal government were lavish in their praise for the $164 million they received. A couple of weeks later, the arts in Australia got $252 million and the ANL employees effectively got around $250 million, but the $164 million was not given to the farmers; it was given to the banks. Effectively, that money goes as a subsidy on the farmers' interest, and that means that the money goes to the banks and not to the farmers. If the banks were borrowing money at five per cent and lending it out at six per cent, I would say, `Fair enough.' But, at the present moment, the banks are borrowing at five per cent and lending it to the farmers at 10 per cent, and the difference is being made up by the Australian taxpayers. Not only is this unfair but also it is toweringly stupid.

Not only was the $164 million supposed to be good for us—the farmers in this case—but straight afterwards we had a 1 3/4 per cent rise in interest rates foisted upon us by the federal government. That led to a $302 million a year extra burden upon the farmers of Australia who owe $17,000 million. At the start of the ALP decade, they owed only some $4,700 million. That tripped off a rise in the Australian dollar which saw farmers lose $540 million per year. So, whilst we got $164 million, we now find ourselves in a situation where we have been hit with a bill from the actions of the federal government of an extra $842 million per year. Thank you; it is a lovely Christmas present from the federal government. It indicates clearly the government's treatment of the farming sector of Australia.

DEBATE.TITLE: ROYAL COMMISSION INTO THE NEW SOUTH WALES POLICE SERVICE (ACCESS TO INFORMATION) BILL 1994

PARA.TAB: Consideration resumed from 5 December.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kerr The Hon D.J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: In June this year the Premier of New South Wales requested the assistance of the Commonwealth government for the Royal Commission into the New South Wales Police Service. This government considers that it would be proper for the Commonwealth to provide such assistance as it can in the fight against police corruption.

PARA.TAB: Allegations of corruption within an Australian police service constitute a serious threat to the integrity of the criminal justice system and the safety of the community, not just in the particular jurisdiction but nationally. All jurisdictions have increased their cooperation in national law enforcement initiatives in response to the national and international threat of organised crime. The corruption of one police agency therefore has the potential to compromise the national law enforcement effort and to jeopardise international law enforcement cooperation.

Such assistance as can be provided without the need for amendment of legislation is, of course, already being provided. Part of such assistance should be the provision of any evidence the Commonwealth might have of, or in relation to, such corruption. In some cases, the Commonwealth can provide relevant information without legislative change being necessary. There are, however, two important instances where specific legislative authority is necessary before information can be communicated to the royal commission. These are in relation to information obtained under the Financial Transaction Reports Act 1988 and the Telecommunications (Interception) Act 1979. In relation to the latter, in some circumstances it may prevent New South Wales law enforcement agencies, as well as the Commonwealth, from providing relevant information to the royal commission.

The matters being inquired into by the royal commission include allegations of corrupt activity by police. By their very nature, such allegations of corrupt activity may include secret transactions involving cash payments and other financial benefits. The amendments to the Financial Transaction Reports Act allow the Royal Commission into the New South Wales Police Service to be treated as a law enforcement agency under the act. This will allow the director of AUSTRAC, the Australian Transaction Reports and Analysis Centre, to pass financial transaction reports information to the royal commission.

The same conditions of access to financial transaction reports information and use of such information will apply to the royal commission as currently apply to the Australian Tax Office and to the various law enforcement agencies which currently have access to AUSTRAC's data. Information relevant to matters other than those the specific subject of a warrant under the Telecommunications (Interception) Act is obtained by law enforcement agencies. That act has strict rules about to whom such information may be communicated. As the act presently stands, no intercepting agency—including the New South Wales Crime Commission and the Independent Commission Against Corruption—could pass relevant information to the royal commission.

The proposed amendments provide for relevant lawfully obtained information to be communicated to the royal commission. The royal commission will then be able to use that information for a purpose permitted by the act. The amendments have no financial impact, and I commend the bill to the Committee.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Royal Commission into the New South Wales Police Service has been established by the Fahey government to inquire into allegations of corrupt activity by police. The Fahey government has had a single-minded determination to inquire into and to root out corruption, where allegations of corruption have been made to it; and the establishment of this royal commission is yet another signal from the government of that determination. It is in marked contrast to the stench which has surrounded previous governments in New South Wales.

PARA.TAB: I pay proper respect to Premier Fahey for the initiatives that he has taken, and also of course to former Premier Greiner, who—whilst suffering a personal penalty as a result of the establishment of one such organisation in the past to deal with allegations of corruption—always took a very strong stand on this issue in New South Wales. Since these issues have significance beyond the borders of one state, as the Minister for Justice (Mr Kerr) has said in his second reading speech, it is important that we recognise the very strong stance taken by the New South Wales government in contrast to some of its predecessors—in particular, the previous Labor administration, which I note is now offering itself for re-election.

The New South Wales authorities, as I understand it, support this bill; the coalition is unequivocal in its support as well, and we seek the support of all members in the early passage of this legislation. As the minister has said, allegations may include secret transactions involving cash payments or other financial benefits. In this regard there are two Commonwealth statutes which are relevant and which provide a framework for the control of such information and for its usage: in particular, the Financial Transaction Reports Act of 1988 and the Telecommunications (Interception) Act of 1979. To ensure that the royal commission has available to it all relevant information and that the arms of government, both state and federal, are put to the task of supporting the royal commission in its terms of reference, it is proposed by this bill before us to facilitate the provision of certain information to the royal commission. In particular, the bill allows for telephone tap material obtained under warrant to be made available to the commission.

I suppose it is surprising that some criminals have yet to work out that telephone taps are available to police authorities. Be that as it may, they are a useful source of information—or potentially a useful source of information—for a royal commission of this sort and this bill does allow for that information to be made available to the commission.
