The bill also allows the royal commission to be treated as a law enforcement agency so that financial transaction reports information can be passed to the royal commission. In the view of the coalition these are appropriate amendments to support the work of the royal commission and under those circumstances the coalition is pleased to provide its support in a bipartisan manner.

As I have mentioned, the New South Wales government supports the bill. I understand that there has been some comment, apparently from the royal commission itself, as to the way in which this matter ought to be dealt with. In a sense I think that is a technical matter. The policy perspective from my point of view is to ensure that the commission does have the information; whether it obtains the information directly or indirectly through existing federal agencies is a secondary consideration.

I understand that the government does have plans to include official corruption as a tappable offence, but it is not doing so now simply because it has a pre-set schedule to make further amendments at a later date. I encourage the government to bear in mind the views of the commission to ensure that there is in no sense whatsoever any hindrance to the work of the commission in fulfilling its terms of reference. With those brief words, I offer the coalition's support to this initiative from the government in support of the policy of the New South Wales government and, in particular, we offer support to this royal commission.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Jenkins)—Is it the wish of the Committee to proceed to a report motion forthwith?
Leave granted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kerr The Hon D.J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the bill be reported to the house without amendment.

SPEECH.PARA: I deal with the matter raised by the honourable member for Flinders (Mr Reith). The legislation was, in fact, proposed by both the Labor Party and the Independents and, without wishing to enter into any partisan debate, I dissociate myself from any suggestion that this matter was proceeded with against the wishes of the Labor Party in New South Wales. In fact, it was its specific initiative.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN CAPITAL TERRITORY ELECTORAL LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1994

PARA.TAB: Consideration resumed from 14 November.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Snowdon The Hon W.E.

TALKER.NAME: Mr SNOWDON
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Employment, Education and Training)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: The main purpose of the Australian Capital Territory Electoral Legislation Amendment Bill 1994 is to amend and repeal those parts of the Commonwealth's Australian Capital Territory self-government legislation which are no longer appropriate now that the ACT Legislative Assembly has enacted its own electoral legislation. The bill provides for transitional arrangements for dealing with disputed qualifications of members of the assembly and casual vacancies in the period up to the next assembly election on 18 February 1995.

PARA.TAB: These provisions arise from a review of the ACT electoral legislation, which was conducted by the ACT administration and my department after self-government was granted in 1989. That legislation, the Australian Capital Territory (Self-Government) Act 1988 and the Australian Capital Territory (Electoral) Act 1988, applied the modified Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918 to the territory and provided for the Australian Electoral Commission to conduct legislative assembly elections.

The ACT Legislative Assembly has now passed its own comprehensive electoral legislation, some of which came into effect on 25 August 1994. The ACT Electoral Commission has been established, its functions and powers determined and the procedures for Legislative Assembly elections laid down in the Australian Capital Territory's Electoral Act 1992 as amended in 1994.

The effect of this is to provide parallel mechanisms for running ACT elections—the Commonwealth legislation and the ACT's local legislation. The Commonwealth's Australian Capital Territory (Self-Government) Act 1988 still serves, in effect, as a `constitution' for the territory. Some of its provisions need amendment to permit the transition from the Commonwealth's Australian Capital Territory (Electoral) Act 1988 to the Electoral Act 1992 of the Australian Capital Territory.

The Commonwealth's Australian Capital Territory (Electoral) Act 1988 on the other hand needs to be repealed to make way for the ACT legislation, with the exception of section 16, saving that provision which allows division 2 of part XXII of the modified Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918 to apply. This enables the Supreme Court of the Australian Capital Territory to continue to determine issues of disputed qualifications and casual vacancies in the period until 18 February 1995, after which the ACT's local electoral laws will commence to apply.

Item 1 of the schedule to the bill deals with subsection 48(1) of the Australian Capital Territory (Self-Government) Act 1988. That subsection currently refers to subsection 10(7) of the Australian Capital Territory (Electoral) Act 1988, which is repealed by the bill. Item 1 brings the Commonwealth's self-government legislation into line with the Electoral Act 1992 of the Australian Capital Territory in respect of the circumstances following the calling of an extraordinary general election by providing that an ordinary general election shall not be held within six months of such an extraordinary general election.

Items 2 and 3 of the schedule amend the Australian Capital Territory (Self-Government) Act 1988 by omitting subsection 67A(2) and subsection 67C(2) and substituting a new subsection 67C(2) to reflect the fact that the Australian Capital Territory now has its own `electoral enactment', the Electoral Act 1992.

Items 4 and 5 provide for the definition of `registered party' found in the Commonwealth's Australian Capital Territory (Electoral) Act 1988 and in the Electoral Act 1992 of the Australian Capital Territory to apply respectively before and on or after 25 August 1995. The bill also omits redundant provisions in the Commonwealth's self-government legislation.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Jenkins)—Order! The question is that this bill now be read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the absence of any comment from the opposition I am happy to speak on this.
—I certainly would not wish it to be implied that you are leading for the opposition in this case.

—Absolutely not. I presume the absence of an opposition speaker suggests that the opposition is supporting this very mechanical bill, and I hope that is true because it should, of course. The significance of the Australian Capital Territory Electoral Legislation Amendment Bill 1994 is that it completes the transition to self-government in the ACT, and that is a very important step. The bill is a quite straightforward one of just handing the responsibility for electoral matters over to the ACT government now that it has passed its own legislation. This completes a process that has been going on now for six years, and has involved the progressive transfer of responsibility for all matters for which the ACT now has responsibility over to it. It does so on the basis that this was a necessary step for ensuring that the last part of Australia which did not manage its own affairs was able to do so.

PARA.TAB: This step towards self-government was quite controversial in the ACT. There was uncertainty about what it would mean and there was dispute about what the implications were in terms of distribution of power and financial arrangements. But it seemed clear to many people that in a practising democracy it was not reasonable or responsible for one part of the country not to accept responsibility for its own affairs. In a situation where there is a commitment to participatory democracy, it was important that the ACT—after all, the seat of the national parliament—should fit that model as well. That was why many of us pushed hard for self-government and why we are very glad to see it in operation.

Of course, it has not functioned free of controversy, and some would say it has not functioned perfectly, but it has been a learning experience for the people of the ACT and for the members of the Legislative Assembly. The functioning has progressively improved and that suggests a growing political maturity within the territory. That is exactly what one would expect and would hope for.

I strongly support this bill, therefore, because it is consistent with one of the most important principles on which our country is based—that is, participatory representative democracy. This completes the process of transition, and I am glad that the ACT government has now its own electoral act which means that the Commonwealth can withdraw from this area and leave the territory to operate independently and responsibly. I strongly support the bill and I hope, now that the shadow minister is here, that he will do the same.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to be able to tell my honourable colleague that I shall endeavour to do the same, in the sense that the opposition, naturally, is not opposing the Australian Capital Territory Electoral Legislation Amendment Bill 1994. I must say that a reading of the history of recent years has seen a saga of mismatching to some degree—
—A growing maturity, though.

—You rightly describe it as `a growing maturity'. I think it is a very charitable choice of words. The main aim of this bill is to amend and repeal those parts of the Commonwealth's ACT self-government legislation which are no longer appropriate, given that the ACT Legislative Assembly has enacted its own legislation covering the conduct of elections and related matters. There now exists an ACT Electoral Commission and its functions and powers are determined by the procedures laid down in the relevant 1992 legislation, as amended in 1994. This bill also makes provision for transitional arrangements dealing with disputed qualifications of members, which are not covered by the ACT's legislation in the period leading up to the 18 February 1995 election, which will soon be upon us.

PARA.TAB: Prior to the commencement of the Australian Capital Territory (Self-Government) Act 1988, which was Commonwealth legislation, the ACT was administered by the Commonwealth through its respective agencies. Debate about a local legislature for the ACT dates back to the time when the seat of government was established here in the 1920s. In October 1988, a package of bills dealing with self-government was introduced into the House of Representatives. After much negotiation regarding the electoral system for the territory, the legislation was passed with amendments in November 1988. A modified d'Hondt system, which provided for a form of proportional representation not previously used in Australia, was established. The system was criticised by the Australian Electoral Commission at the time as being absurd and bizarre.

The ACT became a separate legal entity from the Commonwealth under the Australian Capital Territory (Self-Government) Act 1988, which is, in effect, the constitution of the self-governing polity. The Commonwealth handed over some of its powers to the ACT government while others—such as police and the courts—were transferred over time and, of course, we still have the Commonwealth Federal Police in operation at present. Some legislative powers were reserved to the Commonwealth and were not available to the ACT Legislative Assembly. For example, the assembly could not vary the electoral system.

The transition to self-government has not been—as mentioned by my predecessor—without problems. The first ACT election held under a modified d'Hondt system took place on 4 March 1989. It proved to be a fiasco. Some 117 candidates stood for 17 positions, there were 108 different parties and nine independents. Apart from the Liberal and Labor parties, there were parties such the Party! Party! Party! Party, the Sun-Ripened Warm Tomato Party and the Surprise Party!. The ballot paper was the biggest ever seen in Australia and the second largest seen in the democratic world.

Getting the ballot paper into the voting booths proved to be something of a gymnastic feat, given that it was a metre wide. Once in the booth, the voter was confronted with 139 boxes, which led to widespread confusion. Consequently, the informal vote mounted to 5.69 per cent, which is remarkably low, considering that at the last state election in New South Wales the figure was nine to 10 per cent. Nevertheless, it demonstrated at that stage a not inconsiderable public view, disparate though it may have been described at the time, of not being in favour of self-government for the ACT. Those various components of a political process came out in support of that proposition.

Counting took some nine weeks and it was more than two months from the time of the election before it was determined who had become a member of the Legislative Assembly. Scrutiny of the ballot papers required eight stages and had to be sorted into 209 categories—a massive feat. Understandably, many ACT residents were less than impressed with what occurred.

In the wake of the election, two inquiries were held into the ACT electoral system. In July 1989, the ACT Legislative Assembly established a select committee on self-government to report on a number of issues, including the electoral process. In November 1989, the Commonwealth parliament's Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters presented a report entitled Inquiry into the ACT election and electoral system. Among the recommendations of the ACT Legislative Assembly select committee were that the ACT enact its own electoral act and that a separate electoral office be established in the ACT to administer the legislation, provide policy advice to the ACT government, and conduct public awareness and education campaigns on matters relating to ACT Legislative Assembly matters. In the view of the select committee, full ACT control of its own electoral system was an essential ingredient in a self-government process.

In 1991, the Commonwealth government introduced the Australian Capital Territory (Electoral) Amendment Bill. The minister's second reading speech included a commitment to hand over to the ACT the power to control its own electoral system. In the same year, the government also introduced amendments to the Australian Capital Territory (Self-Government) Act 1988 and the Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918. This package of legislation enabled the ACT Legislative Assembly to enact electoral legislation specifically for the ACT.

The Electoral Act 1992 (ACT) was the first stage in the making of the act of the ACT's own electoral laws. It established an electoral commission for the Territory and an independent procedure for the determination of electoral boundaries. The next stage in the process occurred in 1994 when the Electoral (Amendment) Act 1994 (ACT) and the Electoral (Amendment) (Consequential Provisions) Act 1994 were passed by the assembly. The net effect of this has been the construction of parallel mechanisms for running ACT elections—that is, the Commonwealth legislation and the ACT legislation.

The Australian Capital Territory Electoral Legislation Amendment Bill 1994, which is the bill before us, amends and repeals certain Commonwealth laws which are no longer appropriate as a result of the passage of the ACT act. The bill also contains transitional provisions relating to casual vacancies and disputed qualifications for the period leading up to the next ACT general election on 18 February 1995.

Clause 3 of the legislation repeals the Commonwealth's Australian Capital Territory (Electoral) Act 1988, as it is no longer necessary. However, subclause 3(2) is a savings provision which states that division 2 of the Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918 continues to apply in relation to certain disputed qualifications and casual vacancies. Consequently, the ACT Supreme Court can continue to hear any questions of disputed qualifications and casual vacancies—should they arise—until the next ACT general election, when the ACT's own electoral laws will apply.

Subclause 4(1) also provides that the Australian Capital Territory Electoral Act is not and never has been invalid on the grounds of inconsistency with the Commonwealth's Australian Capital Territory (Electoral) Act 1988. There are a number of other changes of that nature.

As the shadow Attorney-General of the Australian Capital Territory, Mr Gary Humphries, has said, it is appropriate that the Australian Capital Territory Legislative Assembly take control of its own electoral system following a decision by the people at referendum in 1992. This referendum involved a choice between single member electorates and the Hare-Clarke voting system with a Robson rotation. Some 67 per cent of Canberrans supported the Hare-Clarke system. There was support for that system from every party, except the ALP, which had previously thought it would have a monopoly over power in the Australian Capital Territory forever.

After the referendum, a major controversy broke out as Ms Follett, the Chief Minister, attempted, in the view of many people, to undermine the results of the referendum with the Labor Party's proposals. In the event, the ALP was forced to back down. The Australian Capital Territory voting system now reflects the wishes of the vast majority of electors. As we have seen in the past and as we will probably see in the future, the probabilities in the Australian Capital Territory are that the balance of power may well be held by independent members of the chamber. In a sense, this gives the two major parties a reasonably fair prospect of having a share of government over time. This is a considerable improvement over the original proposal which would have given to the Labor Party, and the Labor Party alone, a significant and unfair advantage over other political interests. Consequently, the legislation is supported by the coalition.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Motion (by Mr Snowdon)—by leave—agreed to:
That the bill be reported to the House without amendment.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Delegation to Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania and Inter-Parliamentary Union 92nd Conference, Copenhagen

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 5 December, on motion by Mr Taylor:
That the House take note of the paper.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Quick Mr H.V.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is with great pleasure and a sense of pride that I rise to speak on the report of the delegation to Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania and the 92nd Inter-Parliamentary Union conference in Copenhagen. I will concentrate on our visit to Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania, for reasons which will become obvious, and decline to speak at length about the Inter-Parliamentary Union conference in Copenhagen.

PARA.TAB: Going to school in the 1950s, as I did, geography and history were an integral part of the curriculum. Everyone of my age knew where Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania were and they knew the historical importance of those countries. Fate is rather strange. In the early 1970s I married into a Lithuanian family from Sydney and I quickly gained a new perspective on my versions of world history, coming as I did from an Anglo-Saxon base with a father who, I proudly claim, was one of the original Anzacs. I gained a new perspective into a version of world history, especially concerning Eastern Europe and the choice that people had between the German and Russian domination of that part of the world.

Then, as a federal parliamentarian, having the chance to visit Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania enabled me and my wife to see places at first hand which were previously only spoken about around the table in Sydney and at my home in Hobart. As I said, I wish to confine my remarks today to our visit to the three countries which are often described as the Baltic states.

As a result of the vast changes occurring in these countries and the very close links Australians have with them now, and as a result of the parliamentary delegation's visit, I would like to think that we as Australians will come to see these countries as separate entities in their own right rather than being bundled up as the Baltic states. Our delegation's visit could not have been timed more perfectly. The delegation was in these countries just as the Russian troops were finally leaving. Fifty years of Soviet domination and subjugation were finally coming to an end. Our delegation's visit to Estonia, the first of the countries that we visited, coincided with the withdrawal of the remaining Russian troops from that country.

When we arrived in Estonia we were told that there was a change in the itinerary and that we were being asked to attend a special thanksgiving service. Those of us who were there were very privileged to be at this special thanksgiving service of the church of Kaarli, attended by the Estonian Prime Minister, Mart Laar. This service was one of the special events in my life. None of us understood a word of Estonian but this did not make a scrap of difference. From the fervour of the singing one could sense the feeling in the country and the rejoicing that its people had now gained their freedom. After this rather moving service, bells in all the churches throughout the country rang out to proclaim the news that Estonia was now Estonian, not part of the Soviet Union.

Just to be part of this enabled all of us to glimpse a little of what was happening throughout Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania. For the next several days we were given an insight into life in Estonia as it was under Soviet control, and now as a free and sovereign state. It was evident as we travelled around that housing as we know it was reserved for the privileged few in Estonian society. The vast majority of the people lived in 12- to 15-storey apartment buildings built in the style we jokingly refer to as `Soviet realism'—grey brick which over time has taken on a black hue. Maintenance appeared to have never taken place. Public transport, cheap as it was, was badly in need of being updated.

Life in the Estonian countryside seemed to have remained in a time warp. There were no fences apparent anywhere. Farm animals were taken out and individually tethered. Farm machinery was rarely seen and vast areas of agricultural land were not being utilised. With the end of collectivisation, the whole farming sector of the economy lacked purpose and direction and the potential for development seemed enormous. Those of us who had some farming connections were amazed at exactly what was not happening in this country.

Relations with Russia dominate the foreign policy aspects of Estonian life, and this was no more evident than when we had the chance to visit the former military base in Klooga. We quickly sensed, as I said previously, that the Estonians are a very proud race of people. When we were shown the military base in Klooga we were told that this was one of over 500 such bases throughout the country and for the first time in 50 years people were able to see parts of their country for the first time. It was rather difficult for us to understand, being able as we are to travel wherever we like and to see whatever we like, that one-twentieth of this country had been locked away for 50 years and that people were now seeing their own forests, roads, highways, lakes and the like for the first time. There were tears in their eyes when they spoke of it and it rather moved us.
At Klooga we were able to obtain at first hand an insight into the environmental problems facing each of these three countries. I would like to quote from the delegation report:

SPEECH.PARA: The Klooga base had been left by the Russians less than a week before the delegation's visit. It was a wasteland—a scene of total devastation. Buildings on the base had been stripped of all fittings and fixtures, including wiring, hand basins, taps and door handles. The external surrounds had been similarly treated and roadside culverts had been removed where possible. Outlying buildings were littered with waste. There was no guarantee that the base was free from landmines. Accordingly, the delegation was required to walk on specific routes only. Abandoned pets were also in evidence, and they are also a feature of many of the 500 such places throughout Estonia.

PARA.TAB: I can assure members that we in the delegation were amazed and bewildered by what we saw at Klooga. As I said, it is one of 500 such places in Estonia. I think there are in excess of 560 in Latvia, and there is probably the same number in Lithuania. This legacy affects these countries. It is a vast problem. Given that these countries are still moving from a command economy to a market economy, there is little realistic prospect of funds being available to clear up these bases. Vast sums will be required before such blots on the landscape can be erased.

Throughout all these countries, we were confronted with a problem that some of us had no difficulty in understanding: the problem of the Russians still residing in these countries. The question of citizenship and exactly what constitutes an Estonian, Latvian or Lithuanian was raised frequently in our discussions with members of parliament and ministers from all these countries. After 50 years of Soviet domination, and the realisation that these people have now gained their rightful place on the world stage, one can easily understand why many of the people in these countries wish to make the issue of citizenship as stringent as possible, so as to exclude those Russians who have no desire to be a part of these emerging countries.

However, this desire to stand on their own is tempered by the ever-present realisation that Mother Russia is not all that far away. Knowing of some of the weird and wonderful characters—such as Mr Zhirinovsky—who are espousing Russian domination of these places again, one can understand why people in Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania are mindful of asserting citizenship rights. But, as I say, mother Russia is not far away. These countries are inextricably linked to Russia for their economic futures, as they are almost totally reliant on Russia for energy supplies—whether they be oil or uranium rods for the power stations that proliferate in their countryside—and for the markets for their exports.

Each of these countries is different in its own right. I guess Estonia—the first country we visited—had a pretty enormous impact on all of us. Latvia was completely different. It has a huge problem with the Russian presence, in that, after the withdrawal of Russian troops, only 54 per cent of people living in Latvia are Latvians. The rest is made up of Russians, Byelorussians or members of other races. Currently, Latvians are in the minority in the seven largest cities and towns in the country. It was evident from our time in Riga—where one heard more Russian spoken than Latvian—that this is an enormous problem. How can the emerging country, with only 54 per cent of its population Latvians, assert its sovereignty? As I say, many of us could understand why pretty stringent conditions have been put on Latvian, Estonian and Lithuanian citizenship.

I would now like to briefly turn to our time in Lithuania. I have a Lithuanian wife, who was able to return to the homeland, so it was rather special for us. It was a chance for my wife to practice her fluent Lithuanian, and she enjoyed the role of interpreter when we were able to visit parts of the countryside. It was also rather special to have permission to make a slight detour on our way to Kaunas, to visit Jonova—the town where her parents were born—and to have a quick glimpse of the countryside around there.

The second special event was to share a meal with Professor Landsbergis and his lovely wife. Professor Landsbergis was the architect of Lithuanian independence and he took a bold stand, ahead of the other two Baltic countries, in asserting Lithuanian independence.

We had the privilege of going to the radio station, which is not dissimilar to Black Mountain Tower. To see the 13 crosses around the radio station and the display inside the radio station is to understand that those 13 crosses symbolise the places where 13 proud Lithuanians of all ages died for their country, in an attempt to stop the Soviet army seizing the radio station when Lithuania declared its independence.

Another moving event was to visit the Hill of Crosses in the Lithuanian countryside. It is rather hard to describe it. There is a small hill covered by hundreds of thousands—and I mean hundreds of thousands—of crosses of all sizes and shapes from all around the world with messages on them. The Hill of Crosses is a symbol also of Lithuanian independence. In the time of the struggle for independence, the Russians tried in vain to wipe this part of Lithuanian history off the face of the map. But every morning the crosses were back and they finally realised that you cannot quell freedom.

Another special event occurred when Mr Speaker, in addressing the Lithuanian parliament, was persuaded to begin his speech with two sentences of Lithuanian. It was ironic that the only word that he struggled over was the word `Australia'. I would like to incorporate in my speech his opening words in which he offered greetings and best wishes from Australia: `Laba diena iss Australiose Ma-lornu su yumis susiparzhinti.'

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a test for Hansard.

—Yes, I have written it down so they can understand it. As I said, it was a wonderful experience for me and my wife to be part of the delegation. I would like to thank all the other members of the delegation who came with us. I would like to thank Anne Hazelton for her wonderful work, and the Australian ambassadors, as mentioned in the Speaker's report yesterday.

PARA.TAB: All I can say is that from the brief time—nine days—that we spent in these countries we were impressed to see the wonderful relationships that have developed as a result of the visit of our parliamentary delegation and to see the examples of young Australians of second and third generation Estonian, Latvian and Lithuanian families who have now returned to their homelands and are playing a very vital role in establishing education, community service and health initiatives to enable the people to better manage what is happening.

I would like to briefly mention two young women, one from Melbourne and one from Adelaide, who single-handedly have set up in Vilnius a school for young children with disabilities. We had the pleasure of spending a couple of hours there and it was a moving experience to see these two young girls who, with no money but with all the will in the world, convinced the ministers for education and community services and health in Lithuania to deinstitutionalise, almost overnight, all the young people with disabilities and to set up a program for these children and for their parents. This was moving evidence of the links that we have established. With those few words, I am pleased to support the report.(Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is an honour and a pleasure to speak to the report of the parliamentary delegation to Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania and the 92nd Inter-Parliamentary Conference in Copenhagen. At the outset I would like to acknowledge my parliamentary colleagues from both sides of the House who accompanied me on this delegation, including the previous speaker, the honourable member for Franklin (Mr Quick). I acknowledge also the leader of the delegation, Mr Speaker (Mr Martin), Senator Paul Calvert, from Tasmania, who was the deputy leader, and Senator John Woodley, a Democrat senator from Queensland, with regard to the visits to the Baltic states. As well, I acknowledge the friendship, support and cooperation of a number of other House of Representatives colleagues—the honourable member for Watson (Mr Leo McLeay), the honourable member for Melbourne Ports (Mr Holding) and the honourable member for Moncrieff (Mrs Sullivan), all of whom made a substantial contribution, in Australia's national interest, at the 92nd IPU conference in Copenhagen.

PARA.TAB: I pay tribute to a number of the support staff on our delegation—to Pam McDonald, from the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, whose counsel was valued by all of us, particularly during that IPU conference; and to Anne Hazelton, the secretary to the delegation, whose performance is reflected in the quality of this report, which is an outstanding precis of what went on during that bilateral visit and in terms of the IPU conference. I would like to acknowledge also the contribution of the Speaker's executive assistant, Geraldine Skinner. Geraldine was always there, always helpful and a great support. On behalf of all us in the delegation I thank Geraldine for her substantial contribution to our visits.

I would like to speak briefly to one or two points from the report, firstly in relation to the Baltic states, and to expand a little on one or two points that the honourable member for Franklin has made. The first point that impressed all of us about the Baltic states was commitment to democracy by the peoples of those three countries. Let nobody misjudge what they are about—they are totally committed to democracy, to democratic processes, to the processes of parliament. In all three countries we saw, albeit at varying stages of development, parliaments being firmly established and governance being firmly established.

The peoples of Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania can justifiably be proud of what they have achieved since 1991, when their move into democratic processes really started. As the honourable member for Franklin has said, that was not without a certain degree of bloodshed. We saw evidence, direct and indirect, of that while we were in those three countries.

I pay tribute to the peoples of those three countries for their commitment. Yes, they have a few major challenges ahead of them. In those three countries the inflation rate was running at about 1,000 per cent in 1991. To bring that back—as they have all, I think—to double figures, around 20 to 25 per cent at this point in time, is a major achievement. We, as part of the international community, should be doing everything we can on a bilateral and a multilateral basis to assist them in moving further along the path of democratic progress.

The second point I would like to make in relation to the three countries is something that was referred to by the honourable member for Franklin—the Russian legacy. Let there be no doubt about it, there are still a lot of reservations about the Russians in all three countries, perhaps more prominently in Estonia and Latvia than in Lithuania, the last named having a rather more pragmatic approach to the bilateral relationship with the emerging Russian Federation. But it is posing some problems. As the honourable member said, that is exemplified in the citizenship legislation which continues to bounce around within the domestic political environment of those three countries. I think it is something which will put a few pressures on the democratic processes in all three of those countries, but I have every confidence that they will be able to overcome them and move onwards and upwards.

In Estonia, we were scheduled to visit the former Soviet nuclear naval base west of Tallinn. For reasons known only to those in Estonia, the day before we got there it was decided that we were not allowed to visit. The official reason given was that they were withdrawing the rods from the two nuclear reactors which had formed the basis of a simulated submarine at that nuclear naval base. That disappointed a number of us.

Nevertheless, having, as a replacement for that, visited the former armoured brigade camp at a place called Klooga, some earlier views that we had been given about the impact of the former Soviet military forces in those countries were reinforced. We were all made speechless by what we saw. I do not pull punches in referring to the environmental vandalism that has resulted from that Soviet occupation. I will say a little bit more about that in a moment. We were all almost speechless once we had seen Klooga.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is hard to believe—all of you?

—It is hard to believe, yes. I have strong reservations—I hope they are unfounded—about the position of the people of Estonia in terms of the residual radiation that may emerge from the Tallinn naval base, especially if the environmental standards are the same level as those we saw in the more conventional warfare base at Klooga. I put those reservations on the Hansard record. I implore the Russian Federation to take every step it can to assist the people of Estonia in that nuclear environment by making quite sure that the area is swept clean before the Russians finally depart in about a year's time.

PARA.TAB: For the next couple of years the Russians will have an early warning ballistic missile radar station in Latvia at a place called Skrunda. That is causing some political pressures within Latvia. I hope that can be resolved and that finally, in a year or two, that facility will be dismantled and the Russian military will withdraw.

In terms of the military situation in Lithuania and the pressures that are being applied and have been applied, the Lithuanians do not have any Russian military personnel on their soil; nevertheless—through the back door—they were forced to give transit rights to the Russian Federation, to the military enclave at Kaliningrad. Kaliningrad is the most highly militarised enclave in Europe, as the report has said. Something between 40,000 and 140,000 Russian troops—depending on who is speaking—are still there.

The transit rights through Lithuania were negotiated as a result of pressures applied on that country by the Russian Federation in terms of most favoured nation trade status. I think that is to be deplored in many ways but nevertheless, being very pragmatic about it, the Lithuanian people have accepted it. My only comment would be that I hope that progressively the traffic from west to east—in other words from the Baltic into Byelorussia and into the Russian Federation—will increase rather than decrease.

I would like to mention one other matter, something that was mentioned by the honourable member for Franklin. He would agree with me, and indeed our wives who were with us felt the same way, that the most moving experience during the whole of our travels was the visit to the living skills centre in Vilnius. There we met two young ladies, both of Lithuanian origin, who had set up in 1991 a centre for intellectually handicapped people.

I have to say that all of us had a few tears in our eyes; Senator Woodley, in particular, was very moved as a result of that visit. I pay tribute to those two young ladies, one from Melbourne and one from Adelaide. I made the point on the House floor about this matter a few weeks ago. It was certainly a most moving experience.

In terms of that visit to the Baltic states, the visit to the Hill of Crosses was also a very moving experience. As you may or may not know, in Estonia and Latvia the dominant religion is the Lutheran religion whilst in Lithuania 93 per cent are of the Roman Catholic faith. Mr Deputy Speaker, in my view the two things that held those three countries together during the Soviet occupation were, firstly, their faith in their own peoples and, secondly, their religious faith.

That was reflected very much in that Hill of Crosses. As the honourable member for Franklin has said, the Hill of Crosses is about 100 metres in diameter, about 30 metres high and is covered in millions of crosses. The Soviets attempted, over and over again during their occupation, to bulldoze the area, only to find that within days it was restored. That indicates the commitment that those Baltic people had.

My final point is in relation to the 92nd IPU conference in Copenhagen. For my part it was a very valuable experience and I believe the Australian delegation performed very well. We should all be proud, on both sides of the House, of the contribution that everybody made to the debates in that forum. It was my first experience of the IPU and I hope it will not be my last. It was a very beneficial experience.

I notice my colleague from South Australia, the honourable member for Adelaide, is here. She might like to note that in my speech on the floor of that conference I particularly made reference to an undesirable international development, the feminisation of poverty. I hope that at the world summit on social development which will be held in Copenhagen in March next year this and many other issues in relation to international poverty will be addressed.

I do not think we should lose sight of the fact that in this region there are about a billion people who are in deep poverty and a very large proportion, arguably about three-quarters, are women. That has to be looked at very seriously in the context of that summit conference in Copenhagen in March.

I would like to finish by saying that I and my colleagues would like to acknowledge the very substantial progress that the people of those three Baltic states are making towards democracy. I think we on both sides of the House, and the Australian people, should wish them the very best of luck. I have no doubt that they will succeed.
Debate (on motion by Mr Griffiths) adjourned.
Debate resumed from 5 December, on motion by Mr Humphreys:
That the House takes note of the paper.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was a great privilege for me to be part of the delegation to southern Africa and, just to make sure that I do not leave them out at the end, I would just like to record some thankyous at the very beginning of my speech. Firstly, I thank my colleagues who were members of the delegation. The honourable member for Griffith (Mr Humphreys) was the leader, and we all benefited from his experience, goodwill and charm along the way. I was certainly very grateful to have him as leader, and it was a privilege for me to be deputy leader.

PARA.TAB: The honourable member for Throsby (Mr Hollis), the honourable member for Cowan (Mr Richard Evans) and Senators Dee Margetts and John Coulter were the other members of the delegation. I like to think that, with that wide political mix, we worked well together, that we all benefited from the experience and, hopefully, that we contributed to greater goodwill between Australia and the countries that we visited.

I was grateful to, in particular, the parliaments of the three countries who hosted us: Zimbabwe, Namibia and Botswana. They were very generous in their hospitality, just as we were welcomed most warmly in South Africa, of course. The former three countries certainly paid for our expenses while we were there and took us under their wing. We had very good briefings before we left this country, and I record my appreciation to AIDAB, Austrade and the Parliamentary Library. The Parliamentary Relations Office was also most helpful.

Before we went, we met with the South African High Commissioner, His Excellency Mr Steyn, with whom we have also met since and with whom we are having an ongoing dialogue. We also met the Zimbabwe High Commissioner, His Excellency Professor Patel. The Australian High Commissioner in Zimbabwe is Kerry Sibraa, who was the former President of the Senate and is known to many of us, and it was good to see him and his wife, Julie, there. They were exceptionally good to us, their staff were very helpful, and we had briefings of a very high standard.

In South Africa we were fortunate to be met by the High Commissioner, Ross Burns, and his staff were also very helpful with their briefings. Peter Roberts accompanied the delegation as secretary, and we were all grateful for the attention that he gave to the members of the delegation. Alan Fewster, who is from the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade and has responsibility for the South African desk, also accompanied the delegation and we were grateful for his contribution.

The report is quite lengthy and detailed and I thought that, rather than referring at length today to what is already printed in it, I might just make mention of a few areas that I thought were of particular importance. The goodwill that has developed between these countries and Australia should never be underestimated. I was particularly pleased to note that, in all our formal meetings, it was quite obvious that Australia was regarded highly. Malcolm Fraser, in particular, came in for some very complimentary mentions along the way. These relationships and friendships should be built on, as we will all benefit from them. Australia is still a most fortunate country and, if we can be of assistance as role models as far as democracy is concerned and of assistance more practically, then we are doing our bit for that part of the world.

The previous speaker, the honourable member for Groom (Mr Taylor), in reporting on his delegation, mentioned the feminisation of poverty, something that was also most obvious to members of this delegation. It was amazing to consider the number of women with whom we met who were very favourably impressed that an Australian delegation could have a woman as deputy leader. Although it had not occurred to me when I left Australia that that was important, it was certainly important to them, and perhaps it is something that can be thought about in future.

It was also obvious to me that we live in a very small world, and I was reminded of the ease with which friendships can be developed. When the IPU conference met last year in Canberra I attended the day that was devoted to women. The member for Moncrieff (Mrs Sullivan) had asked each of the women members of the Australian parliament to host a table for lunch. I had the great pleasure of sitting opposite Edna Mnangagwa, who is now assistant education minister in Zimbabwe. Edna and I got on famously and I showed her my office; we exchanged addresses but did not really get around to communicating after that. Of course, on that occasion that we had lunch together I did not think for one moment that I would be visiting Harare or would have the opportunity to meet up with Edna again so that we could chat and update each other on what had been happening.

Since I have been back in Australia I have been contacted by a member of the South Australian parliament. Julian Stefani attended a conference recently where he met Margaret Dongo, who is a member of the parliament in Zimbabwe, and Margaret was able to pass on to him good wishes to be conveyed to me, which he certainly did. Again, I was reminded of what a small world it is. Just the other night several of us had dinner with the President of the Senate here as the legal committee from Zimbabwe was entertained. Again, messages were able to be exchanged with people we had met in Harare, and I think that this all contributes to a much better relationship between the two countries.

In the report we mentioned Australian aid, which I think has been a subject which from time to time comes up for debate. There were some comments made some time ago as to what regions of the world our aid should be channelled into. All members of the delegation that visited southern Africa, I think, are of the view that southern Africa, not only for trade but also for aid, should be considered as a region. In the report we have come up with areas that we consider it would be important to give attention to. It is not necessarily demanding of a lot of money, but it is appropriate that our expertise be put into these areas.

We have developed significant expertise in some areas in Australia which would be particularly beneficial to this area. Those areas include AIDS education—and I will come back to that in a few moments—the training of medical and counselling staff, veterinary science, dry land farming, use of solar energy technology, computerisation of taxation and electoral records, which they do not have there at all, collection of census information, trade union training, vocational and trade training, senior secondary education, business education, remote education, mining technology, national park management and sports coaching.

The one that gets first mention and is of particular interest to me is AIDS education. Before I went to this part of the world I had certainly heard of the high incidence of AIDS. But when one gets there one sees that it is not just out in remote areas: it is in the cities; it is in the highly civilised areas. Of course, there are no accurate records in many of these areas, but several of us visited the Princess Marina Hospital in Botswana where we met with the surgical registrar and his colleagues, a physician and also a paediatrician.

They do have some very reliable information there, and the statistics on AIDS sufferers are quite frightening: 10 per cent of the whole population, 25 per cent of the sexually active population and in some communities up to 35 per cent. Very often the first indication of the problem is when a very small baby is admitted. Then it is discovered that the mother, and perhaps one of the other children, is HIV positive. The father does not really want to be tested and thinks that a mosquito could well be responsible. The expertise that we have developed in this area is something that could well represent a major input from us.

On the same subject we met with Dr Stamps, the health minister in Zimbabwe. He was able to pull condoms out of his pocket to show that he was aware of the problems. Apart from anything else, it is a cultural problem. The disease is affecting the heterosexual community there and this should be a lesson for the rest of the world. There should be a selfish reason for our interest and our desire to help because AIDS does not know about international or state boundaries. Areas in the world such as Australia which are certainly way out in front and which have this under control to a large extent have a vested interest in assisting here, quite apart from any humanitarian reasons.
We visited the Alexandra clinic in South Africa where the same problems arose: pregnant women are found to be HIV positive. This is an area that deserves very thorough examination.

I would like to mention a few stories along the way because I think they will give some flavour to the trip. I was certainly moved by the degree of forgiveness and reconciliation which was apparent in every one of those countries which we visited. In Harare, we met with the justice minister, Mr Emerson Munangagwa. He had given us a very good formal briefing in the afternoon. He happened to be sitting next to me at dinner and I asked him where he had studied law. I discovered he had studied law when he was in prison. He was in prison before the age of 18. If he had been 18, he would have hung. He gave me some details about some of the torture he had experienced during his 10 years in gaol: for the first three years, he was in solitary confinement. He told me of his elation at independence and of some of the reforms that he was able to achieve as justice minister. Prisoners are now given soap and clothing. One of the first things he did was to promote his torturers as a sign of his forgiveness. I found this example quite extraordinary and something that I had not come across before, and I found this to be consistent through the other countries that we visited.

Certainly President Mandela is spoken of extremely highly in South Africa. The Speaker in Namibia and his wife, Sandra, spoke about their new institutions and their old customs. Four years ago, they were tearing themselves apart but now they work together. The various political parties got together to write the constitution, again with an extraordinary degree of forgiveness.

In South Africa, at the high commissioner's residence, we met with a number of people, including Professor Asmal, Minister of Water Affairs and Forestry. He had had 30 years exile in Ireland. He taught at a university there and had, of course, helped write the interim constitution. He spoke to me about how he was notified on the radio that he would be going home.

Once again, extraordinary forgiveness and cooperation was exhibited there. And none more so than Mr Govan Mbeki, Vice-President of the Senate and father of the Deputy President. He and Mr Kobie Coetsee, who is a National Party member and President of the Senate, are good friends. Mr Mbeki was in gaol for 20 years and the person who signed his release from prison was Mr Coetsee when he was correctional services minister in 1988. When they wish to converse now and they do not want others to know what they are talking about, they talk in Latin. These examples of harmony, where people who had previously been enemies are now working together, are good examples for people in other parts of the world who still seem to be tearing themselves apart.

We had very many formal meetings. In Zimbabwe, we were fortunate to be taken to Victoria Falls and to meet with environment officers for the parks. In Namibia, we were taken to Etosha to see the animals and the wonderful tourist opportunities that are open to this part of the world. I would hope that, in the future, Australia's strong ties with this area are maintained. I am certainly grateful for the experience that I had in travelling to this part of the world and I will always be prepared to raise the causes that we have recorded in this report.

TALK.START.PARA: —I consider myself most fortunate to have been a member of the parliamentary delegation to southern Africa in July 1994. At the outset, let me pay tribute to the leader of the delegation, the member for Griffith (Mr Humphreys), the deputy leader, the member for Adelaide (Ms Worth), and, indeed, all delegation members. It was a harmonious delegation; and, having been on a delegation to Africa which was not harmonious, I know how important it is to have harmony amongst delegation members.

PARA.TAB: I doubt that any of us had our ideological views changed by each other, but we were able to present our various views in a straightforward and friendly way. I also believe that we projected a very positive image of the Australian parliament and of Australia. As with such delegations, there was a very full program, although at times exhausting, and each of us, I believe, learnt a lot from the wide range of people we met and the diversity of views expressed to us.

I want to pay a particular tribute to the current High Commissioner to Zimbabwe, and, indeed, high commissioner to eight other African nations, Kerry Sibraa. The high commissioner travelled with the delegation through Zimbabwe, Namibia and Botswana. It is fashionable for media to be critical of the appointment of former politicians to diplomatic posts or other jobs but, interestingly, the same criticism is never made when serving defence personnel take on jobs as governors or other such appointments.

In my 12 years in parliament I have been on the occasional delegation and made the occasional overseas trip. Let me state categorically that I have never been briefed as fully as I was by the high commissioner to Zimbabwe. Not only did he have a feel for the countries but he also had excellent local contacts and, in his own diplomatic way, he very skilfully assisted the delegation. I believe that we benefited immeasurably by his assistance. I also believe that Australia is very well served by having him as our high commissioner to not only Zimbabwe but also the other countries. The many years of experience that he gained as President of the Senate, his involvement with the Commonwealth Parliamentary Association, his understanding and—I might say—love of Africa makes him an exceptional high commissioner for this part of the world.

The visit to Zimbabwe encompassed everything from the majesty of the Victoria Falls to watching nervous and foolhardy people bungee jumping off the Zambezi River bridge. I have been assured that it is one of the most spectacular bungee jumps in the world but it is one, unlike my colleague the honourable member for Maribyrnong (Mr Griffiths), that I will never experience.

There was also the excitement of the visit to the Harare Cricket Academy where I had the honour of presenting cricket balls to up and coming Curtley Ambroses and a couple of other famous cricketers. We were also told about exciting investment opportunities and there were many meetings with ministers. All of these things made the Zimbabwe part of our tour especially rewarding. Zimbabwe is, I believe, one of the successes of Africa. The country has its problems, but then what country does not. I believe that Zimbabwe will overcome whatever current problems it has and will continue to play a meaningful role in the politics of southern Africa.

Namibia was, for many of us, the highlight of the tour in that it was so totally unexpected—from the modern city of Windhoek to the spectacular sandhill formations. The great hospitality and friendship extended gave each of us a determination to revisit the country. Our visit to Botswana was too brief to make a fully detailed appraisal but, again, we were shown great hospitality and friendship. We were impressed with Botswana's approach to tourism, especially in respect of the Okavango Swamp area. Botswana continues on its steady path of stable and democratic government since independence in 1966.

To visit South Africa so soon after the historic elections was a most rewarding experience. The difficulty for South Africa will be fulfilling the sometimes unrealistically high expectations of the majority of the population. The aspects that struck me most were not only the spirit of forgiveness, which the honourable member for Adelaide has already mentioned—I think it is a particularly African trait which we most certainly do not have in this country—but also the desire of people on all sides of the political spectrum to make the current system work. It will be difficult and there will be setbacks but in the end southern Africa and its people will triumph.

When South Africans woke on 30 April this year, if formal apartheid was no longer in existence, the social and economic symbols were still there, and in many respects remain—as, indeed, does the system within the bureaucracy. We had first-hand experience of this when we were to meet a group at the Ministry of Foreign Affairs for a round table discussion chaired by Mr D. Laubschur, Chief Director of the Southern Africa Branch. When we arrived as a delegation and were met at the foreign ministry building in Pretoria we were escorted to the office of the former ambassador to Australia, Mr Tothill, famous for his articles in the Australian. Later that day a concerned officer telephoned our high commissioner to ask where the Australian delegation was. In short, Mr Tothill had ambushed us.

Among the many interesting things Mr Tothill said was that Australia had missed the boat in regard to a relationship with South Africa because of our attitude to the former white regime. I personally do not accept this, and feel that the strong anti-apartheid stand Australia took, as the member for Adelaide said, on both sides of the political spectrum, and the many formal and informal contacts we have with South Africa, will ensure a meaningful relationship between Australia and the new democratic South Africa.

In my view, our diplomatic representatives in South Africa went a little overboard with security. I know it is difficult for them with parliamentary delegations, and I suppose it would cause an incident if something happened to a member of a parliamentary delegation. Security is often a problem, and it is a problem in South Africa, but in many respects we were prisoners, albeit it in airconditioned luxury, in both Cape Town and Johannesburg. We were not allowed out.

Of particular interest to me were the national archives of each of the countries we visited. I was fortunate to visit them all, and with my colleague the honourable member for Cowan (Mr Richard Evans) I visited the archives in South Africa. I would suggest that for a very small outlay Australia could play a significant role in assisting with the archival activities in each of these countries. For example, in Zimbabwe there is difficulty with obtaining foreign currency to allow archivists to travel overseas for training. Namibia is in need of assistance with personnel, and the same is true with Botswana. We could assist with the training of archivists and the provision of facilities in both countries, although I must say that I was most impressed with the way the archives were maintained in sometimes trying and difficult situations in both Namibia and Botswana. The South African archives are well run, on professional lines, and I am sure our national archives will maintain regular contact with them.

Again, I thank the parliament for giving me the opportunity to be part of this delegation to Africa, a part of the world in which I have a particular interest. I pay tribute to the long-suffering secretary of the delegation, Peter Roberts, who maintained good humour throughout—not always an easy thing to do with a parliamentary delegation—and I thank the members of the delegation for their friendship exhibited during the trip.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will enjoy joining in this particular debate about the delegation to southern Africa. It was with some trepidation that I joined this delegation, but I was lucky enough to do that. We were given a briefing prior to going which suggested that it was going to be a high security risk area to go to, and my colleagues from the other side who were going with me were renowned as `comrades'—I guess that is the best terminology—but they turned out to be very good friends as well as comrades.

PARA.TAB: What surprised me is something that the member for Adelaide (Ms Worth) has mentioned. Although the region is still a bit unstable, the security aspect was not highly noticeable in our trip around the place. Certainly among the people that we spoke to, the reconciliation aspect was very good.

My general feeling is that the whole southern African region is one of high opportunity for Australia. Certainly in the former front-line states of Zimbabwe, Botswana and Namibia there are huge opportunities for us in trade and also in other dealings—in particular in aid, but also in intellectual areas such as information systems and education.

What impressed me most in those front-line areas was Namibia. Although Namibia has been independent for four years, what surprised and disappointed me most is that we have not had one trade person contact the chamber of commerce in all that time. I note that the Western Australian government is taking a trade delegation to the southern African region and is including Namibia in its trip, which will be good.

I believe that specific areas of information systems present a huge opportunity for computer systems in that particular region. In Botswana I was surprised to see very few computer terminals in the parliament and in government offices. We were told at one stage that the tax system in Botswana is still done manually. It totally surprised me that, in this information technology world, we have tax systems still being done manually. Another area that we can work on in southern Africa is that of education—not only in providing resources, but also in providing the expertise in planning and curriculum development. They are very short on that expertise, particularly in Namibia and Botswana. We have an opportunity there of exporting our knowledge in curriculum development.

Another area of opportunity concerns air links. I believe Qantas has established an extra flight per week to the region, but I believe there are opportunities for us to take people to London via southern Africa. If we were to develop more air links between the two regions, we would be developing tourism as a two-way area.

I noticed some matters over there which were of concern. The honourable member for Adelaide mentioned health and, in particular, AIDS. That is a very serious concern in that region and we, as a First World country, should be very concerned about the development of that particular virus in southern Africa and perhaps should be making representations elsewhere so we can address the issue over there.

There was another area of concern for me in South Africa. We travelled to a township called Alexandria. Alexandria is a place of one square kilometre and there are about 300,000 people living in that square kilometre. They live in an array of different housing, mostly lean-tos or shacks. We went to a community hall which had, I think, 200 people living in it. Being the tallest member of the delegation, I was able to look down to observe the living conditions of people there. They had wardrobes facing each other and cardboard boxes and they had passageways into each little family area. Inside, I saw four or five people sitting or lying round in something the size of a double bed. There were 200 people living in this particular community hall and there were sanitary problems—toilets and things like that were not very good.

It was a humbling experience to go to Alexandria, but the shining light about this place was that we went to a community centre which had a community hall and also a library. What was disappointing about this particular library was that most of the shelves were empty. People were looking for books to fill the shelves. It must be pleasing to my delegation comrades to know that I have started up an appeal in my own electorate to get some high quality, hardcover books from primary schools and to get them over there. They are not just children's books but technical books and also non-fiction books.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hansard?

—Yes, we can send some copies of Hansards over, comrade. It would not be a problem at all. My first delegation was a very gruelling delegation. We were away for about 21 days. Of those 21 days, we had three days off and those three days were fully structured as well. I must commend the leader for his discipline on the trip—he had everyone arriving on time. My colleague the honourable member for Throsby (Mr Hollis) showed a lot of patience and a lot of humour, especially towards hotel staff and during checkouts and things like that.

PARA.TAB: It was a good trip. I think everyone enjoyed it. The highlight of the trip was the farewell dinner in Namibia. The leader of the delegation and the deputy leader spoke and then a couple of other people got up and spoke. It was a particular highlight. Another highlight was the visit we made to Vice-President Nkomo in Zimbabwe. He was a very friendly chap. He gave us a rendition of some of his favourite songs.

The other highlight, I guess, was visiting the archives in South Africa with the member for Throsby, where we met the gentleman who actually designed the new flag. There were 8,000 entries for the flag design—unlike Australia, which had 35,000—and not one of them was picked. In fact, the gentleman we met decided to do it all himself, which was interesting. He was explaining it to us on the way down in the lift; it was another highlight.

All in all, it was a good trip. I want to thank my colleagues for the friendliness that they showed me after the hesitation that they had at the start of the tour. They realised by the end of the tour it was not so bad. Thanks should go, in particular, to the High Commissioner for Zimbabwe. I think he and his staff provided much help. The briefings were fantastic and he showed his superior knowledge of the region.

I also want to make mention of one particular person in Cape Town, Luke Williams. I think his role was difficult because we were very demanding at the end of our tour. We were a demanding delegation and he accommodated us very well. All in all, it was a successful trip. We got a lot of information from it. I think that we can learn from our particular visit in the area of trade—in particular, information systems. There are a lot of opportunities there for Australia. I look forward to—perhaps—Mexico.
Debate (on motion by Mr Griffiths) adjourned.
Debate resumed from 5 December, on motion by Mr Halverson:
That the House take note of the paper.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is probably an understatement to say that there is some confusion surrounding the calculation of the Child Support Agency's collection rate. In order to clear it up, we need to have some explanations. Let me give the Committee some examples. Firstly, the child support scheme fact sheet supplied to the committee by the Department of Social Security states that 75 per cent of liabilities registered with the CSA are being collected. I might add that a private collection arrangement under the law needs to be registered. Secondly, in its supplementary submission to the committee which was received on 30 June 1994, the CSA states that the overall collection rate of 73 per cent in July 1993 has improved to 75 per cent in May 1994. First off we have liabilities registered; now we are talking about a collection rate.

PARA.TAB: Thirdly, the ministerial statement issued on 5 December states that in 1994-94 the CSA collected an amount equal to 75 per cent of the liabilities raised. In the House, the Assistant Treasurer (Mr Gear) said on 6 December that the CSA collected 75 per cent of net liabilities. In addition, since the scheme has started, the CSA has collected 68 per cent of all debt. It is unclear to me, and I think to the committee, where the collection rate applies. Does it apply to all those cases registered with the CSA? Does it apply to all liabilities? If so, what are they? Does it apply to net liabilities? If so, what are they? What is the overall amount of debt—is it an overall amount of debt, or is it an annualised debt? I am happy to plead to some confusion. I hope the Committee might understand that with these different terms being applied at different times there is a degree of confusion.

I want to place on record some thanks, because when one tables a report one does not get that opportunity. In particular, I want to extend my thanks to Michael Carmody, the head of the Australian Taxation Office, and Moira Scollay. It is my belief that the committee has been privileged to receive very good cooperation from them. I also want to say something about the staff of the CSA. Firstly, they were very generous, because the committee was able to go around to quite a number of agency offices and on each and every occasion we had an opportunity to sit down with staff and to discuss the problems as they saw them. I have no doubt that the Child Support Agency is staffed by very genuine people who are working extremely hard in an area that I am the first to admit is very difficult and very complex.

I guess I have made the point in the report that I have felt that the staff have been forced in some ways to try to exercise their role with one hand behind their back. I also wish to acknowledge that since the inquiry has started there has been a whole myriad of changes that have either been piloted or commenced in the agency. I have never been backward in wanting to offer my congratulations and support for these changes. I would say that the committee's report has created quite a number of challenges for the staff, and that we have really set the bar very high. If the recommendations of this committee are adopted by the agency and successfully implemented, it will be performing at the highest possible level.

Last, but not least, I would like to thank both Michael Carmody and Moira Scollay for the opportunity on three different occasions to speak to different people, including all the top people in the agency, to discuss the report and to be challenged by their questions. I would be less than honest if I did not report that I very much appreciated those exercises and that they did cause me to reflect on a number of points. I want to reinforce what I have said, that the agency has sought to cooperate fully with the inquiry and it has made the committee's work a lot easier than it might otherwise have been. As can be seen in my comments about the collection rate, there are still some difficulties either in reporting or language that we need to overcome. I will be looking forward to the explanation of the different terminologies.

I would also like to sincerely thank the members of my secretariat, who worked particularly hard and diligently throughout the course of the inquiry. It was a very complex inquiry and I do not think their role was made any easier by some of the demands I placed on them, but I would certainly like to acknowledge the depth and the quality of the work that has gone into the report. There is another member of the committee present and it would be unfair if I did not acknowledge the fact that there were nine other members of this committee who signed up for a very difficult task. It is pleasing to report that, whilst no member can stand up and claim to have achieved 100 per cent of what he or she sought out of the report, the report does, with one dissenting report, constitute a consensus amongst the committee—and not a consensus that is at the lowest common denominator, a consensus that I think reflects the best traditions of parliamentary inquiry.

I think it is fair to say that this report will be of great interest to electorate offices of members and senators, so I particularly want to draw the attention of members and senators to appendix 3 of the report, which models the changes to the formula. I want to give a couple of examples of how it could be used.

Firstly, in a case where the number of children with the custodial parent is two and the non-custodial parent has no new or adopted children or is in fact single, the non-custodial parent's income is $20,000 and the CP is a sole supporting pensioner at zero income, what would be the changes that the formula would put in place? It is true that the NCP would pay $430 less but still, on $20,000, have a commitment to pay $2,821. The change to the CP annually would be $216. As to the relative disposable income—again the NCP earning $20,000, the CP on supporting parent's pension—the NCP would have a disposable income, after tax, Medicare and child support, of $14,129; the custodial parent's disposable income would be $15,598.70. That does not include the value of fringe benefits, which perhaps should be added in but have not been.

Let us take an example where the parents are both earning money. This is not a typical example but let us say that the NCP earns $30,000 and the CP earns $30,000. What then would be the change? The non-custodial parent would be paying $1,733 less and the CP would receive that much less, but the NCP would be paying $4,218 in child support per annum. The NCP would have a disposable income of $19,000.50 and the custodial parent would have $29,660.10 income left.

I will take an example where there are two children from a previous relationship and two children that are counted in. Again in this example the non-custodial parent is earning $20,000. Effectively, he has responsibility for four children—that is, two from his first family and two in the new. The change in the non-custodial parent's disposable income would be $947; the custodial parent would receive that amount less. The NCP would have a disposable income of $23,100 and the custodial parent would have a disposable income of $13,621.

In an example where the non-custodial parent is earning $30,000 and the custodial parent is earning $30,000, what would be the changes? It would be $2,020 less child support that the non-custodial parent is responsible for; the same amount less would be received by the custodial parent. The child support being paid by the non-custodial parent would be $1,627. The non-custodial parent with a wife and two children would have a disposable income of $24,124.10 and that of the custodial parent, who has the care of the two children, would be $27,069.10.

It is always useful to provide honourable members with examples of the implications of the proposed modelling changes to the formula. Again I caution honourable members not to do what the ministerial statement has done, which is to seize upon one recommendation and extrapolate from that, but to look at the report as a whole. It is most definitely a package of recommendations. I think the dearest wish of all committee members would be that the recommendations are mulled over carefully and over some time, so that the response to them is well thought out and structured.

I am fond of saying that if there are problems with the recommendations I will be really pleased to hear about them. But, if people—particularly the public at large—feel that these recommendations are worthwhile, I really feel that they need to exercise a bit of people power to ensure that the government picks up the recommendations, that we see an early cabinet submission and, indeed, that we see the legislation implemented as quickly as possible.

I want to finish on this note: I am not aware of any committee member who did not think that the child support scheme was a good scheme, particularly in concept. I am not aware that any committee member brought a particular bias to committee deliberations. I am not aware that anyone can say about this report that a committee member, or the committee, favoured non-custodial parents, or favoured custodial parents. What the committee was all about was wanting to strengthen this scheme, to see it become more effective, more efficient and capable of sympathetically dealing with the trauma of separation.

I think we have done a decent bit of work in the child support scheme. Our second reference is into the funding administration of the Family Court. We will be dealing with that as quickly as we can; hopefully, we will complete it by the middle of next year.

For those that are involved in the trauma of separation and break-up—or in examining their entrails, as the committee was—I must say that it is a pity that we do not have a positive reference. So much government action, so much government interest and so many government dollars go into the damage end of relationships. No-one in the Committee, I am sure, pretends that we can wave a magic wand and make separations disappear or go away. I certainly do not pretend that I or the committee possess such power. But I do say we have got the proportions all wrong. It is an absolute tragedy that the committee does not have a reference to look at the way in which we may provide positive support to families, or to those people in long-term relationships.

Marriages and relationships are dynamic things; they change over time. The demands of each partner change over time. They need to be constantly worked at. There are highs and lows, pressures and crises, and—I regret to say—there is not a lot of structure in place to provide some assistance or some counselling. I sincerely believe that the dollars going into saving or attempting to repair relationships are going to yield many dollars worth of value.

Not every relationship will be saved; not every marriage will be saved. But we are not making any effort about too many of them. That is the tragedy.
