It is my particular dilemma, in the International Year of the Family, that this committee—the work of which in the last parliament was well received, and the pioneering work of which on the child support scheme will be acknowledged as a benchmark report—does not have the opportunity, via a reference, to pick up this important sector and to try to complete its pioneering work in this family law area.

The committee probably would not have all the answers or all the clues. But I am sure that we could come up with some very worthwhile suggestions and recommendations that ordinary people—ordinary family members, who feel that they have nowhere to turn—would be able to benefit from. I commend the report, and I look forward to the contribution of my esteemed colleague from Queensland, the honourable member for Capricornia (Ms Henzell), who is also a member of the committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Henzell Ms M.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to speak on the report of the Joint Select Committee on Certain Family Law Issues because it has been a serious responsibility to participate in such a far-reaching inquiry. I thought it was very positive that as a joint committee with representatives of all parties in the parliament the considerable debate within the committee was very often not along party lines.

PARA.TAB: During very intense discussion on many aspects of the scheme members of the committee became very aware of the complexity of the arrangement. We were not looking at just the child support formula; we had to look at the issue of child support in relation to the Family Law Act and the Department of Social Security arrangements, so that at all times we were aware that this was a very difficult inquiry. We are very much indebted to the secretariat, which provided a huge amount of analysis and work. Departments also responded to our requests, even when that took some little time. The modelling from the Department of Social Security,

SPEECH.PARA: for example, was most useful. The committee's recommendations need to be seen as part of a package of reforms, so I hope that the government will not just pick up on a couple of items in our recommendations, as unfortunately it has in initial media releases. The package of reforms brings in interrelationships between the Family Law Act, property settlements and the availability of existing government support and income support for families. No members of the committee have walked away from the core issue of this very important legislation: that both parents have responsibility to maintain and support their children, irrespective of what happens in their relationship.

PARA.TAB: As the Chair of the committee, the honourable member for Chifley (Mr Price), has said, it would be wrong to say that people came in with a particular mandate. It is true that as elected representatives and senators we have many constituents coming to our offices complaining about various aspects of this scheme. It is true that in our public hearings we had many non-custodial parents who were motivated to come along and express their serious concern. We sought to balance those concerns with the concerns of custodial parents.

At all times we attempted to maintain our responsibilities to the parliament and we were aware that prior to the Child Support Agency and the arrangements that are presently in place taxpayers of this country were effectively the de facto parents of many children whose parents' relationships had broken down.

In 1987 when I was working professionally in a mining town I had a number of high income earners on $60,000 to $80,000 a year who were paying possibly less than $20 a week, the maximum income that a single parent could receive before it affected his or her pension. This was obviously unjust, placed a significant burden on other taxpayers and led to an increasing number of sole parents falling well below the poverty line. There is no doubt that the child support legislation has required parents to assume their responsibilities. Indeed, there has been a major change in social attitudes in terms of acknowledging that responsibility.

In most cases, non-custodial parents who appeared before the committee acknowledged and admitted their responsibility. Their concern was in relation to the burden that the current formula placed on them. One of the recommendations that we have made is an attempt in our modification of the formula to provide a slight degree of equity and justice between custodial and non-custodial parents.

Although modelling from the Department of Social Security indicated that non-custodial parents were always better off, it was very hard to relate that to the evidence in submissions, through our hotline, and in public evidence, where non-custodial parents said that they were not able to afford to maintain themselves after they had fulfilled their child support obligations and that they were often forced to live with their parents or be supported by partners or friends. That is not a situation that is conducive to ex-marital harmony—if we can put it that way—and to the development of positive parenting relationships following the breakdown of marriage.

One of the issues that I was always concerned about in my professional work was to indicate clearly to parents that, irrespective of what happened to their relationship, the one relationship that was never going to change was that they were parents to their children. They had to meet those responsibilities and develop a continuing, positive relationship with their children following the breakdown of the marriage.

There is no doubt that the burdens and stresses associated with the amount of child support non-custodial parents have been paying and the relationship with the Child Support Agency have had a negative effect on those adjustments, which I think all members of this House would acknowledge are very difficult. One of the great challenges for the Child Support Agency when it was set up was that its workers were not used to dealing with traumatised individuals in this particular way.

What happened, and what caused a great deal of hostility on the part of non-custodial parents, was that after having dealt with the early trauma of the breakdown, and often making arrangements, transferring funds, agreeing to cover bankcard debts, giving the custodial parent maybe the car or the house, and having a number of costs in terms of early resettlement, they would then receive an unreadable letter from the Child Support Agency which would indicate their liability and often a considerable debt because of the delay in processing the application.

Non-custodial parents would then react in a very hostile manner. They would try to contact the agency and either would not be able to get through or, when they did get through, would be told, `This is your problem. We are here to collect money for custodial parents.' The perception that the Child Support Agency was down on non-custodial parents gained wide currency. Certainly, the reforms that we are suggesting in terms of the way the agency handles its business and some of the reforms that have already been put in place by the Australian Taxation Office will assist that process.

However, we did feel, as a committee, that there needed to be changes to aspects of the formula. One of the contentious issues—and it was referred to by the Assistant Treasurer (Mr Gear) yesterday in his answer in the House—is the cap on the high income earners. It was originally recommended by the consultative group that that be set at twice average weekly earnings. One of the reasons it appears to have been changed before the legislation came into effect was the cost to parents of going back to court to seek a review.
In evidence to our committee, the Department of Social Security noted, and I quote from page 338 of the report:

SPEECH.PARA: By way of context DSS notes that of Stage 2 cases registered with the CSA at 24 February 1994, there are 472 NCPs with taxable income over $70,000 where the custodian has income in the range of $0-$7,000.
In effect, the change reducing the cap from 2.5 per cent of average weekly earnings to two per cent will affect a relatively small number of people.

TALK.START.PARA: —How many was that again?

—The Department of Social Security, in its letter to the committee dated 12 May, designated the number of non-custodial parents as being 472. Although it may appear that in reducing the cap we are actually giving high income earners a free go, it has become a severe disincentive. In fact, it becomes a transfer of assets to the non-custodial ex-partner. In many cases, those high income earners are willing and able to provide income support for their children in the way of school fees, health insurance and so on. Our recommendations for flexibility will allow non-custodial parents to have more say in the way that the transfers are made. Non-custodial parents will be able to direct a proportion of their income support without the consent of the custodial parent and a high degree with the consent of the custodial parent, allowing them more involvement in the way the moneys are spent.

PARA.TAB: The committee did not agree with the submissions from some non-custodial parents that they should have full control over the way their child support is spent. There is a group of non-custodial parents who want to continue to control and dominate their ex-partners, and we do not want to see child support payments used to control and harass custodial parents.

It is very important to provide some relief at the high income end so that there is not total disincentive. The committee believes that the disregarded income level and the self-support component should be balanced. To tell non-custodial parents that we will give them the equivalent of the dole after they have worked very hard and before we take into consideration their child support responsibilities would be seen by non-custodial parents as discriminatory. Although the amount has not been raised very much, at 1.2 per cent of the pension it will give some measure of relief. At the same time, we recommend that the disregarded income for custodial parents be reduced from average weekly earnings plus the child care component. Effectively this means that the contribution by custodial parents will not be taken into account until they achieve an income of approximately $34,000 to $37,000. That range covers very few custodial parents. We feel that it is more effective to bring the level down to the pension cut-off point, and then to ease down to 50c in the dollar the amount by which the child support withdrawal is calculated.

This may appear to be a disincentive to custodial parents, but there are many opportunities for supporting parents to achieve assistance through the Department of Social Security; the JET scheme is an effective example. At the same time, in intact families the situation is that many mothers are in the work force. We want to encourage single parents and custodial parents into the work force, and we believe that by providing equity there is a degree of justice on both sides.

We believe that the package needs to be seen as a package of reforms. I suspect we will please very few people out there in the community but we would hope that both the government and the community will look at the package as a reform package that goes a deal of the way to redressing some of the concerns that the community obviously has and put before this committee during its hearings and on the hotline.
I commend the report. I thank all my colleagues on the committee for a very productive and hard working commitment to attempt to address these wrongs.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Andrews Mr K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to make a few brief remarks in support of the comments that have been made by the Chairman of the Joint Select Committee on Certain Family Law Issues, the honourable member for Chifley (Mr Price), and the member for Capricornia (Ms Henzell) in her remarks about this report. In many respects this is an amazing report. Here is a report of a joint parliamentary committee to which 6,197 submissions were received. That is a record number of submissions in the history of the Commonwealth of Australia. According to information provided by Telecom when a telephone hotline was set up, at least 150,000 attempts were made to contact the committee by people who had a particular interest in the child support scheme.

PARA.TAB: This report is about an operation of government which has been the subject, in terms of the size of the agency, of more complaints to the Commonwealth Ombudsman than any other agency in the Commonwealth of Australia. Almost every member of this parliament at one stage or another over the last few years has made reference to or raised complaints about, either publicly in the chamber or privately with the minister concerned on behalf of constituents, the way in which the Child Support Agency has operated since its inception.

Here we have a report of a parliamentary committee which has been the subject of considerable public discussion, public debate and public input. On that basis alone, I would have thought that it was a report which the responsible ministers of government would have said, on the basis of anecdotal experience, is something that we ought to take careful consideration of. To that one can add a further dimension, and that is that the joint select committee comprises members of both the Senate and the House of Representatives and embodies a range of opinions, political and otherwise. It does not simply reflect the division in this place between the Labor and the non-Labor side of politics. It reflects an ideological spectrum even within those divisions of Labor and non-Labor.

I am not going to name where people sit because we all have our own impressions or perceptions on the ideological spectrum, but it is a committee which includes Senator Carr, the honourable member for Chifley, the honourable member for Capricornia, the member for Oxley (Mr Les Scott) and Senator Neal from the Labor party. It includes Senator Spindler from the Democrats and the member for Tangney (Mr Williams), Senator Brownhill, me and Senator Reid, the deputy chairman of the committee. I would have thought anyone who is a student of Australian politics, even in a most basic way, would realise that that covers just about the entire ideological spectrum which is represented in the houses of parliament of the Commonwealth of Australia.

The report runs to some 687 pages. Other than in relation to a couple of matters raised by one senator in a dissenting report, it is a unanimous report of this committee. It represents the entire political spectrum of thought, ideals and aspirations in Australia. I refer to the dissenting report because I want to quote what Senator Neal said to put it in context. She starts off by saying:

SPEECH.PARA: I must begin this report by stating quite clearly that, even though there are some issues in the Joint Committee report that I cannot agree with, I believe that the majority of the matters raised and the recommendations set out within that report will be of great benefit to the Child Support Scheme and to those whose lives are affected by the operation of the Scheme.
In her concluding paragraph, Senator Neal says:
Notwithstanding my disagreement on these matters—
three matters which she sets out in her short dissenting report—
I again state my support for the balance of the recommendations of the Joint Committee report.

So here we have a report from a committee which covers the political spectrum of people from the Senate and the House of Representatives of the Commonwealth parliament which is unanimous in all but three matters which are raised by Senator Neal. Senator Neal states twice in her dissenting report that she has total support for the majority of the recommendations. Having this background of the Child Support Agency which has been complained about vigorously and quite loudly by many constituents and complained about on their behalf by many members of parliament, and having a report which was 18 months in the drafting, one would have expected that this was an amazing situation which would have led to some sort of response from the government. It could have said, for example, `We note the work that has been undertaken by the committee. There are a lot of serious matters that need resolution and further thought and consideration and that will be given in due course.' As members of the committee, we would have hoped that a rider would have been added saying that that would have been done as soon as possible.

PARA.TAB: What do we get in response? We get something within 24 hours of the report being released. I have been working on this report with my colleagues for 18 months. I could not have read this report and understood it in 24 hours. We have read and re-read and drafted and redrafted and found fine nuances in particular aspects or in aspects of the complexity of the law. We went over the complications of the matters over and over again and we talked about and discussed and reworded to come up with this report after 18 months of reading submissions and listening to many people around the country; yet we have this amazing situation of a response from two members of the government in relation to this—and I suspect they are out of kilter, even with most of their colleagues—within less than 24 hours, about 12 hours. They are basically writing off a whole chunk of the report and saying that this is something which we are simply not going to deal with.

I think this really points to the problem that the people who made submissions to this report are going to have to deal with. It has been pointed out quite clearly by my colleagues on the other side that this is a package of recommendations. There is not one member of the joint select committee who will not say that this was a package of recommendations, because quite clearly it is. They are recommendations which must be seen in the light of being a package and being integrated with each other. We cannot simply pluck one out and say, `I don't like that so I am not going to deal with that but I might deal with something else.' It is like a stack of cards or a house of cards; if one is pulled out, others fall down. As a consequence, on that basis the whole report would be a total waste of time. Given that there is this broad support from the committee which was charged with the responsibility of listening to the concerns of the community about the Child Support Agency, I have to say that this is a totally amazing response—12 hours later to be writing off parts of this. I invite; I urge; I implore the ministers concerned to go back and have a look at it again rather than give this knee-jerk reaction that we have got at the present time.

In the speech I made when the chair tabled this report, I criticised the Department of Social Security. I think this is part of the problem. I want to take that criticism a bit further today. What I said was that the evasiveness of the Department of Social Security in much of its evidence to the committee was such that, had that evidence been given in a court of law, a judge would be constrained to direct the jury to consider whether or not that evidence was biased and self-serving. Now I did not say that without some support in the report itself. I want to refer briefly to certain passages of the report where that statement is clearly backed up by what is in the report. Paragraph 2.28, for example, on page 18 says:

SPEECH.PARA: The Joint Committee considers that the findings from CSEAG's evaluation—
CSEAG is the evaluation advisory committee—

of each stage of the Scheme may be open to question on the basis that they were reviewing the implementation of their own recommendations. Furthermore, the research and administrative support for both the Consultative Group and CSEAG was provided by the Department of Social Security who had a significant role in the Scheme's development and who were far from disinterested in the outcome.
If we turn over to chapter 22, again we find there are a series of paragraphs which deal with this particular issue. I go to chapter 22, paragraph 22.1, which says:

The Joint Committee has stated its concern in respect of the impartiality of past evaluations of the Child Support Scheme in previous Chapters of its report. In particular, given that the membership of the main body responsible for the evaluation of the performance of the Scheme, the Child Support Evaluation Advisory Group (CSEAG), was exclusively drawn from membership of the Consultative Group whose report, Child Support, Formula for Australia (1988), was critical in the establishment of formula assessment under Stage 2 of the Scheme, the Joint Committee was immediately concerned over the impartiality of CSEAG's findings. Upon examination of CSEAG's evaluation reports, these concerns unhappily proved to be well founded. The Joint Committee discovered that the only major survey which evaluated the impact of the Scheme virtually overlooked the financial situation of non custodial parents and subsequent families. Furthermore, CSEAG's analysis in respect of key components of the child support formula such as the custodial parent disregarded income level was grossly inadequate.

We go on to say that the chapter sets out some views in relation to future evaluations. I wish to read a couple of other paragraphs from chapter 22, because they reinforce what I have said, and what I believe is the problem as it has been illustrated in terms of the response that has been made by the ministers to date. In paragraph 22.5 of the report we say:

Any future evaluation of the child support Scheme must be seen to be truly independent and outside the influence of the departments with policy responsibility for the Scheme, as well as any other parties who have played a significant role in the establishment of the Scheme or in any past evaluation of it. In this way any future evaluations of the Scheme will be publicly seen to be truly independent thereby ensuring public confidence in the results of these evaluations and the Scheme is generally enhanced.
And in the following paragraph, 22.6, we say:

The Joint Committee notes the Department of Social Security (DSS) dominates the policy aspects of the Scheme whilst the Australian Institute of Family Studies (AIFS) has been the major body assisting with the evaluations of the Scheme. Neither DSS or the AIFS could be considered to be at `arms length' to the Scheme and the Joint Committee considers that any future evaluation should be conducted at arms length from both organisations.
Then we go on to suggest a way in which that could be done. Finally, to reinforce the point, in paragraph 22.13 we say:

The Joint Committee notes that the modelling of the impact of the Child Support Scheme is monopolised by DSS. As highlighted in Chapter 4, DSS has a direct financial interest in the Scheme and consequently is far from disinterested in the outcomes produced by its modelling of the impact of the Scheme. This potential conflict of interest is exacerbated by the fact that the clients of DSS under the Scheme are sole parent pensioners who represent over 90 per cent of custodial parents under the Scheme. Consequently, the Joint Committee considers that the public confidence in the Scheme can be best served by DSS commissioning an independent party to conduct all future modelling of the impact of the Scheme on the relative disposable incomes of both parents.

So, Mr Deputy Speaker, the evidence in the report is quite clear, and the recommendations which are endorsed by all members of the joint select committee are quite clear from reading these paragraphs of the report. The problem here is that we have a scheme which was basically devised by, and implemented within, a policy section of the Department of Social Security; that reviews and evaluations of the scheme up until the one by the joint select committee were largely conducted or influenced by that same policy section of the Department of Social Security; and that now we have that same policy section of the Department of Social Security presumably giving the ministers advice about the way in which they should react to this scheme.

PARA.TAB: This comes back to what I think is a fundamental misunderstanding about the problems which arise in relation to the Child Support Agency, because it seems to me that there has been an attempt to set up two groups of parents against each other as if there were a conflict that they were at war with each other about. The two groups of parents are custodial parents and non-custodial parents. Other members of the committee have spoken about the tragedy and the emotional trauma of marriage breakdown and divorce, and what we need to try and do to deal with that. I do not have time to speak about that today, except to endorse those remarks.

It is a nonsense to suggest that these two groups of parents are somehow in conflict with each other and that the way we enhance the position of one group is by somehow putting aside the rights and position of the other. Overwhelmingly, the complaint of non-custodial parents was that in many circumstances their particular financial arrangements were not being taken into account. We have mountains of evidence about that so it is a nonsense to simply dismiss it out of hand. A group of custodial parents said that it was simply impossible to get payments from some of their former spouses. Those two groups are not in conflict with each other; they are two separate sets of problems. This response, which reeks of saying that there is a conflict, is one which is simply not credible. I urge the ministers to withdraw their remarks and consider the matter.
Debate (on motion by Mr Gibson ) adjourned.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: United Nations International Conference on Population and Development

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 17 November, on motion by Dr Theophanous:
That the House take note of the paper.

TALK.START.PARA: —People sometimes question the outcomes of international conferences, especially huge conferences such as the United Nations International Conference on Population and Development held in Cairo from 5 September to 13 September this year: are they huge talkfests or do meaningful achievements come from them? I suppose, in all honesty, it is a combination of both. There are endless speeches of varying quality and there is a certain amount of political point scoring or governments pushing their own particular line, but there are also some achievements and some meaningful outcomes—not always immediate, but meaningful nevertheless.

PARA.TAB: A world population in excess of five billion, growing by about 90 million each year, has been of increasing concern to many people for some years. What did come out of Cairo—I think it is true to say this—is that population growth is now viewed as a matter of global concern. I also feel that many people are now looking at population in a wider context, in that it can no longer be seen as a problem which can be tackled in isolation from social and economic conditions. Population must be seen as part of an overall global, economic and environmental problem.

There was also much discussion about abortion and I might say that the Catholic Church played a most unhelpful role. No-one at Cairo, or anywhere, was advocating abortion as a means of family planning. It was being said that where abortion is conducted it must be carried out in a proper medical and hygienic manner. Indeed, for some time it seemed that the Vatican was advocating backstreet abortions. Perhaps the negative stand of the Catholic Church on family planning will not change until there are a few women in the hierarchy of the Catholic Church. Ageing men, wandering around in drag, are hardly competent to pontificate on how women should control their fertility.

Of course one of the issues that caused most concern, indeed fright to many delegates, was the issue of empowering women. Many of the male delegates were prepared to agree to the mainstream views of the conference until it came to the question of the empowerment of women. This was too much for many of them but to me the issue seems quite straightforward: until we empower women and take away barriers such as illiteracy and economic dependency the world will make no progress on the population question.

One is aware of cultural differences and it is not acceptable for the West, or Australia, to put value judgments on other parts of the world. This is where I take issue with many of my colleagues, even in this House. There is a tendency for us, as politicians, to pontificate on the national or international scheme to impose our moral judgments on others. There is absolutely nothing to indicate that politicians are in any position to impose their value judgments, or their morality, on any other section of the community and we should resist the temptation to do this.

In Cairo, there was much discussion concerning respect for religious, ethical and cultural considerations. This, for me, caused a great difficulty because, while respecting religious, ethical and cultural considerations, nevertheless, if we are going to make any progress, these are the very considerations that, in many respects, have to be challenged.

For many people, it is a cultural matter that women have no rights and are not treated equal to men. For many Roman Catholics and others, the whole question of birth control weighs heavily on their religious considerations. It is important that many of these long held cultural considerations be, at least, challenged.

Less than 100 years ago, it was a cultural tradition that women in China had their feet bound. It took many people much effort to challenge this cultural tradition and have it changed. The same could apply to female circumcision. For some, this is a cultural tradition and it is argued that those outside the society in which the practice occurs have no right to challenge that tradition. The same argument is put up, and indeed was put up in Cairo, about the role of women, people saying that outsiders from the particular cultural tradition had no right to challenge it. This to me is a nonsense argument and, until some of these religious, ethical and cultural considerations are challenged, all the talk about population is meaningless.

It can be said that abortion is a mistake and that, in an ideal world where there is proper education and information about family planning, it would not be resorted to. This is why I found it staggering that some people, including the Prime Minister of Pakistan, argued against sex education. It must be acknowledged that unsafe abortion and its consequences are a major public health concern which governments must address.

Post-Cairo, there is widespread recognition that, to be successful, population programs need to integrate development and family planning objectives and to include strategies for addressing this social and economic disadvantage so often associated with high levels of population growth. I was very pleased to participate in what was known as `Parliamentarian's Day', which was held in the chamber of the National Assembly of Egypt. On this occasion, my friend and colleague the honourable member for Calwell (Dr Theophanous) made what I thought was one of the best contributions of the day. In his speech, he highlighted the concern to achieve social justice for all humanity. He also stressed the universal basis of social justice. Without going into the complex philosophical argument, it can be summed up simply. All the main religions of the world, all the main moral philosophies and all the major traditions of democratic policies have one underlying premise: all human beings are of equal moral worth. The basic premise of equality is the foundation of the key religions of today's modern world, including Christianity, Islam, Judaism and Buddhism.

Although I was not part of the official delegation to the Cairo conference itself, my participation in Cairo was to do with my membership of the Asian Forum of Parliamentarians on Population and Development. In Cairo, there were meetings, discussions and plans to make politicians more aware of the population issue, including the IPU meeting of politicians called `World Population Day'.

I am pleased that the program of action from Cairo was endorsed. Although some countries have entered reservations, nevertheless, member nations are committed to regularly assess their progress towards implementation of the program of action and to report on a periodic basis. Many of the goals set out within the program are ones to which Australia has already given high priority and the targets are more than met.

In other areas, Australia meets standards at a national level but needs to continue to address the needs of particular groups, such as indigenous peoples, people in rural and remote areas and people from non-English speaking backgrounds. Australia needs to position itself early in ensuring that it meets, or more than meets, the objectives of the program of action. A detailed examination of the program of action has, therefore, been initiated and further statements on the results of these reviews are expected to be made early next year.

Population is an issue for each of us. Perhaps because we as a country are not overpopulated, the issue does not generate as much debate in Australia or among Australian politicians as it should. If population in Australia is not a problem—although some suggest it already is—it certainly is for many of our near neighbours, for example PNG and countries such as Tuvalu and Kiribati. If reports are correct, global warming and the possible increase in sea level will cause a real problem for those countries. Countries such as the Cook Islands will not remain the paradises they are if the population issue is not dealt with.

As I said, population is an issue that affects us all. But it is not a single issue and cannot be viewed in isolation from social, economic and environmental issues. I regard the Cairo conference as important and was pleased to have the opportunity to be in that city of some 14 million persons, along with representatives from some 180 nations, to discuss with people issues as diverse as sustainable development and women's reproductive rights.

I congratulate those associated with the Australian delegation. Let us each ensure that in years to come the Cairo conference is regarded not as a giant talkfest but as a turning point regarding population and sustainable development.
Debate (on motion by Mr O'Keefe) adjourned.
